A,C:  (Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    On May 3, "[the] Minister of Health has received the second dose of the COVID-19 injection at Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha Hospital this morning, along with the Permanent Secretary, Deputy Permanent Secretary, Head of Departments, senior officers, officers and staffs at the Ministry of Health; as well as officers consisting of frontliners.    Since the implementation of the National Vaccination Program for COVID-19 began on 3 April 2021, a total of 14,876 people have received the COVID-19 vaccine, of which 14,526 people have received the first dose of COVID-19 vaccine, while 350 people have received the second dose of COVID-19 vaccine.    At present, the administration of COVID-19 vaccine is still being implemented for Phase One, consisting of frontliners, students studying abroad and senior citizens aged 60 and above. Priority is given to frontliners and especially the elderly because frontliners have a higher risk of being infected with COVID-19 and the elderly have a higher risk of getting more severe complications of COVID-19 infection. Without COVID-19 vaccine injections, clinical data obtained from around the world show those aged 60 and above are more likely to get the effects of more severe infections that require treatment in the Intensive Care Unit including respiratory assistance and have a higher risk of death as a result of the COVID-19 infection. Scientific studies have also shown that injection of COVID-19 vaccine can reduce the risk of COVID-19 infection for the elderly and frontliners."    Separate to the press release by the Ministry of Health, the Minister of Health also stated that “Brunei Darussalam will receive 200,000 doses of the Moderna vaccine and 300,000 doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, in addition to more than 100,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine in several batches. This will help to cover the COVID-19 vaccination for 70 per cent of the population by end of this year,” confirming the future expansion of Brunei's vaccination programme to use the Pfizer-BioNTech (tozinameran) and Moderna (mRNA-1273) vaccines, and the use of these two vaccines will account for 55% of Brunei's population.    On May 5, it was further announced that "the number of people [in Brunei] receiving their second dose of vaccine has reached 862, while 15,043 have just received their first dose".    See:  the Ministry of Health's press release (03 May), archived at https://archive.vn/u9EH5  the Borneo Bulletin report (03 May) entitled "Moderna vaccine on the way", archived at https://archive.vn/PgWZC  the Scoop report (03 May) entitled "55% of Brunei population to receive Pfizer, Moderna jabs", archived at https://archive.vn/4aWdG  the Borneo Bulletin report (05 May) entitled "Over 15,000 inoculated under vaccination programme", archived at https://archive.vn/K6iWQ    NB: Although this was previously reported as 3G as the Ministry of Education encouraged students heading overseas to "register" themselves for the vaccination, no such vaccinations can be confirmed to be carried out. Additionally, the Ministry of Health's press release (archived at https://archive.vn/Ta43, dated 21 May 2021) suggesting that students can finally get the vaccination via the QueUp app indicates that the vaccination of students heading overseas for further studies have not been carried out until at least 21st May.

(Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above;  +  opt-in for general population available for Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine from 6–29 May, or until stocks are depleted)    NB: This is coded as 4G; however, group B (clinically vulnerable groups which are non-elderly) are not eligible to receive the vaccination in Brunei as of yet, as they are categorised under Phase 2 of Brunei's Vaccination Strategy (Brunei is currently in Phase 1 of its vaccination strategy).    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    The Ministry currently operates an opt-in programme for the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine, due to the very low risk of thrombotic thrombocytopenia and related events the vaccine causes; alongside the National COVID-19 Vaccination Strategy (where the Sinopharm vaccine is still being offered to the groups under Phase 1; and the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine is routinely used in individuals aged 60 and above).    According to the Borneo Bulletin (owned by the Government of Brunei), "[u]nder the opt-in programme for the Oxford-Astrazeneca COVID-19 Vaccine, the AstraZeneca vaccine will be made available free of charge to all citizens, permanent residents, and foreign long-term residents in the country from May 6–29. This is made available on a voluntary basis and offered to all individuals above 18 on a-first-come-first-served basis until May 29 or until all available doses have been utilised."    Additionally, "[t]his opt-in programme will run alongside to the prioritisation phases outlined in the National COVID-19 Vaccination Strategy and allow individuals aged between 18 to 59 wishing to receive the vaccine earlier than they otherwise would be able to, the opportunity to do so with the AstraZeneca vaccine"    Furthermore, the report by Borneo Bulletin also mentions that "[v]accination with other brands (at least including Moderna and Pfizer, as per the Health Minister's comments on 3rd May) for the general population is expected to commence in the fourth quarter this year".    See:  the Borneo Bulletin report (03 May) entitled "Moderna vaccine on the way", archived at https://archive.vn/PgWZC  the Scoop report (03 May) entitled "55% of Brunei population to receive Pfizer, Moderna jabs", archived at https://archive.vn/4aWdG  the Borneo Bulletin report (10 May) entitled "AstraZeneca: What you need to know", archived at https://archive.vn/cOPsb

(Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above;  +  opt-in for general population available for Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine from 6–29 May, or until stocks are depleted)    NB: This is coded as 4G; however, group B (clinically vulnerable groups which are non-elderly) are not eligible to receive the vaccination in Brunei as of yet, as they are categorised under Phase 2 of Brunei's Vaccination Strategy (Brunei is currently in Phase 1 of its vaccination strategy).  NB2: Although this was previously reported that students heading overseas are also getting vaccinated at this point in time, as the Ministry of Education had encouraged such students to "register" themselves for the vaccination, no such vaccinations can be confirmed to be carried out. Additionally, the Ministry of Health's press release (archived at https://archive.vn/Ta43, dated 21 May 2021), suggesting that students can finally get the vaccination via the QueUp app, indicates that the vaccination of students heading overseas for further studies have not been carried out until at least 21st May.    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    There are no significant updates since the last entry. As mentioned in the last entry, the Ministry currently operates an opt-in programme for the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine, due to the very low risk of thrombotic thrombocytopenia and related events the vaccine causes; alongside the National COVID-19 Vaccination Strategy (where the Sinopharm vaccine is still being offered to the groups under Phase 1; and the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine is routinely used in individuals aged 60 and above).    According to the Borneo Bulletin (owned by the Government of Brunei), "[u]nder the opt-in programme for the Oxford-Astrazeneca COVID-19 Vaccine, the AstraZeneca vaccine will be made available free of charge to all citizens, permanent residents, and foreign long-term residents in the country from May 6–29. This is made available on a voluntary basis and offered to all individuals above 18 on a-first-come-first-served basis until May 29 or until all available doses have been utilised."    See:  the Borneo Bulletin report (10 May) entitled "AstraZeneca: What you need to know", archived at https://archive.vn/cOPsb

(Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad  +  opt-in for general population available for Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine from 6–29 May, or until stocks are depleted)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    Vaccinations using the Sinopharm vaccine is now definitively open to students travelling abroad for studies. According to a Ministry of Health press release dated on 21 May, "[it] would like to inform the public, especially students who will be studying abroad, that those who wish to receive the COVID-19 vaccine, which is the Sinopharm vaccine can get the vaccine injection at the Berakas Health Screening Center during office hours.    They can make an appointment for the Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine injection via the Queup application."    This was also reported by the Scoop, "During a press briefing on Friday (21 May), the health minister said students who will travel soon will be inoculated with the Chinese-made vaccine as the interval period between the first and second doses is 21 days.  YB Dato Seri Setia Dr Hj Md Isham Hj Jaafar said students should wait 14 days after their second Sinopharm COVID-19 shot before boarding a flight as it takes time for antibodies to kick in."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/Ta43T  See the Scoop report, archived at https://archive.vn/XJo2s

(Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad  +  opt-in for general population available for Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine from 6–29 May, or until stocks are depleted)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    There has been no further updates, however, as previously written on 6th May,    ---  The Ministry currently operates an opt-in programme for the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine, due to the very low risk of thrombotic thrombocytopenia and related events the vaccine causes; alongside the National COVID-19 Vaccination Strategy (where the Sinopharm vaccine is still being offered to the groups under Phase 1; and the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine is routinely used in individuals aged 60 and above).    According to the Borneo Bulletin (owned by the Government of Brunei), "[u]nder the opt-in programme for the Oxford-Astrazeneca COVID-19 Vaccine, the AstraZeneca vaccine will be made available free of charge to all citizens, permanent residents, and foreign long-term residents in the country from May 6–29. This is made available on a voluntary basis and offered to all individuals above 18 on a-first-come-first-served basis until May 29 or until all available doses have been utilised."    Additionally, "[t]his opt-in programme will run alongside to the prioritisation phases outlined in the National COVID-19 Vaccination Strategy and allow individuals aged between 18 to 59 wishing to receive the vaccine earlier than they otherwise would be able to, the opportunity to do so with the AstraZeneca vaccine"  ---    There has been no further updates on the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine programme open to the general public, as to whether it will be continued beyond its 29th May deadline.    See:  the Borneo Bulletin report (03 May) entitled "Moderna vaccine on the way", archived at https://archive.vn/PgWZC  the Scoop report (03 May) entitled "55% of Brunei population to receive Pfizer, Moderna jabs", archived at https://archive.vn/4aWdG  the Borneo Bulletin report (10 May) entitled "AstraZeneca: What you need to know", archived at https://archive.vn/cOPsb

(Frontline workers [Sinopharm]; senior citizens aged 60 and above [Oxford-AstraZeneca, Sinopharm]; students studying abroad [Sinopharm])    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    There has been no announcements as to whether the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine drive for the general public has been extended beyond its 29th May enddate.    There are no major updates, except "students who will be pursuing / continuing their studies abroad that they can reserve COVID-19 vaccine injection slots through the Bruhealth app commencing on Tuesday, 01 June 2021". Additionally, the elderly (aged 60 and above) are encouraged to get their vaccines.    See:  The Ministry of Health's press release on COVID-19 VACCINE for students continuing their studies abroad (dated 30 May), archived at https://archive.vn/E8gRc  The Ministry of Health's press release on encouraging COVID-19 VACCINE For The Elderly 60 Years And Over (dated 01 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/SZA4z

(Frontline workers [Sinopharm]; senior citizens aged 60 and above [Oxford-AstraZeneca, Sinopharm]; students studying abroad [Sinopharm])    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    There are no major updates.  As there still is no announcements as to whether the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine drive for the general public has been extended beyond its 29th May enddate, it can be assumed that it has concluded.    Separately, the Star (one of neighbouring Malaysia's English-speaking newspapers) reported that "[t]he Brunei government has issued updates on the Exit-Travel Application Guidelines, requiring outbound travellers to obtain mandatory Covid-19 vaccinations starting from August 1, 2021".    See previous:  The Ministry of Health's press release on COVID-19 VACCINE for students continuing their studies abroad (dated 30 May), archived at https://archive.vn/E8gRc  The Ministry of Health's press release on encouraging COVID-19 VACCINE For The Elderly 60 Years And Over (dated 01 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/SZA4z  The Star Online's report, entitled "Brunei requires mandatory Covid-19 vaccinations for outbound travellers", archived at https://archive.vn/Wavys

(Frontline workers [Sinopharm]; senior citizens aged 60 and above [Oxford-AstraZeneca, Sinopharm]; students studying abroad [Sinopharm])    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    On 14th June, the Ministry of Health announced that vaccinations of people included in the Phase 2 of Brunei's Vaccination Strategy (teachers; childcare center staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases) will commence on Monday, 21st June; and that people in this group can start booking their vaccination slots on the BruHealth app from Wednesday, 16th June.    Additionally, it was reported in the Scoop that:  "Since Brunei started its vaccine rollout on April 3, a total of 50,846 people or 11.2 percent of the population have received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine.  A total of 11,497 people, or 2.5 percent of residents, have been fully vaccinated.  The vaccine uptake among the elderly has been relatively slow since the rollout expanded to senior citizens on April 24, with just 17 percent of the targeted 38,000 seniors receiving their first dose.  Brunei currently uses Oxford-AstraZeneca and Sinopharm vaccines as part of its national vaccination campaign, with Moderna expected by the end of June, and Pfizer later in the year."      See:  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Scoop's report, entitled "Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm

Vaccination groups: Phase 1 and 2 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare center staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (mRNA-1273)    On 14th June, the Ministry of Health announced that vaccinations of people included in the Phase 2 of Brunei's Vaccination Strategy (teachers; childcare center staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases) will commence on Monday, 21st June; and that people in this group can start booking their vaccination slots on the BruHealth app from Wednesday, 16th June.    On 20th June, the Ministry of Health announced that the Moderna vaccine has arrived in Brunei.    On 21st June, it was reported by the Borneo Bulletin that the Moderna vaccines are being utilised - "scores of people lining up to receive their first shots were inoculated with the Moderna vaccine, which arrived in the country from Spain on Sunday"    See:  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Scoop's report, entitled "Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm    The Ministry of Health's press release "COVID-19 Moderna vaccine arrived in Brunei Darussalam" (dated 20 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/2onLe    Borneo Bulletin's report, entitled "Second phase of COVID-19 vaccination begins" (dated 22 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/XhM2i

Vaccination groups: Phase 1 and 2 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare centre staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran/mRNA-1273)    No significant updates. Elasomeran (the Moderna mRNA-1273 Covid-19 vaccine) was introduced in use in Brunei on 21 June, which was also the date for the start of Brunei's Phase 2 of its Vaccination Strategy.    On 28 June, the Star Online (syndicated from Borneo Bulletin) reported "Some 76,471 people in Brunei had been inoculated under the National Covid-19 Vaccination Programme by June 26, with 63, 432 having received the first dose and 13, 039 their second dose".    See:  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Scoop's report, entitled "Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm  The Ministry of Health's press release "COVID-19 Moderna vaccine arrived in Brunei Darussalam" (dated 20 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/2onLe  Borneo Bulletin's report, entitled "Second phase of COVID-19 vaccination begins" (dated 22 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/XhM2i  The Star Online's report, entitled "Brunei: Over 76, 000 received Covid-19 vaccination as country goes 417 without local cases" (dated 28 Jun), archived at https://archive.is/7F2bK

Vaccination groups: Phase 1 and 2 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare centre staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases)    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran/mRNA-1273)    On 01 July, Brunei's Ministry of Health announced that "the Phase 3 of the National Vaccination Program will commence on Monday, 24 Zulkaedah 1442 / 05 July 2021, of which Phase 3 are for individuals aged 18 years and above.    [Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot, especially for individuals who has received invitations to attend the events in conjunction with His Majesty Sultan and Yang Di-Pertuan of Brunei Darussalam's 75th Birthday Celebration this year. To facilitate the COVID-19 vaccine injection process and to avoid congestion at vaccination centres, only individuals who have a slot reservation through the BruHealth app will be allowed to receive the vaccine injection. Walk-ins will only be allowed for senior citizens and special needs individuals."    Previously, Elasomeran (the Moderna mRNA-1273 Covid-19 vaccine) was introduced in use in Brunei on 21 June, which was also the date for the start of Brunei's Phase 2 of its Vaccination Strategy. The first consignment of the vaccine will arrive in the country very soon.  The plan is to vaccinate all the people together, so we will roll out the nationwide vaccination program only when we have sufficient doses for all the targetted population.  Once we have the required number of doses, our plan is to vaccinate the entire population in their respective communities, gewogs and chiwogs in one week. We are well on track with health facilities and human resource planning. That time, movement of people will be stopped for one week.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/18-01-21-%f0%9d%90%92%f0%9d%90%9a%f0%9d%90%a5%f0%9d%90%a2%f0%9d%90%9e%f0%9d%90%a7%f0%9d%90%ad-%f0%9d%90%a9%f0%9d%90%a8%f0%9d%90%a2%f0%9d%90%a7%f0%9d%90%ad%f0%9d%90%ac-%f0%9d%90%9f%f0%9d%90%ab/

India has already supplied around 5.5 lakh vaccine doses to Bhutan in two batches. And, roughly 80% of adults in the Himalayan country have been vaccinated with the first dose. Bhutan had said that it would fully vaccinate the entire country by the end of June. However, vaccine crunch in India might delay Bhutan's plan for 100% immunization. Earlier this month, Bhutanese Foreign Minister Tandi Dorji said the Indian government had assured Bhutan that it would provide the half-million AstraZeneca vaccines, known as Covishield in India, required for the second dose to achieve full immunization.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210531151256if_/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/india-requires-more-covid-vaccines-will-not-exert-pressure-for-supply-bhutan-11621693513156.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210531151256if_/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/india-requires-more-covid-vaccines-will-not-exert-pressure-for-supply-bhutan-11621693513156.html

No vaccination policy.  COVID-19 Vaccine Information: Has the government of Botswana approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? No. The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas. Please follow host country developments and guidelines for COVID-19 vaccination. The Government of Botswana is likely to publish any news on vaccine approvals and distribution on their website at gov.bw and their social media accounts found below under “Local Resources.” Information from the CDC regarding COVID-19 vaccination.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208011805/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No availability yet. Recent announcements by the health minister about vaccination policy, that payments of about US $10 million have been made. This is in collaboration with COVAX, the AU and the private sector.     See twitter update from the office of the president (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222210609/https://twitter.com/bwpresidency/status/1357424538070433794).

No availability yet, but the government has announced that it is pursuing the purchase of vaccines and is aiming for rollout by end of March.    See public advisory (https://web.archive.org/web/20210301160351/https://twitter.com/BWGovernment/status/1365364318599004166/photo/1).

Botswana has made an upfront payment to COVAX, the World Health Organization (WHO)’s vaccine arrangement, to acquire 940,800 vaccines under a two-dose regime, enough to cover about 20 percent of the population. In addition, Botswana has paid US$7.1 million to the African Vaccine Acquisition Task Team (AVATT) to secure more vaccine doses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315081515/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Botswana received a consignment of the CoviShield Vaccine from India earlier in March. The Ministry of Health's facebook page announced the rollout on Friday the 26th of March, with group C (the elderly) as the priority.     See the vaccine self-registration portal:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330090433/https://dhis2sms.gov.bw/vaccine/    See also an earlier government press release about the consignment in early March:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210330091016/https://twitter.com/bwgovernment/status/1369215961308553219    Refer to the facebook page of the Ministry of Health for more details:  https://archive.vn/6NBHY

Botswana received its first consignment of 33,600 AstraZeneca vaccines from the COVAX facility. This is the second consignment since receiving the CoviShield Vaccine from India earlier in March. The Ministry of Health's facebook page also announced the rollout on Friday the 26th of March, with group C (the elderly) as the priority.     See the vaccine self-registration portal:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330090433/https://dhis2sms.gov.bw/vaccine/    See also an earlier government press release about the consignment in early March:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210330091016/https://twitter.com/bwgovernment/status/1369215961308553219    Refer to the facebook page of the Ministry of Health for more details:  https://archive.vn/6NBHY

Botswana received vaccines on the 28th of March. Both AstraZeneca and SK Bioscience are mentioned in the sources.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405144939/https://www.gavi.org/covax-vaccine-roll-out/botswana    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405145046/https://www.afro.who.int/news/new-dawn-botswanas-covid-19-response    Currently only people under B and C are eligible to receive vaccinations, but could not find government sources to corroborate this.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405145331/https://africa.cgtn.com/2021/03/27/botswana-receives-over-33000-doses-of-covid-19-vaccines/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330090853/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2021-03/26/c_139838942.htm

Botswana is administering mainly AstraZeneca vaccines and has done so since the end of March. A 6 April press release stated the need to protect the most vulnerable, and thus a decision has been made to prioritise the elderly above the age of 75.      See the press release:   https://archive.vn/VfzZo

Botswana is administering mainly AstraZeneca vaccines and has done so since the end of March. A 6 April press release stated the need to protect the most vulnerable, and thus a decision has been made to prioritise the elderly above the age of 75. (Group C only).    The vaccine rollout programme has halted in some areas, as announced on the official twitter, since the vaccine doses allocated to these areas were finished. Vaccination policy will only resume in these areas when the next consignment arrives, which the announcement says is in the following weeks. Other areas continue to administer their allocated vaccines.     See the announcement   https://archive.vn/ah205

•	Oxford University-AstraZeneca, Moderna, and Pfizer BioNTech have been approved for use.   •	Sinovac vaccines were delivered in April, but the Government of Botswana has not yet confirmed approval or distribution of the vaccine.   •	Janssen (Johnson&Johnson) and Gamaleya (Sputnik V) may be used in Botswana in the coming months.  •	The rollout planned through COVAX will provide 100,800 vaccines for thecountry. 24,000 AstraZeneca doses have been delivered according to COVAX.  •	The Government of Botswana reports 30,000 Covishield vaccines from India were received in early March and 200,000 doses of Sinovac were delivered on April 25.  •	Botswana began its vaccination campaign on March 26-7 and is currently only vaccinating military, police, and health practitioners along with some government officials. They will prioritize those over 75 and those over 55 with underlying health conditions as more vaccines become available.   •	Persons over 55 may already register at https://dhis2sms.gov.bw/vaccine/.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210531085646/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of June 7, 2021, according to the U.S. Embassy in Botswana, Oxford University-AstraZeneca, Moderna, Sinovac, and Pfizer BioNTech have been approved for use. Janssen (Johnson&Johnson) and Gamaleya (Sputnik V) may be used in Botswana in the coming months.     The rollout planned through COVAX will provide 100,800 vaccines for the country. 24,000 AstraZeneca doses have been delivered according to COVAX. Botswana announced the delivery of an additional 38,400 AstraZeneca doses from COVAX.  The Government of Botswana reports 30,000 Covishield vaccines from India were received in early March and 200,000 doses of Sinovac were delivered on April 25. 19,890 Pfizer doses were received through COVAX in early June.  Botswana began its vaccination campaign on March 26-7. They have opened vaccinations as of May 10 for those over 65, followed by those aged 55-64. They will prioritize those over 65 and those over 55 with underlying health conditions as more vaccines become available.  Persons over 18 may already register on the vaccine registration webpage for future availability as eligibility expands.  Government officials are being vaccinated, as confirmed on the government's Twitter.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032613/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032637/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613062420/https://dhis2sms.gov.bw/vaccine/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613053303/https://twitter.com/BWGovernment?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor

On 9 December, Health Canada approved Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine “for use in people 16 years of age or older”. “Canada will receive up to 249,000 doses” later this month. The federal government is arranging distribution to provincial governments with the first group of high-priority recipients expected to receive vaccinations before year end. See Government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210205358/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2020/12/health-canada-authorizes-first-covid-19-vaccine0.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210210347/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-services-procurement/news/2020/12/canada-to-receive-early-delivery-of-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccine.html

On 10 December, Prime Minister Trudeau repeated the Government of Canada’s commitment that the covid-19 “vaccine would be completely free for all Canadians”. See Global News website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201216164929/https://globalnews.ca/news/7514966/coronavirus-canada-vaccine-rollout-trudeau/

On 14 December, Ontario began vaccinating health care workers in Toronto and Quebec vaccinated workers and residents at long-term care facilities in Montreal and Quebec City. Other provinces are expected to start targeted vaccinations of high-risk groups later this week. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201216165500/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-canada-administers-its-first-covid-19-vaccine-shots/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214190242/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-personal-support-worker-first-person-in-canada-to-receive-dose/

A:    On 15 December, British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan began vaccinating front-line health care workers.  See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219203531/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-western-canada-long-complex-job-of-covid-19-vaccinations-begins/

A:    On 16 December, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland and Labrador, Prince Edward Island, and Manitoba began vaccinating front-line health care workers.  See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201219202229/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-manitoba-three-atlantic-provinces-to-begin-covid-19-vaccinations-today/

On 19 December, the Canadian Press news service reported that the Province of New Brunswick began vaccinations starting with front-line health care workers and long-term care residents. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221203858/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-updates-dec-19-vaccinations-now-underway-in-all-provinces/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

On 23 December, Health Canada authorized use of the Moderna vaccine to immunize against covid-19. Delivery and distribution expected before year-end. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102132802/https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/74621a-eng.php

On 28 December, Andre Picard, health reporter at the Globe and Mail newspaper, commented on what he viewed as slow progress delivering vaccinations in Canada. See article in Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102220132/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-didnt-take-a-holiday-and-the-vaccine-rollout-should-not-have/?cu_id=A6KwM2NPqY9Tjy01oPJvjyThBi3rn%2FLU

On 29 December, Canadian Press news service reported on plans in several provinces to accelerate vaccinations. See article in Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102222357/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-reports-nearly-4500-new-covid-19-cases-over-two-days/

A, C:    On 30 December, vaccinations began in remote indigenous communities in British Columbia (BC). Members of three groups -- long-term care residents, frontline workers, remote indigenous community residents -- have now been vaccinated somewhere in Canada. Vaccinations are expected to start soon in indigenous communities in other provinces. However, to my knowledge, there is no province that has vaccinated members of more than 2 groups at this time. See article in Globe and Mail newspaper website and Province of BC website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210103010814/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-vaccine-rollout-picks-up-speed-in-first-nations-across-canada/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104162416/http://www.bccdc.ca/health-info/diseases-conditions/covid-19/covid-19-vaccine/bcs-plan-for-vaccine-distribution

As of 4 January 2021, 11:18AM EST, according to the Canadian Television (CTV) News covid-19 vaccine tracker, 121,295 Canadians or 0.3% of the national population have received vaccinations. See CTV News website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104165037/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/covid-19-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

A, C:    As of 8 January 10:30AM EST, according to the CTV News covid-19 vaccine tracker, 231,807 Canadians have received a covid-19 vaccination or 0.6% of the national population. See CTV News website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210106182429/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

A, C:    As of 11 January 10:21AM EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, 328,797 Canadians have received a covid-19 vaccination or just under 0.9% of the national population. (Another unofficial vaccine tracker website shows a slightly smaller national count. It is possible that vaccine tracker websites are not reporting up-to-date information in all provinces.) See covid19tracker.ca and CTV News websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111152357/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111145425/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

On 14 January 2021, the Government of Quebec announced that, if vaccine supply is insufficient, the second vaccination dose will be delayed for up to 90 days in order to maximize first doses to members of high-risk groups. The Government of Canada’s Deputy Chief Public Health Officer “noted … that there is no data to support extending the interval past 42 days. However, he … suggested the ethical issues raised by a surge in cases and a resulting spike in hospitalizations and deaths could present an exceptional enough circumstance to justify it.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115140139/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-quebec-further-delaying-second-dose-of-covid-19-vaccines/

As of 15 January 10:21AM EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “more than 450,242 Canadians (almost 1.2% of the national population) have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. At least 24,939 Canadians (0.07%) are fully vaccinated, having received both required doses.” See covid19tracker.ca, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115153920/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html

As of 18 January 11:06AM CST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “more than 557,237 Canadians [almost 1.5% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. At least 31,199 [0.08%] Canadians are fully vaccinated, having received both required doses.” See covid19tracker.ca, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118183916/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html

A.C: On 19 January 2021, the Globe and Mail newspaper updated its “EXPLAINER: The federal and provincial rollout plans so far” which contains a clear explanation illustrated with charts on how the federal and provincial governments are working together and sharing responsibility to vaccinate Canadians. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126030320/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/

On 20 January 2021, Indigenous Services Canada announced: “The rollout of the vaccines to many First Nations, Inuit, and Métis communities has started. Vaccine administration continues within communities, thanks to the commitment of Indigenous leadership and health experts, and federal, provincial, Indigenous collaboration, including on logistics and data sharing. To date vaccination has begun in 169 communities for First Nations or Inuit in all provinces and territories except Nova Scotia and PEI.” Covid vaccinations (Pfizer and Moderna) in Canada are being administered to 3 groups -- A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or other health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126020941/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/01/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities1.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126024649/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-older-at-risk-federal-inmates-to-receive-shot-sparking-criticism-from/

As of 25 January 1:05 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “more than 733,500 Canadians [1.9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. At least 96,537 [0.25%] of Canadians are fully vaccinated, having received both required doses.” See covid19tracker.ca, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124221629/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html

As of 29 January 10:25 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “doses of COVID-19 vaccines (including both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech) have been delivered to the provinces for administration. As of today, 82.5% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 829,385 Canadians [almost 2.2% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 96,857 Canadians [0.25%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” Note that previous estimates of the number of Canadians fully vaccinated were incorrect due to a data reporting error by one of the provinces. Delays in vaccine delivery to Canada have resulted in first-does vaccinations being halted in the province of Alberta. In most other provinces and territories, vaccine supply is sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129155032/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129163115/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/covid-update-deena-hinshaw-alberta-1.5891450

As of 5 February 1:30 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “doses of COVID-19 vaccines (including both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech) have been delivered to the provinces for administration. As of today, 89.1% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 883,648 Canadians [2.3% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 150,807 Canadians [almost 0.4%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has resulted in a slower pace of vaccinations.However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131010943/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205162839/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/gov

***Updated to add link providing further support for 3 groups being vaccinated   A, B, C  As of 11 February 1:30 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “doses of COVID-19 vaccines (including both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech) have been delivered to the provinces for administration. As of today, 90.5% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 940,304 Canadians [almost 2.5% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 235,924 Canadians [0.6%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations.However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and government of Canada websites, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210211185843/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities0.html https://web.archive.org/web/20210211190042/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html

As of 19 February 11:12AM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1,007,878 Canadians [2.65% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 372,911 Canadians [almost 1%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations over the past 4 weeks. However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue vaccinations for three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217180702/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities1.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219184842/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

As of 26 February 10:21AM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1,231,835 Canadians [3.2% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna or Pfizer. 497,318 Canadians [1.3%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations over the past month. However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue vaccinations for three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). In some provinces/territories, vaccinations are starting or are about to start for elderly persons living in the community outside of care homes. On 26 Feb. 2021, Health Canada authorized the AstraZeneca vaccine (including the version from the Serum Institute of India) for use in Canada for those aged 18 and up. See CTV news, Globe newspaper, and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224122201/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226155631/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-health-canada-approves-astrazenecas-covid-19-vaccine-for-people-over/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226160443/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-with-a-mass-expansion-of-the-covid-19-vaccine-program-just-weeks-away/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226160132/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities2.html

A,B,C: On 1 March 2021, the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) “recommended against using the AstraZenec-Oxford vaccine in people aged 65 and older, although Health Canada has authorized it to be used in adults of all ages”. Most, and perhaps all, Canadian provinces and territories accepted NACI’s recommendation and updated their vaccination plans. See CBC news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308155125/https://www.cbc.ca/news/health/astra-zeneca-vaccine-naci-age-1.5932347

A,B,C: On 3 March 2021, the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) “recommends that in the context of limited COVID-19 vaccine supply, jurisdictions should maximize the number of individuals benefiting from the first dose of vaccine by extending the interval for the second dose of vaccine to four months”. Most, and perhaps all, Canadian provinces and territories accepted NACI’s recommendation and updated their vaccination plans to include the four-month interval. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308154413/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/rapid-response-extended-dose-intervals-covid-19-vaccines-early-rollout-population-protection.html

A,B,C: On 5 March 2021, “Health Canada authorized the COVID-19 vaccine manufactured by Janssen Inc. [owned by Johnson & Johnson]…. for use in people over 18 years of age”. “Health Canada has now approved four distinct COVID-19 vaccines, with the others being from Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna and Oxford-AstraZeneca.” The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are being administered to Canadians. Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines may not have been administered yet. The first shipment to Canada arrived 3rd March. See CBC news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210305211028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/naci-interval-advice-change-four-months-1.5934563  https://web.archive.org/web/20210305203353/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2021/03/health-canada-authorizes-janssen-covid-19-vaccine.html

As of 8 March 2021 1:30PM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1864745 Canadians [4.9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna or Pfizer. 567,954 Canadians [almost 1.5%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). In some provinces/territories, vaccinations have started for elderly persons living in the community outside of care homes. According to Canada’s Minister of Indigenous Services, “more than 127,000 COVID-19 vaccine doses have been administered in more than 480 First Nations, Inuit and Territorial communities... approximately 40% of the indigenous population in First Nations, Inuit and Territorial communities having received at least one dose.”  See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308184423/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308160146/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/03/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities.html

As of 12 March 2021 12:50PM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 2,205,244 Canadians [5.8% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 589,048 Canadians [1.55%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 60+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) vaccine has been approved recently, but no reports yet of J&J shots being administered. See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312175918/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210312180206/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/03/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities0.html

As of 22 March 2021 5:50PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 3,409,857 Canadians [9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 632,489 Canadians [1.6%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education and emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, medical conditions), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 60+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved recently, but no reports yet of shots being administered. See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322224218/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

On 24 March 2021, Health Canada updated the product monograph—or label—for the AstraZeneca and COVISHIELD COVID-19 vaccines to provide information on very rare reports of blood clots associated with low levels of blood platelets (i.e., thrombocytopenia) following immunization with the AstraZeneca vaccine...The Department has also issued guidance for healthcare professionals and vaccine recipients on the potential symptoms to monitor. Health Canada reassures Canadians that the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine continues to be safe and effective at protecting them against COVID-19 and encourages people to get immunized with any of the COVID-19 vaccines that are authorized in Canada.”  See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326174902/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2021/03/health-canada-issues-label-change-and-guidance-on-the-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine.html

As of 26 March 2021 1:05PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 4,083,225 Canadians [11% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. 651,750 Canadians [1.7%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, medical conditions), C. elderly groups (starting with residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes and now some seniors aged 60+ living at home receiving shots). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved recently, but no reports yet of shots being administered. See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210326175238/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/covid-19-vaccine-treatment/vaccine-rollout.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322224218/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

On 29 March 2021, Canada’s “National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) is recommending an immediate pause in the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine in all individuals less than 55 years of age in Canada. This is based on evidence of rare instances of vaccine-induced pro-thrombotic immune thrombocytopenia (VIPIT) following AstraZeneca vaccination reported in Europe”. All provinces and territories accepted this advice. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405135723/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/03/use-of-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine.html

***Recoded from 3G to 4G. While five provinces have broad availability (4), there is not yet broad availability nationally. Therefore, this doesn't yet meet the threshold for 4G since for this indicator, the lowest common level is coded, rather than the most stringent/highest exceptions.     See previous coding notes:     On 21 april 2021, “Quebec has dropped the age limit for the AstraZeneca vaccine to give access to people 45 and up [and] [t]he change took effect”. Earlier in the week, British Columbia, Alberta, Manitoba and Ontario lowered the age limit to 40. The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines continue to be administered. Johnson & Johnson Janssen vaccine approved, but not yet available. With the 5 most populous of the 13 provinces and territories now vaccinating those aged 45+, code changed to 4 = Availability for all three (key workers/ clinically vulnerable groups / elderly groups) plus partial additional availability.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210422061156/https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/the-astrazeneca-vaccine-is-now-available-to-quebecers-age-45-and-up-1.5394863  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422153049/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-four-provinces-lower-age-limits-for-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine/    As of 23 april 2021 1:42EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 10,435,836 Canadians [27.5% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca. Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments will not arrive until later. 980,044 Canadians [2.6%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations were initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women in Ontario), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, now all seniors wherever they live). AstraZeneca now being administered to ages 40+ in British Columbia, Alberta, Manitoba, Ontario and 45+ in Quebec. See CTV news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210423174535/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccination-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

In the 5 May 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, “Prime Minister Justin Trudeau reiterated that Canadians should get the first COVID-19 vaccine they can, contradicting the recommendation from … the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) … that waiting for an mRNA vaccine, like those from Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna, is preferable to receiving a viral vector vaccine, from Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca, when personal risk of contracting COVID-19 is lower.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506122103/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-trudeau-urges-canadians-to-get-first-covid-19-shot-theyre-offered/

Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed pending a quality control check. 1,211,646 Canadians [3%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, now all seniors wherever they live). Effective 25 May 2021, Yukon Territory exempted fully vaccinated persons from the 14-day self-isolation requirement for entrants to the territory. This marks the first official use in Canada of a “vaccine passport” favouring fully vaccinated persons. Also: “The University of Western Ontario will require students living in residence this fall to be vaccinated against COVID-19 … although vaccines are not required to attend classes or visit campus, students living in university residence will be required to have received at least one dose. University president Alan Shepard said Thursday that he was strongly urged to take this step by the local health authority in London, Ont. Students are asked to get their vaccination before arriving on campus in September, or, if one is not available, to get a shot within 14 days of their arrival in residence.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210529151211/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-news-today-bc-set-to-lay-out-restart-road-map-as-cases-slow/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210529150242/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-university-of-western-ontario-to-require-covid-19-vaccinations-for/

As of 14 june 2021,  2:06PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 24,513,774 Canadians [64% of the total national population and 73% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 12+] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca (no longer being offered as a first dose). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed due to a quality control problem at the manufacturing plant. 4,761,574 Canadians [12.5% of total pop.] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. (Note that vaccination data do not include Canadians who were vaccinated in other countries while wintering at retirement homes or on essential business trips.) Within Canada, vaccinations were initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, then all seniors wherever they live). With all provinces and territories now making vaccinations available to ages as young as 12, code now at 5 = universal. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614184449/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614185220/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-federal-government-not-tracking-vaccination-status-of-returning/

Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed due to a quality control problem at the manufacturing plant. 6,180,593 Canadians [16% of total pop.] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. (Note that vaccination data do not include Canadians who have returned home after being vaccinated in other countries while wintering at retirement homes or on essential business trips. On the other hand, there may be a small amount of double-counting when residents live and work in different provinces and vaccinations take place at work.) With all provinces and territories now making vaccinations available to ages as young as 12, code now at 5 = universal. B: Pfizer/BioNTech    First canton (Lucerne) launches vaccination campaign on December 23, starting with vulnerable residents over 65. In the first phase, individual cantons can begin the first vaccinations for people in vulnerable groups on a step-by-step basis. Vaccinations will take place in specific settings such as old people’s and care homes. Starting 4 January 2021, the vaccination of people in vulnerable groups and other priority groups will then start all over Switzerland.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102134745/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210102134839/https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/first-covid-19-vaccine-approved-for-swiss-use/46234782

B,C: Pfizer/BioNTech      Vaccination was started in most cantons on 4 January 2021. Especially vulnerable people are being vaccinated first.   The following people are to be given access to vaccinations first:  * People age 75 and over  * People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age    https://web.archive.org/web/20210109120317/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

Second vaccine - Moderna - approved for use on January 12.     B;C     Targeted groups amended to explicitly identify care home/retirement home residents and staff : "The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:    People age 75 and over  People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time."     However, still coded as two groups rather than three as "key workers" are not categorically being vaccinated; rather, only some care/retirement home staff has the option of vaccination.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210124122931/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

Recoded from 1G to 2G as official government policy allows for both B & C to access vaccine nationally, despite lags or variation in localized vaccine rollout. Not coded as 3G as "key workers" are not able to categorically access the vaccine; rather only a limited portion of care/retirement home workers have the option of vaccination.     B;C , Moderna & Pfizer    Original coding note:     Note that the federal policy is to give access first to A, B and C:    The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:  ?	People age 75 and over  ?	People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  ?	People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124122931/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html    However, the status is that only elderly people are indeed getting shots in arms in all cantons. In some cantons B and C are vaccinated. In Zurich, A and C. In others, only C (detailed sources below). Based on the coding guidance that Geographic coverage needs to be national before this is coded, as we code the lowest common value if there is geographic variation, changing to 1G.  Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNTec, Moderna. Undergoing approval process: AstraZeneca    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110150607/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html    Clinically vulnerable people under 75 now also being vaccinated as well, e.g. in Zug:  https://archive.vn/v7s4P  and Baselland:  https://archive.vn/KPry4    But the roll out varies across cantons, e.g. in Basel-city only the elderly over 75 are being invited to get vaccinated.  https://archive.vn/WVWiv  https://archive.vn/hJDAb    Similarly, in Bern, where only people over 75 years old are being vaccinated for now.  https://archive.vn/rRwCL#selection-1591.0-1595.92    In Zurich, residents and staff in elderly care home have started to receive vaccines.   https://archive.vn/cZiRN  In Tessin, elderly care home residents and staff, as well as the over 85-year-olds can book vaccinations.  https://archive.vn/T29oA    Note there are reports of a slow roll out of the vaccine program.  https://archive.vn/ukR7N

No policy changes.    B;C , Moderna & Pfizer    The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:    People age 75 and over  People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time.  If you are in the group of people with chronic diseases of the highest risk, the doctor treating you will urgently recommend you to have the vaccination as soon as possible.    After that come:    People aged between 65 and 74  People under 65 and people with chronic diseases who have not yet been vaccinated  Following people at especially high risk (vulnerable people), the vaccination will also be offered to the following target groups in the corresponding order.    Target group 2: Healthcare professionals with patient contact/carers for people at especially high risk  Target group 3: Close contacts (household members or relatives providing care) of people at especially high risk  Target group 4: People in communal facilities with an increased risk of infection and outbreaks (for example homes for the handicapped).  It has become apparent that these priorities are being put into practice differently from canton to canton. In particular there are differences in the vaccination of healthcare professionals. For this reason the Federal Vaccination Commission (EKIF/CFV) and the FOPH have drawn up guidelines specifying which groups of healthcare professionals may possibly be vaccinated at the same time as especially vulnerable people (target group 1). Given that volumes of vaccine are currently limited, the goal is to assure the provision of healthcare in areas that are particularly affected while making sufficient vaccine available for especially vulnerable people at the highest risk.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210205081724/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

AC:    Starting December 24, the Chilean government has started vaccinating "medical personnel from the regions of La Araucanía, Biobío and Magallanes, some of the most affected by the pandemic. As of January 11, 2020, there have been 10, 699 first doses administered.    The Sinovac vaccine is being distributed to adults between 87 and 89 years of age, starting February 4th and to adults between 85 and 86 on Friday, February 5th.     "«As of Monday, March 1, we will incorporate people who are with cancer, over 16 years of age, and who are undergoing treatment with radiotherapy, immunotherapy or chemotherapy , we will also incorporate those people who have an autoimmune disease and are are in treatment with biological therapy and / or small molecules, ”reported the Undersecretary of Public Health, Paula Daza, during the balance of the COVID-19 pandemic in the country."    https://www.dw.com/es/chile-iniciar%C3%A1-la-vacunaci%C3%B3n-contra-la-covid-19-este-jueves-24-de-diciembre/a-56044566  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111201030/https://www.gob.cl/yomevacuno/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208233218/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/presidente-pinera-da-inicio-a-la-vacunacion-masiva-contra-el-covid-19-en-todo-chile-es-un-tremendo-desafio-y-una-verdadera-epopeya/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301180410/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/pacientes-de-cancer-y-de-enfermedades-autoinmunes-podran-vacunarse-contra-el-covid-19-partir-de-este-lunes-1-de-marzo/

ABC:    Starting December 24, the Chilean government has started vaccinating "medical personnel from the regions of La Araucanía, Biobío and Magallanes, some of the most affected by the pandemic. As of January 11, 2020, there have been 10, 699 first doses administered.    The Sinovac vaccine is being distributed to adults between 87 and 89 years of age, starting February 4th and to adults between 85 and 86 on Friday, February 5th.     "«As of Monday, March 1, we will incorporate people who are with cancer, over 16 years of age, and who are undergoing treatment with radiotherapy, immunotherapy or chemotherapy , we will also incorporate those people who have an autoimmune disease and are are in treatment with biological therapy and / or small molecules, ”reported the Undersecretary of Public Health, Paula Daza, during the balance of the COVID-19 pandemic in the country."    "As of this Monday March 8, more than 89 thousand people with severe or profound disabilities will receive the first dose against Covid-19"    " In the vaccination calendar established by the Ministry of Health, it was specified that from March 15 people in the transport sector can be vaccinated, with which it is expected to inoculate more than 74 thousand drivers of basic taxis, executives, tourism , collectives, school transport and bus drivers. "    https://www.dw.com/es/chile-iniciar%C3%A1-la-vacunaci%C3%B3n-contra-la-covid-19-este-jueves-24-de-diciembre/a-56044566  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111201030/https://www.gob.cl/yomevacuno/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208233218/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/presidente-pinera-da-inicio-a-la-vacunacion-masiva-contra-el-covid-19-en-todo-chile-es-un-tremendo-desafio-y-una-verdadera-epopeya/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301180410/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/pacientes-de-cancer-y-de-enfermedades-autoinmunes-podran-vacunarse-contra-el-covid-19-partir-de-este-lunes-1-de-marzo/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322162249/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/partir-de-este-lunes-mas-de-89-mil-personas-con-discapacidad-severa-o-profunda-recibiran-primera-dosis-contra-el-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322162512/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/chile-recibe-209-mil-dosis-adicionales-de-la-vacuna-pfizer-biontech-y-laboratorio-cansino-solicita-autorizacion-ante-el-isp/

ABC:    Starting December 24, the Chilean government has started vaccinating "medical personnel from the regions of La Araucanía, Biobío and Magallanes, some of the most affected by the pandemic. As of January 11, 2020, there have been 10, 699 first doses administered.    The Sinovac vaccine is being distributed to adults between 87 and 89 years of age, starting February 4th and to adults between 85 and 86 on Friday, February 5th.     "«As of Monday, March 1, we will incorporate people who are with cancer, over 16 years of age, and who are undergoing treatment with radiotherapy, immunotherapy or chemotherapy , we will also incorporate those people who have an autoimmune disease and are are in treatment with biological therapy and / or small molecules, ”reported the Undersecretary of Public Health, Paula Daza, during the balance of the COVID-19 pandemic in the country."    "As of this Monday March 8, more than 89 thousand people with severe or profound disabilities will receive the first dose against Covid-19"    " In the vaccination calendar established by the Ministry of Health, it was specified that from March 15 people in the transport sector can be vaccinated, with which it is expected to inoculate more than 74 thousand drivers of basic taxis, executives, tourism , collectives, school transport and bus drivers. "    "« Today (March 24) a milestone is marked starting with the healthy population, under 60 years of age. We have finished (vaccinating) people who have chronic diseases, the elderly and that is important. We are starting with the 59-year-old group of the population, tomorrow those who are 58 and the next day those who are 57 years old and so we will continue until they are 50 years old. We want to ensure that this entire age range between 50 and 59 years is vaccinated before April 9, "said the Undersecretary of Public Health, Paula Daza."    https://www.dw.com/es/chile-iniciar%C3%A1-la-vacunaci%C3%B3n-contra-la-covid-19-este-jueves-24-de-diciembre/a-56044566  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111201030/https://www.gob.cl/yomevacuno/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208233218/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/presidente-pinera-da-inicio-a-la-vacunacion-masiva-contra-el-covid-19-en-todo-chile-es-un-tremendo-desafio-y-una-verdadera-epopeya/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329174435/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/minsal-inicia-proceso-de-vacunacion-de-poblacion-sana/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301180410/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/pacientes-de-cancer-y-de-enfermedades-autoinmunes-podran-vacunarse-contra-el-covid-19-partir-de-este-lunes-1-de-marzo/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322162249/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/partir-de-este-lunes-mas-de-89-mil-personas-con-discapacidad-severa-o-profunda-recibiran-primera-dosis-contra-el-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322162512/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/chile-recibe-209-mil-dosis-adicionales-de-la-vacuna-pfizer-biontech-y-laboratorio-cansino-solicita-autorizacion-ante-el-isp/
