To date, Chile has received shipments of both the Sinovac and Pfizer vaccines. Vaccines are available for foreign nationals who are also either residents or citizens of Chile. Vaccination includes resident foreign nationals but not tourists. Vaccination in Chile is voluntary and free of charge. Resident foreign nationals must present proof of their resident status.    https://archive.vn/ggltZ   https://archive.vn/QOGgB

12 December    Provincial governments across China are placing orders for experimental, domestically made coronavirus vaccines, though health officials have yet to say how well they work or how they may reach the country’s 1.4 billion people.    Developers are speeding up final testing, the Chinese foreign minister said during a U.N. meeting last week    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184213/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/06/china-prepares-large-scale-rollout-of-coronavirus-vaccines-443159

This extended note aims to capture the progress on vaccination programme before it is rolled out to the entire country (does not include R&D, clinic trials).    The China National Medicine Products Administration (MPA) has not formally approved the Sinopharm Inactivated vaccine to go to the market. However, the green light is anticipated in the next few days.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214212000/https://weareunited.com.my/11515744/    On 24 June 2020, the MPA approved the emergency use of COVID-19 vaccine. Voluntary vaccination started on around 17 June. The first batch of receivers consisted mainly of key workers, including state-owned enterprise employees who must go overseas to countries where the pandemic hits hard; medical staff, epidemic-control staff, border force and other essential workers who keep cities running.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231804/https://finance.sina.com.cn/chanjing/cyxw/2020-11-18/doc-iiznezxs2537217.shtml    From mid-October, Zhejiang province has offered vaccines to ordinary citizens on a voluntary basis. The rationale has been that many cities in Zhejiang have export-oriented economies; for example, Yiwu city is the world centre for light industry commodity trading. Many wholesale merchants were keen on receiving vaccines so that they can travel to Latin America and Africa to inspect their businesses. See BBC reports below. By mid-November, Zhejiang had provided vaccines to some 743,000 people. Voluntary vaccines were paid by recipients. Two doses cost roughly 400 CNY plus a service charge of around 56 CNY, which altogether equals to approximately 70 USD.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231741/https://www.bbc.com/zhongwen/simp/chinese-news-54628714    As the vaccination programme is yet to roll out to the whole country, there is no national policy on who will get the vaccine first. However, Sichuan province, where the most recent cluster of infection was found, did publish a detailed plan to that sets out the order:    The first group to receive vaccines consists of people facing high risks of infection, including medical staffs with International assistance mission, national health emergency rescue team in Sichuan, fever clinic and frontline doctors and nurses, border control force, frontline health inspection and epidemic-control officials, students or workers going overseas, police force, frozen food industry workers, essential workers for keeping cities running, teachers, other medical staffs, doctors and nurses, community social workers. The first batch is estimated to have 2 million people. Vaccination for them has started and will finish within 2020.    The second group to receive vaccines mainly consists of vulnerable people, including elderly people and people with chronic diseases. Vaccination for them will start from early next year (January).    The third batch will open to the general public. Ordinary people are estimated to start receiving vaccines after the Chinese New Year (12 February 2021).    http://web.archive.org/web/20201214221555/https://www.sohu.com/a/437018675_114988    So far, vaccination is not and is unlike to be paid by social medical insurance funds in the future. The National Health Security Administration has cited laws and regulations as the justification that vaccination is a part of public health effort, which should be shouldered by public finance resources, rather than social medical insurance funds.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214211226/https://www.sohu.com/a/425495553_114986    UAE and Bahrain have formally approved the Sinopharm vaccine on 9th and 13th December 2020 respectively.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231619/http://www.xinhuanet.com/2020-12/09/c_1126842251.htm  http://web.archive.org/web/20201214231549/http://www.xinhuanet.com/world/2020-12/14/c_1126855787.htm

A:    China formally started to vaccinate group A - Key workers - and people who need to go to high-risk countries/regions to work and/or study on 15 Dec 2020. Key workers are those who work in frozen stuff-importing industry, border check, market for fresh meet and fish, public transportation, and hospital. Groups B and/or C will be the next to be vaccinated.    https://archive.vn/oG1an

Key workers include those who work in frozen stuff-importing industry, border check, market for fresh meat and fish, public transportation, aircraft, and health care.    https://archive.vn/MVapy  http://web.archive.org/web/20210215074124/http://www.scio.gov.cn/xwfbh/gssxwfbh/xwfbh/jilin/Document/1698273/1698273.htm

A+C    From early-March (or perhaps late-February), Beijing and some cities started to vaccine people above 60 who were in considerably good conditions and somewhat vulnerable to the virus.    https://archive.vn/o4LFz
While kept focusing on key workers and people above 60, the PRC started to roll out vaccines to the general public aged 18 and above from late March.    https://archive.vn/CV5SW

By 23 May 2021, around 511 million vaccines (7 different types) have been rolled out in Mainland China. The vaccination rates among people aged 18 and above in some cities and provinces, such as Beijing and Hainan, have well passed 80%.    https://archive.vn/lIrRt

No change in policy: vaccines are broadly available. Daily vaccination hit record high in Guangzhou and Shenzhen after new infections were found in late-May: by 6pm 26 May, 1.6 million vaccines were rolled out in Guangdong province.    https://archive.vn/hxbEk

No change in policy: vaccines are broadly available. Daily vaccination hit record high in Guangzhou and Shenzhen after new infections were found in late-May: by 6pm 26 May, 1.6 million vaccines were rolled out in Guangdong province.    https://archive.vn/hxbEk

Vaccines are broadly available in most provinces. By mid-June, while some provinces, such as Heibei and Zhejiang, are still aiming to provide the first dose to as many members of the public as possible, some other provinces, such as Guangxi, Hubei, and Shandong, are starting or have started to focus on providing the second does to the public.    https://archive.vn/3tq5n  https://archive.vn/dT3cj  https://archive.vn/CuIAY  https://archive.vn/CNrFk  https://archive.vn/DP6F1
No change in policy.    https://archive.vn/8hkbE

'As of Saturday [19 June], 1,010,489,000 doses had been given to people in China, according to the country’s National Health Commission (NHC). More than 100 million doses had been administered in the six days up to and including Saturday. It’s unclear how many people have been full inoculated as the government does not release those numbers. But Zhong Nanshan, one of China’s top health experts attached to the NHC, said in March that the country is aiming to have 40% of the population fully vaccinated by the end of June.'  https://archive.vn/p83a4    The NHC expects to  have at least 70% of the population vaccinate by the end of the year.  https://archive.vn/mGzBx

The percentage of people aged 15 to 59 who have received at least one jab of different cities in mainland China vary from less than 30% (e.g. Lanzhou) to more than 80% (e.g. Haikou). The press also suggested vaccines in China are available to everyone 18+.  https://archive.vn/Psx6J  https://archive.vn/61x1N  https://archive.vn/pGJTK

The PRC government launched mass vaccination programmes to people aged between 12 to 17 in July. As many as possible people aged between 15 to 17 are expected to receive the first dose in July and the second in August. For those between 12 to 14, they are expected to receive the first and second in August and September/October, respectively.    https://archive.vn/AnPgi#

The central government of China blamed the recent phenomenon seen in many mainland cities that un-vaccinated people are forbidden from entering public places such as supermarkets and hospital and using public transport. The central government re-clarified that vaccination is voluntary, not compulsory.  https://archive.vn/WZdUl    No other changes.  https://archive.vn/PaUE3

The vaccines have arrived in Congo, although no one has been vaccinated yet. The vaccination process was scheduled to begin today.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419193905/https://finance.yahoo.com/news/congo-begins-covid-19-vaccinations-162945545.html

Vaccination started on 19 April, initially with 300,000 doses of Sinopharm's BBIBP-CorV vaccine donated by China and 12,000 doses of Sputnik V. By the end of the month (30th April 2021) 41379 persons had received their first inoculation and 11700 had been fully vaccinated. Vaccination started in Pointe-Noire on Monday, April 19, 2021. To date, five (5) vaccination centers are in operation there. In Brazzaville, four (4) new vaccination centers (Madibou, Mfilou, Moukondo and WHO Africa) have been added to the eleven (11) existing centers. Vaccination operations have extended to Owando and Makoua, whose centers opened on April 26 and April 30, 2021, respectively. It is not clear which groups are being targeted for vaccines, if any.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517190932/https://www.adiac-congo.com/content/communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-15

A, C:    The first stage of vaccination will be for the priority population, i.e. frontline health personnel and 100% of the population over the age of 80. This comprises about 11 million people (7.6 million over the age of 60 and 1.2 million in health personnel) and would begin in January 2021.    In phase two it will focus on vaccination of 100% of the population from 60 to 79 years old and health personnel of the second and third hotlines. This comprises about 7.19 million. While in phase three, 2.95 million people will be vaccinated; phase four, 4.91 million; and in phase five, about 17.4 million.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221215935/https://www.larepublica.co/especiales/mis-documentos-2020/conozca-como-sera-el-plan-de-vacunacion-contra-el-covid-19-en-colombia-desde-enero-3104233

A, B, C:  The government has organised its vaccination strategy in 2 phases, the first one has 3 stages and the second one has 2 stages. They are currently in the third stage of the first phase. The stages are as follows:  Stage 1: population over 80 and health workers directly attending COVID patients.  Stage 2: general population between 60 and 79 years old and the rest of health workers.  Stage 3: general population between 50 and 59 years old, population between 16 and 59 years old that present at least one risk factor, teachers, carers and different national security and police personnel.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210514030411/https://www.minsalud.gov.co/salud/publica/Vacunacion/Paginas/Vacunacion-covid-19.aspx

Not yet being put in arms, but the first wave of COVAX Astrazenica vaccines have been delivered, 24,000. Inoculation thought to begin March 19th.      "Cape Verde on Friday received the first batch of 24,000 COVAX COVID-19 AstraZeneca vaccines and is set to commence its inoculation programme on March 19th, hoping to reach 70% of its population later this year...The prime minister said that soon another 80,000 doses of the vaccine from the same pharmaceutical company will arrive, and on March 15, 5,850 doses of Pfizer will arrive, also under the same international mechanism.    Asked about the fact that several European countries have suspended the administration of the AstraZeneca vaccine, the Cape Verdean leader said that there is no scientific evidence of a relationship between cases of strong blood clotting and its application."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210312105522/https://africa.cgtn.com/2021/03/12/cape-verde-receives-24000-astrazeneca-vaccines/

For this first phase of vaccination, some groups of people were prioritized taking into account the risk of developing serious disease that can cause even death and professional groups that are on the front line of combating the pandemic. Thus, the priority groups to be vaccinated in this first phase are health professionals; chronic patients (hypertensive and diabetic); population over 60 years of age; hotel professionals and related to tourism; professionals from ports and airports; teachers and support staff in schools; police; armed forces; and civil protection professionals and firefighters.    So far the country has received two types of vaccines, bewith achstraZeneca and the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. Meanwhile, the country may receive other vaccines, with the support of the World Bank.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405155801/https://covid19.cv/vacinas/

The current vaccine groups are as follows for Costa Rica, and the first vaccine shots have started becoming administered. Tico Times reports that the vaccine is free but not mandatory for citizens.   """    Staff and residents at retirement or nursing homes.  First responders, including health personnel.  Costa Rica’s older population, defined here as those ages 58 and up.  People with risk factors, including hypertension, diabetes, heart disease, respiratory illness, kidney disease and obesity, among others.  Teachers and other staff within the Education Ministry (MEP).  Imprisoned people and judicial staff.  Workers for the 911 service.  Health science students and related technicians in clinical fields.  People ages 40-57 without any of the aforementioned risk factors but whose work puts them in contact with others. This includes laborers in agriculture, construction, service industries, etc.  """    https://web.archive.org/web/20201231091456/https://ticotimes.net/2020/12/29/costa-rica-reports-no-adverse-effects-after-first-vaccine-shot

D: People with risk factors, including hypertension, diabetes, heart disease, respiratory illness, kidney disease and obesity, among others.  A: Teachers and other staff within the Education Ministry (MEP).  C: Imprisoned people  A: judicial staff.  A: Workers for the 911 service.  A: Health science students and related technicians in clinical fields.  B: People ages 40-57 without any of the aforementioned risk factors but whose work puts them in contact with others. Abdala, anti-Covid-19 vaccine candidate from Cuba, will conclude this week the administration of the third dose to all volunteers as part of phase III of clinical trials  We aspire to May Day to celebrate International Workers' Day in health areas by applying these last doses to all volunteers included,' said Verena Mucio, director of Clinical Research at the Center for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology (CIGB), leader of this project.    The specialist recalled that on April 19 the last two weeks of the application of the third dose to all the volunteers began, of which 21,909 had already been vaccinated as part of the process.    He explained that the phase III clinical research stage with this anti-Covid-19 candidate began on March 22 in the provinces of Santiago de Cuba, Guantánamo and Granma, with the application of the first dose to 48,290 subjects for six weeks; while the administration of the second ended on April 17, with 47,620 volunteers, and satisfactory results.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419021730/https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-56538933

Two of Cuba’s five vaccine candidates are in Phase 3 trials: Soberana 2, which translates to 'sovereignty,' and Abdala, named after a book by the Cuban independence hero José Martí.  Around 44,000 people are getting the Soberana 2 vaccine as part of the Phase 3 double-blind study. An additional 150,000 health care workers are being inoculated with Soberana 2 as part of an “interventional study.”  The final results of the Phase 3 trials are not expected for months. The government’s plan is to have nearly all the inhabitants of the capital, Havana, vaccinated by May through the interventional study, and the entire country’s population inoculated before the year ends.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510211802/https://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/cuba-says-betting-safe-covid-vaccine-rcna643

Cuba has begun to mass vaccinate its citizens -- the first time the country's general population is receiving its ambitious homegrown vaccines. Even though Cuba is getting a late start, Cuban health care officials predict the majority of the island will be vaccinated by the end of the summer. On the 14th of October, 2020, there was a statement by MSP stating that it has already started actions to prepare the country for the application of the vaccine against COVID-19, of which the Government has committed a sufficient amount as soon as it is available .    The Vice Minister of Collective Health, Dr. Ivelisse Acosta explained that an international consultancy has been hired to design the logistics for the application of the vaccine and determine the equipment and training needs of the health service personnel who will work in this program.    He said that these tasks began last Friday and that first of all all people who work in the health service, the elderly and people with comorbidity (diabetes, high blood pressure and others) will be vaccinated.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221231059/https://coronavirusrd.gob.do/2020/10/14/msp-inicio-acciones-para-preparar-el-pais-para-aplicacion-de-la-vacuna-contra-el-covid-19/

A, B:    Denmark begins vaccinating against COVID from 27 December.    Vulnerable people and front-line health sector workers will be the first to receive it    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106171203/https://covid19.ssi.dk/overvagningsdata/vaccinationstilslutning    https://web.archive.org/web/20201217144136/https://www.thelocal.dk/20201217/coronavirus-denmark-hopes-to-begin-vaccine-programme-on-december-27th

According to the official calendar, up to the current date the Danish Health Authority has determined that the target groups for the vaccination programme should be given priority in the following order:  - Residents in nursing homes, etc. & People aged = 65 years who receive both personal care and practical assistance.  - Personnel in healthcare, elderly care and selected parts of the social sector who are at particular risk of infection or who has been identified as performing a critical function in society.  - Selected persons with conditions and diseases that result in a significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19.  - Selected relatives of persons at significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19 or relatives who are indispensable as carers.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130122057/https://www.sst.dk/-/media/Udgivelser/2021/Corona/Vaccination/Kalender/Vaccinationskalender-A4-webtilgaengelig.ashx?la=da&hash=5234BB82243B24FD492FDDAC1388CA9A22BC83D6  https://web.archive.org/web/20210130123050/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Vaccination-against-COVID-19/Target-groups  https://web.archive.org/web/20210130123058/https://www.sst.dk/-/media/Udgivelser/2021/Corona/Vaccination/Kalender/Specificeret-vaccinationskalender.ashx?la=da&hash=C2818CB774B7C56FCC64981CD7D6B3752EA026AF      The first approved vaccine against COVID-19 is called Comirnaty® and was developed by the German company BioNTech in collaboration with the American company Pfizer. The deliveries of Comirnaty® that we receive to Denmark are produced in factories in Germany and Belgium.   The second vaccine, which is approved for use in the EU and thus Denmark, has been developed by the American company Moderna. COVID-19 vaccine Moderna® is developed on the same technology as Comirnaty®, and is produced in factories in Switzerland and Spain.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130132848/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/emner/vaccination

A: Key workers/ Health professionals  Egypt has begun vaccinating people against the novel coronavirus, the country’s Health Ministry said Sunday.    The country received its first batch of China’s Sinopharm vaccine and the first doses were given to health professionals at a quarantine hospital in northeastern Ismailia province, the ministry said in a statement.    Vaccinations will first be administered to healthcare professionals at quarantine hospitals and other hospitals where the virus is seen and then to the elderly, chronic patients and others, it said.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125230109/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/egypt-starts-covid-19-vaccination/2121613    Has the government of Egypt approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes.  Sinopharm’s vaccine has been approved on an emergency use basis.  Approval for the AstraZeneca vaccine is expected by the end of January.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210129191754/https://eg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

By early March, 2021, the Egyptian government had made vaccines available only to some health workers, as well as limited numbers of older people and people with chronic illnesses and had not provided a clear plan for its rollout. In January, the government created a website that on March 1 began accepting registrations for the vaccine but only from medical professionals, the elderly, and people with immunity-compromising health conditions. On March 4, the health ministry offered the vaccine for the first time to registered people who are not medical professionals    https://web.archive.org/web/20210321165150/https://reliefweb.int/report/egypt/egypt-provide-equitable-covid-19-vaccine-access-enar

The Estonian vaccination drive began on 27th of December. Healthcare workers (group A) are the first to be vaccinated, using the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101212336/https://news.err.ee/1220851/over-200-health-care-workers-receive-covid-19-vaccination-on-first-day

In the first two weeks of vaccination, 10,197 people have received the first dose of coronavirus vaccine at 100 healthcare facilities in Estonia.    The first dose has been given to most of the staff of family medicine centers, approximately 30 percent of the staff of the hospitals in the hospital network, as well as the staff and residents of the first care homes, the Ministry of Social Affairs said.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123120628/https://www.baltictimes.com/more_than_10_000_people_in_estonia_have_received_1st_dose_of_coronavirus_vaccine/    A,B

Vaccination in Estonia takes place according to the vaccination plan. In 2021, vaccination is free for everybody who lives in Estonia, including those who do not have health insurance. Vaccination is voluntary. Estonia has currently joined the advance purchase agreements with 5 vaccine manufacturers -- AstraZeneca, Janssen Pharmaceutica NV, Pfizer/BioNTech, Curevac and Moderna. Estonia has the possibility of joining the Sanofi advance purchase agreements later.    https://archive.vn/ethW2   https://archive.vn/I1clv

H7: THE GOVERNMENT of Prime Minister Sanna Marin (SDP) on Wednesday came to an agreement on its strategy for deploying vaccines against the new coronavirus.  “To protect the entire population, the vaccine will be offered [for free] to everyone who wants it and who doesn’t have health-related contraindications to being vaccinated,” Minister of Family Affairs and Social Services Krista Kiuru (SDP) was quoted as saying late yesterday evening by YLE.  The government presently expects to be able to commence the vaccinations of social and health care professionals who treat coronavirus patients or work in nursing homes in January, provided that at least one of the vaccines is granted market authorisation by the European Commission in December. The vaccinations of social and health care professionals could be wrapped up by February or March.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201208050644/https://www.helsinkitimes.fi/finland/finland-news/domestic/18381-finland-to-offer-covid-19-vaccine-to-everyone-starting-with-health-care-staff.html

According to the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health: "No vaccine candidate has yet been granted a marketing authorisation. Finland’s priority is to immunise the whole population once a safe and effective vaccine is approved for use in the EU."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221191413/https://stm.fi/en/coronavirus-vaccines

A:    Finland's vaccination campaign started on 27 December, with front-line ICU healthcare workers in Helsinki being the first recipients of the vaccine.         https://web.archive.org/web/20210104183537/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/1271139/healthcare-and-social-welfare-workers-first-in-line-to-get-authorised-covid-19-vaccines-on-voluntary-basis

A,B,C as per: https://web.archive.org/web/20210115143227/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19 Vaccines on order: BioNTech – Pfizer (Comirnaty-vaccin) Moderna AstraZeneca Curevac Jansen Group Sanofi-GSK Novavax http://web.archive.org/web/20210115143749/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/vaccines-and-coronavirus/arranging-covid-19-vaccinations-in-finland  Note, that all are planned to be vaccinated, but it is currently only rolled out for two groups: According to a Government Decree (22 December 2020), the vaccinations are first offered to social and health care professionals who treat COVID-19 patients and to people who work and live in nursing homes or housing services for the elderly. Most of these vaccinations will be carried out in January–February 2021.   The vaccine will then be offered to elderly persons and to those with diseases that predispose them to severe coronavirus disease. After that, the vaccine will be offered to the rest of the population. It is still unclear when the vaccine can be offered to everyone willing to be vaccinated because the schedule mainly depends on the marketing authorisations and the availability of the vaccines.

A,B,C  Astrazeneca is the vaccine    As recently announced the Ministry of Health and Medical Services is rolling out the next phase of vaccinations with approximately 50,000 people eligible to receive this 2-dose vaccine from Tuesday April 6th. This group includes the rest of the frontline staff at the borders, all healthcare workers (including those in private healthcare), police and military officers, tourism and hotel workers, and civil servants. Also eligible to receive the vaccine will be those over the age of 60, and people with medical conditions that increase the risk of severe disease if they do get infected with COVID-19. You will fall into this category if you are currently attending a Special Outpatients Department (SOPD) clinic with the Ministry of Health and Medical Services, or similar with a private healthcare provider. This includes people with diabetes, asthma, and heart conditions.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210410174838/http://www.health.gov.fj/covid-19-vaccination-update/

Fiji’s priority groups who will receive the COVID-19 vaccines first are:  -Front-line workers (e.g airport workers, health front-liners, sea-ports, quarantine facility staff, hoteliers working in quarantine facilities, defense forces and some other essential workers);  -The rest of the health workers across Fiji, including private practitioners, members of the disciplined forces, persons with existing medical conditions, and family members of front line workers;   -Elderly/Older People 60 years and above  All individuals must be 18 years and above.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210524035409/http://www.health.gov.fj/covid-vaccine/vaccine-faqs/

Fiji’s priority groups who will receive the COVID-19 vaccines first are:    Front-line workers (e.g airport workers, health front-liners, sea-ports, quarantine facility staff, hoteliers working in quarantine facilities, defense forces and some other essential workers) ;  The rest of the health workers across Fiji, including private practitioners, members of the disciplined forces, persons with existing medical conditions, and family members of front line workers;  Elderly/Older People 60 years and above; and  All individuals 18 years and above6. Why are these groups prioritized?Healthcare workers:  Health workers continue to serve on the front line of Fiji’s fight against this deadly pandemic. The occupation type, and job settings of healthcare workers place them at a higher risk of contracting COVID-19. Health care workers are also at a high risk of being exposed to COVID-19 as they provide critical care to those who are or might be infected.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210531144905/http://www.health.gov.fj/covid-vaccine/vaccine-faqs/

No availability yet but plans in place to start vaccination in January. Vaccination will be rolled out in three phases:    Phase 1: January 2021 – elderly care home residents, and residence staff who are at risk of developing severe illness (about one million people)  Phase 2: February 2021 -  people who are at risk of developing severe illness, and health care workers – about 14 million people.  Phase 3: spring 2021 – availability for the entire population, although still prioritized e.g. by age.  Vaccination will be free and voluntary.    https://archive.vn/aLCoS
PARIS (Reuters) - France will start its COVID-19 vaccination programme next Sunday, Health Minister Olivier Veran wrote on his Twitter feed.  https://archive.vn/HrrMw

As of Dec. 31, only 352 people had gotten at least one dose of the vaccine, versus 131,626 in Germany and 944,539 in the U.K., according to data cited by Le Parisien.  https://archive.vn/0E17Q    From 2nd January, people over 50 will begin to be vaccinated (which had previously been planned for February), to speed up the vaccination roll out.  https://archive.vn/R00XW

A, C:    The HAS (Haute Autorite de Sante = High Authority of Health) recommends first vaccinating the elderly in establishments, in particular EHPADs, as well as the staff working there when they are at risk of developing a severe form of COVID. This represents around 1 million people.    On January 5, 2020, Olivier Véran indicated that firefighters and home helpers over 50 years old will be able to benefit from the injection as priority personnel. "They are also professionals who are in contact with fragile people and who may have to work with the sick," said the minister to justify this decision.  https://archive.vn/a0Ju1

A, C:    Previously coded policy is still in place in this period. By now, 318.216 have been vaccinated, out of which 10% are residents of care homes. The remainder are caregivers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities, but also firefighters, home helpers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities.  https://archive.vn/J7Rwn    So some members of the following groups have started receiving vaccines:  A Key workers  C Elderly groups  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    The vaccines that are given are PfizerBiontech and Moderna.  BioNTech-Pfizer's vaccine was approved by the EMA and then by the European Commission on 22 December. On Wednesday 6 January 2021, the European Commission gave the green light to the Covid-19 vaccine developed by the American start-up Moderna, this decision was approved by the High Health Authority on Friday 8 January 2021. To date, two additional vaccines are being evaluated by the EMA following Phase III clinical trials: the AstraZeneca and Janssen laboratories.  https://archive.vn/dNmaS    In addition, from 18 January, people over the age of 75 will be able to get vaccinated as well as people with one of the five pathologies leading to a very high risk of serious form of the disease, regardless of their age.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210113222447/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins    Note that the government has faced a lot of criticism regarding a perceived slowness and overly bureaucratic approach in rolling out the vaccines.  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    France wants to immunize 1 million people by the end of January but at the current vaccination rate, it will reach that target in late February.  There is also widespread vaccine-scepticism.  https://archive.vn/trhlh    Polls suggest that less than 40% of the population here is planning to take the vaccine.   https://archive.vn/J7Rwn
A, C:    As of Jan 24, 1,092,958 people received the first dose of Covid-19 vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126170527/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
A,C:    PfizerBiontech and Moderna vaccines are being administered, https://web.archive.org/web/20210128112737/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

A,C:     As of February 5th, over 2 million vaccinations have given in France https://web.archive.org/web/20210207203851/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/actualites/presse/communiques-de-presse/article/vaccin-anti-covid-premiere-livraison-de-doses-du-vaccin-astrazeneca-ce-samedi-6    PfizerBiontech and Moderna are being administered, with the AztraZeneca vaccine available as of February 6th. Following approval by EMA on January 29th 2020, the Haute autorité de santé (HAS) approved the AstraZeneca vaccine for use with two groups: "people under 65, starting with professionals in the health or medico-social sector, whatever their age; and in people aged 50 to 64, prioritizing those with co-morbidities" per https://web.archive.org/web/20210207203851/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/actualites/presse/communiques-de-presse/article/vaccin-anti-covid-premiere-livraison-de-doses-du-vaccin-astrazeneca-ce-samedi-6    France24 reported that first doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine were administered to health workers on Feb 6 2021 at "The Hospices Civils de Lyon, which received 7,700 doses on Friday evening [...] began to vaccinate their nursing staff and liberal doctors on Saturday afternoon at the Édouard-Herriot hospital, according to their press service." https://web.archive.org/web/20210208213549/https://www.france24.com/fr/france/20210206-covid-19-premi%C3%A8res-injections-du-vaccin-d-astrazeneca-en-france    This addition will expand availability to Group B (clinically vulnerable groups), adding this cohort to existing Key Worker and Elderly groups that are eligible for vaccination. Although the first doses of the AstraZeneva vaccine were delivered to France on February 6th, injection of people will begin "As soon as the quantities delivered allow it, it can be administered by town doctors, then, subsequently, in local pharmacies, for people meeting the criteria required by the HAS (people aged 50 to 64, starting with those with comorbidities). The exact date of initiation of vaccination for these people will be communicated very soon, depending on the doses available." so coding remains as 2G, but should move to 3G in the near future.

A, B, C:    AstraZeneca, Pfizer-Biontech and Moderna vaccinations are available per the “Data on COVID-19 vaccine deliveries” dataset issued by the Government at https://web.archive.org/web/20210418175238/https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/donnees-relatives-aux-livraisons-de-vaccins-contre-la-covid-19/    First availability of the Janssen vaccine in France is expected on 25 April, according to the above dataset, despite the Health Minister's assertion on 10 April that  "First delivery of the Johnson and Johnson vaccine is expected tomorrow [11 April] in France, a week ahead of schedule" (https://archive.vn/81gfC) it does not appear that this vaccine has been integrated into the supply chain yet.     From 12 April "From Monday, all over 55s can be vaccinated" https://archive.vn/81gfC, and in addition from 17 April, special vaccination slots would open for "priority professionals over the age of 55 (teachers, police, gendarmes, etc)". Per https://web.archive.org/web/20210418175137/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins groups now eligible to receive vaccines are:     - key workers  - 18-49 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19;  - 50-55 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19 or one or more comorbidities;  - people aged 55 and over regardless of where they live and health (with or without comorbidities);  - adults with disabilities, housed in specialized foster homes or nursing homes;  - pregnant women from the second trimester of pregnancy.

A, B, C:    AstraZeneca, Pfizer-Biontech and Moderna vaccinations are available per the “Data on COVID-19 vaccine deliveries” dataset issued by the Government at https://web.archive.org/web/20210423175502/https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/donnees-relatives-aux-livraisons-de-vaccins-contre-la-covid-19/    Per https://web.archive.org/web/20210423175559/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins the first doses of the Janssen vaccine are expected to be administed to people aged over 55 from 24 April. This web page lists the following groups of people who are elegible for vaccination (no major change from last update)     - key workers  - 18-49 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19;  - 50-55 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19 or one or more comorbidities;  - people aged 55 and over regardless of where they live and health (with or without comorbidities);  - adults with disabilities, housed in specialized foster homes or nursing homes;  - adults living in the same household as a severely immunocompromised person, child or adult (solid organ transplants, recent recent bone marrow transplants, dialysis patients, patients with autoimmune diseases under strong immunosuppressive therapy such as anti-CD20 or anti-metabolites)  - pregnant women from the second trimester of pregnancy.

As part of the imminent start of the vaccination campaign against COVID-19, the Minister of Health, Dr. Guy Patrick Obiang Ndong visited, this Tuesday March 16, 2021, the vaccination centers of the University Hospital Centers of Libreville, d 'Owendo and the Jeanne Ebori Foundation in the presence of the President of the Scientific Committee of the Copil coronavirus, Pr. Marielle Bouyou Akotet.    It was for the member of the government to inquire about the level of preparation of these structures as a prelude  to the said vaccination campaign and the patient circuit.    In terms of organization, the Owendo University Hospital has set up a spacious room including two vaccination posts, three observation chairs and a cold room.    At the University Hospital of Libreville, there are five vaccination posts spread over two pavilions, a main one with two vaccination rooms, two observation rooms, a waiting room, a cold room and a data entry office and a second pavilion, in development course, which will consist of three vaccination rooms, a waiting room, an observation room and an entry room.    Finally, at the Jeanne Ebori foundation mother-child hospital, a large room with five vaccination and observation posts has been set up and is ready to welcome patients.    At the end of this visit, the Minister of Health expressed his satisfaction with the arrangements made by the three CHUs for the smooth running of the vaccination campaign against COVID-19.    It should be noted that the teams in charge of this vaccination will each be made up of anesthetists, senior anesthesia-resuscitation technicians (TSAR), psychologists, nurses, Red Cross volunteers and vaccination agents. previously trained.  Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322071135/https://infocovid.ga/visite-des-centres-de-vaccination-dans/

On 21 January, the national action plan for vaccination was approved. The plan seeks to make sure that 60% of the population are vaccinated by the end of 2021. According to the plan, the highest-risk target groups will be vaccinated first.    Only those vaccines that enjoy authorization from the World Health Organization will be imported into the country, stated Georgian Prime Minister Giorgi Gakharia.    "As you know, at the previous Cabinet meeting, the Health Ministry was instructed to finalize the national action plan for vaccination, to make sure that it is approved by today's Cabinet meeting. The relevant working group was created on December 15 to bring together all stakeholders, including experts, international partners, field specialists, epidemiologists, doctors, the Public Defender, and others," Giorgi Gakharia said.    "Alongside its key goal, equally important is the plan's technical aspect, including timeframe and target groups to vaccinated in stages according to this timeframe. Allow me to emphasize that the highest-risk target groups will be vaccinated at the initial stage, meaning medical personnel, long-term care facility residents, our senior citizens aged 75 and over, and then all our citizens aged between 65 and 75," Giorgi Gakharia stated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130050759/https://stopcov.ge/en/News/Article/Prime_Minister%E2%80%99s_Statements_at_Cabinet_Meeting

On February 24, Ghana received 600,000 vaccine doses through COVAX and they are scheduled to roll out to the public on March 2.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307022840/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/news-style-2/1866-it-is-in-our-collective-interest-to-take-covid-19-vaccine-vp-bawumia    https://web.archive.org/web/20210306173631/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1865-update-no-24-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus

A, B, C: AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine  Ghana was one of the first countries to receive vaccines through COVAX. 600,000 doses were received on February 24 and they started to administer them to the public on March 2. The Health service has published vaccination site information in different districts around the country. A main goal of the COVAX initiative is to provide doses for at least 20% of countries' populations. Ghana aims to vaccinate 20 million Ghanians by the end of 2021. Due to the criteria above, I have coded Ghana as a 2. There is no evidence of cost for recipients; the vaccine was funded by the COVAX initiative.   "So, from Tuesday, 2nd March, to Monday, 15th March 2021, the Ghana Health Service will begin deployment of the six hundred thousand (600,000) AstraZeneca vaccines, with persons in Groups 1 and 2 being the target of this first vaccination campaign. It will be conducted in forty-three (43) districts, which are the epi-centres of the pandemic in the country. They are twenty-five (25) in Greater Accra, sixteen (16) in Ashanti, and two (2) in the Central Region."   "Group 1 is categorised as “persons most at risk and frontline State officials”. It includes healthcare workers, frontline security personnel, persons with underlying medical conditions, persons sixty (60) years and above, and frontline members of the Executive, Legislature and Judiciary.  Group 2 is made up of other essential service providers and the rest of the security agencies."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307022840/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/news-style-2/1866-it-is-in-our-collective-interest-to-take-covid-19-vaccine-vp-bawumia    https://web.archive.org/web/20210306173631/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1865-update-no-24-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307021132/https://ghanahealthservice.org/covid19/downloads/vaccine_administration.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307020522/https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2021/03/04/971798030/ghana-greets-historic-vaccine-delivery-with-a-dose-of-skepticism

Guinea began vaccinations against COVID-19 with a Russian produced vaccine on an experimental basis. Although Dr Sakoba Keita, the Director-General of the National Health Security Agency, outlined the initiative, by saying "We have ordered 2 million doses (from Russia) to be able to vaccinate vulnerable people," government ministers were among the first to receive the vaccines during the pilot phase of the rollout in late December. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210103193105/https://www.africanews.com/2020/12/31/guinea-begins-administering-russia-s-sputnik-v-covid-19-vaccine/

According to Washington Post, December 31st, 2020. Guinea began vaccinating against COVID-19 with the Russian Sputnik V vaccine on an experimental basis, starting with government officials, authorities said Thursday.    Guinea has ordered only 55 doses of the Russian vaccine, said Dr. Sakoba Keita, the director-general of the National Health Security Agency.    “We requested a small quantity of the vaccine, 55 doses precisely. This is the beginning of an order,” Keita said. “Yesterday we vaccinated in this pilot phase 25 senior officials of the state. There are 30 doses left and we will continue with the vaccination.”    However, he said on state TV Wednesday that they also sent a letter to Russia requesting 2 million doses of Sputnik V to help the country’s vulnerable. Guinea has a population of 13 million.    Guinea is one of the first African nations to vaccinate its officials.  The Minister of Defense, Mohamed Diane was the first to receive the vaccine. He was shown getting the inoculation on national TV followed by other Cabinet ministers receiving the shots on Wednesday.    Gen. Bourema Condé, Minister of Territorial Administration and Decentralization, spoke after receiving the Russian vaccine.    “This new vaccine is a strong signal. This signal shows the strong will of the president. Today is a sampling, and this sampling will be duplicated,” he said. “The president wants all Guineans to be in good health in relation to this pandemic.”    Amadou Damaro Camara, the president of the country’s legislative body, the National Assembly, was also vaccinated.    “We are the guinea pigs,” he said of receiving the first doses of the vaccine.    “It is the government’s permanent concern to want to fight against this disease and we are very happy about it,” he said. “We hope that this vaccination will be extended to the rest of the people and that it will be the beginning of the eradication of this disease.”  Tibou Camara, Guinea’s industry minister, also spoke on the television broadcast after being vaccinated.    “The Guinean population should be congratulated and rejoice at a time when the vaccine is coveted and not very accessible to many countries, and that our country is a beneficiary,” he said.    Russia has businesses in the West African nation and Guinea is known for its bauxite mining.    Russian President Vladimir Putin was among the first world leaders to congratulate Guinea’s President Alpha Conde after he won a controversial third term in office after a violently contested election in October.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210111080426/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/guinea-uses-russian-covid-19-vaccine-on-some-officials/2020/12/31/bcf30562-4b5f-11eb-97b6-4eb9f72ff46b_story.html
Vaccine still at pilot phase.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118235356/https://www.africanews.com/2020/12/31/guinea-begins-administering-russia-s-sputnik-v-covid-19-vaccine/

Guinea is the only country, among the 29 world's poorest, to have a vaccination plan. However, only 55 people have been vaccinated in a pilot phase (with Sputnik V). There is no information about the number of doses that will be available and starting from when.

Around 55 people - mainly government officials - were vaccinated during the pilot phase, but no comprehensive vaccination policy is evident beyond this. The country got free vaccines.   Guinea on Wednesday received a donation of 200,000 Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses from China as it seeks help from multiple sources to halt the spread of the coronavirus, foreign affairs minister Ibrahima Khalil Kaba told Reuters.    The West African nation of around 12 million is awaiting its first shipment of 864,000 doses from the global vaccine-sharing scheme COVAX, which started deliveries to developing countries last week.  Guinean authorities are also in talks to obtain 400,000 doses of Russia’s Sputnik V COVID-19, a health ministry official said last month.    Sixty doses of the Russian vaccine were previously provided on an experimental basis, with President Alpha Conde and some ministers among those inoculated.   Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322104842/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-guinea-idUSL5N2L1637

The government of The Gambia has approved Astrazeneca as COVID-19 vaccine for use.  On 3rd March Gambia has received its first shipment of 36,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccines through the COVAX Facility, less than a week after the Ministry of Health submitted the required documentation for the delivery of the vaccines to the country. The AstraZeneca vaccines were shipped by UNICEF on behalf of COVAX, from the Serum Institute of India (SII), and arrived at the Banjul International Airport late Tuesday night.  More shipments of COVID-19 vaccines and syringes are expected in the coming weeks.   The country plans to vaccinate frontline health workers, people who are 65 and above and those with co-morbidities in the first round of the campaign, Bittaye said. The start date of the vaccination drive hasn’t yet been confirmed, he said.    https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.unicef.org/wca/press-releases/first-tranche-covid-19-vaccines-arrives-gambia-covax-initiative  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-03/gambia-set-to-start-vaccinations-after-covax-senegal-donations

The Greek Ministry of Health has developed a priority system for COVID-19 vaccination and system for appointments, available on the Greek government webpage at https://emvolio.gov.gr/. The current phase of vaccination is for individuals age 75 and above, individuals age 60-65, and individuals with certain high-risk health conditions, according to announcements by the National Public Health Organization.  The vaccination phase for individuals age 70-74 opened as of March 26, 2021. So, priority groups currently are the elderly and those with co-morbidities. https://web.archive.org/web/20210330075700/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Policy:  The current phase of vaccination is for individuals age 60 and above and individuals with certain high-risk health conditions, according to announcements by the National Public Health Organization. Notably, 70 and above were previously considered one group at initial rollout, 60 and above were incorporated as a priority group as of April 2nd, however, these were not classified as a third group because they all fall into the general "elderly" category. People who come into contact with animals that may carry mutated strains of the SARS-CoV-2 virus    e. Individuals important for ensuring the functioning and continuity of the state    2    People aged 85 and over    3    People aged 80 and over    4    People aged 75 and over    5    a. People with underlying diseases at high risk    (regardless of age *)    b. People aged 70 and over    6    People aged 65 and over    7    a. People aged 60 and over    b. Vaccinations (Pfizer/BioNTech) have been carried out in the main cities of entry, namely Nuuk, Ilulissat, Aasiaat, Sisimiut and Qaqortoq. The target groups have been everyone aged 65 and over, health and care workers, as well as people who are medically assessed to be at particular risk of serious illness. A successful co-operation project with the Arctic Command has also been carried out, where vaccinations have been carried out in Qeqertarsuatsiaat and Paamiut.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329104455/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2021/03/2603_Vaccine    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329105554/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/greenland/

Greenland has a vaccination strategy where the delivery of vaccines is directly affected by the vaccine supply provided to Denmark. The vaccine type is issued by Pfizer/BioNtech. The population groups that will be vaccinated first include the elderly, physically vulnerable, chronically ill and relevant health care personnel. The number of vaccines shipped to Greenland is scarce, and therefore the vaccinations will be periodically rolled out according to target group prioritisations and residency location. The locals will be contacted directly when their group is next in line for the vaccine:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401155951/https://visitgreenland.com/articles/corona-virus-status/

A,B,C. Pfizer.  At present, Greenland receives a limited number of vaccines. Vaccination is therefore offered in a priority order, which is determined by the authorities on the basis of health professional assessments.    Initially, the following target groups have been offered vaccination:    Citizens over 65 years  Residents of retirement homes  Employees in old people's homes, in home care and selected groups in the health care system who all have extensive patient contact in their work.  Persons in special risk groups (selected by the Health Service).  http://web.archive.org/web/20210427162506/https://corona.nun.gl/emner/vaccination/tilbud_om_vaccination?sc_lang=da

Updated on December 3rd, the government, a member of the COVAX facility, has prepaid about one seventh of the total cost for 6.7 million doses of vaccines and, since a double dose is required, it will vaccinate 3.4 million people, about one fifth of the population. In mid-November, the Ministry of Health created the National Coordination Committee for Vaccination against COVID-19 with the purpose to coordinate the National Strategic Plan.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205091344/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

In addition, the authorities engaged in bilateral negotiations with two laboratories seeking to cover their entire adult population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221081002/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

A    The GTM government, a member of the COVAX facility, has prepaid about one seventh of the total cost purchase for 6.74 million doses of vaccines and since a double dose is required, it will vaccinate 3.37 million people, about one fifth of the population. Covax has recently closed negotiations with AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson and Sanofi. In addition, the government has been engaged in bilateral negotiations with two pharmaceuticals, AstraSeneca and Moderna, seeking to cover its entire adult population.. The vaccine will be applied first to doctors, nurses, firefighters, police and soldiers. Pregnant women and children under the age of 18 will not be able to receive the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111150322/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
A, No policy change.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118093431/https://gt.usembassy.gov/alert-covid-19-2/

The Vaccine and Antiviral Prioritization Policy Committee (VAPPC) held its inaugural meeting Thursday 10th December and the initial identification of priority groups have been broken down into three phases. Phase 1 will include the Healthcare personnel Residents of long-term care facilities, Essential Service workers, people with comorbidities and Elderly adults (65 years of age or older). http://web.archive.org/web/20201215021427/https://guamrecovery.com/jic-release-no-486-vaccine-and-antiviral-prioritization-policy-committee-holds-first-meeting-12-10-2020/

The Department of Public Health and Social Services (DPHSS) placed its first order of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines on December 4 for 3,900 doses. It has been given authorization to place its next order in the next 24 to 48 hours for a minimum of  3,900 doses. This number is subject to change.   Additionally, DPHSS has placed its first order of Moderna vaccines, or vaccine B, on Saturday, December 12, for a total of 3,800 doses. The Moderna vaccine must still undergo the same review and approval process as the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine before distribution begins to states and territories.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201215020809/https://guamrecovery.com/jic-release-no-492-dphss-anticipates-arrival-of-first-vaccine-order-by-end-of-week-dphss-issues-guidance-memo-no-2020-45/

COVID-19 vaccination clinics continue on Tuesday, March 23 to March 27, from 11 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. at the UOG Fieldhouse. These clinics will administer first doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine and second doses of both the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.   PHASE 1a/1b/1c – CATEGORY: Healthcare workers; local and federal law enforcement personnel; School-based employees and Childcare Center employees; adults 40 years and older; Mayors’ Council of Guam (limited to mayors, vice mayors, and mayoral staff); funeral homes, mortuary, and cemetery staff; service providers contracted with the DPHSS Division of Senior Citizens providing direct patient or client care such as transportation for medical appointments, homebound meals, in-home services, caregiver services, case management, shelter care, adult daycare, and other direct services; and others who are due for dose two of the vaccine. Eligibility is subject to change. The COVID-19 vaccination program is being rolled out across the country. The two groups that are being vaccinated are "A,C:" key workers and elderly. The Government has announced the arrival of a shipment with 80000 doses of AstraZeneca Oxford - COVISHIELD which are been provided to the population along with the previous 20000 doses of the Sinopharm vaccine.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210320101347/https://dpi.gov.gy/covid-19-vaccination-advisory/ http://web.archive.org/web/20210320111240/https://dpi.gov.gy/80000-doses-of-covid-19-vaccines-arrive-in-guyana/ http://web.archive.org/web/20210307155655/https://dpi.gov.gy/sinopharm-covid-19-vaccines-arrive-in-guyana/

A,C (AstraZeneca, Sinovax): "The campaign which began on February 12, saw healthcare workers receiving the first jab, before it was expanded to persons ages 60 years and older. To date, over 25,000 persons have been inoculated.  Guyana has so far received 103,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccines from the Governments of Barbados, China and India."  The Guyana government is currently awaiting a batch of 24,000 vaccines through the COVAX mechanism and another 200,000 doses of the Sputnik V vaccine from Russia. The Government also plans to purchase another 149,000 doses under a CARICOM-African Union agreement.  The priority groups are as follows: "On completion of the first category of immunisations, persons ages 50 years and older, other frontline workers including teachers, servicemen and women and people with comorbidities would be vaccinated."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328202103/https://dpi.gov.gy/soesdyke-kuru-kuru-residents-brave-rain-to-get-vaccinated/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328202515/https://dpi.gov.gy/residents-of-unity-clonbrook-receive-covid-19-vaccines/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328201330/https://dpi.gov.gy/region-nine-completes-covid-19-vaccination-of-health-workers/
A,B,C. Those over 60, those with comorbidities key workers are currently being vaccinated. The AstraZeneca vaccine is being administered.  source: https://archive.vn/cDHjN

All Groups are entitled to receive the vaccine: Health workers, clinically vulnerable and persons older than 40 years. The vaccination has been carried out with AstraZeneca, Coronavac, and Sputnik V vaccines.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210502104235/https://dpi.gov.gy/sputnik-v-vaccine-arrives/

The Government conducted a broad campaign where all people over 18 years old can be vaccinated besides those already targeted.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210430175851/https://dpi.gov.gy/persons-18-years-and-older-receiving-covid-vaccines-from-today/

Everybody above 18 years besides those already targeted is eligible for vaccinations. Sinopharm, Sputnik and AstraZeneca are used. http://web.archive.org/web/20210430175851/https://dpi.gov.gy/persons-18-years-and-older-receiving-covid-vaccines-from-today/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210519100047/https://dpi.gov.gy/govt-receives-67537-more-doses-of-sputnik-v-covid-19-vaccine/

On December 11, Hong Kong Leader announced the government had signed advanced purchase agreements to procure 7.5 million vaccines, the first batch of which could arrive as early as January. The government’s plan was to stock up enough doses for two full inoculations for each of the city’s 7.5 million residents. The authorities will manage the purchase, administration and prioritization of the jabs.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201212095025/https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3113667/covid-19-vaccines-hong-kong-how-safe-are-they-and

The Government published the Use of Vaccines Regulation on December 23, which provides the legal framework for emergency use of COVID-19 vaccines.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201228084947/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202012/24/P2020122300963.htm?fontSize=1
No policy change

Government estimated that starting in February, members of the public can get vaccinated through vaccination programmes led by the Government free of charge.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210115230731/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202101/13/P2021011300566.htm

Vaccines are still not available.   On January 21, Scientific Committee under the Centre for Health Protection of the Department of Health reached consensus interim recommendations on use of COVID-19 vaccines in Hong Kong.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210124075621/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202101/21/P2021012100430.htm?fontSize=1

Vaccines are still not available.   The Government plans provide vaccines for the majority of the Hong Kong population within 2021 through vaccination programmes led by the Government. Members of the public can receive the vaccines on a voluntary basis free of charge.   The Secretary for Food and Health (SFH) authorised the COVID-19 vaccine by Fosun Pharma/BioNTech for emergency use in Hong Kong in accordance with the Prevention and Control of Disease (Use of Vaccines) Regulation (Cap. 599K).  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130082018/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202101/27/P2021012700522.htm?fontSize=1  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130082150/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202101/25/P2021012500829.htm?fontSize=1

Vaccines are still not available.   The Government plans to provide vaccines for the majority of the Hong Kong population within 2021 through vaccination programmes led by the Government.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130082018/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202101/27/P2021012700522.htm?fontSize=1

'Hong Kong can start vaccinations for Covid-19 in early March if everything goes as planned, the city’s Civil Service Secretary Patrick Nip said.  The first batch of vaccines from the German firm BioNTech SE should arrive at the end of this month, Nip said, according to a transcript of his comments to reporters provided by the government. Vaccines will be administered via an advance booking process, he said.  The government will offer the shots at community vaccination centers in 18 districts of Hong Kong, said Nip, who is in charge of Covid-19 vaccinations in the city.'    https://archive.vn/zBOSl  https://archive.vn/nw5B0

The Government will launch the citywide COVID-19 Vaccination Programme from February 26 and five priority groups may make an appointment via the online booking system from February 23.    https://archive.fo/5LfDS    The Secretary for Food & Health (SFH) today authorised the COVID-19 vaccine by Sinovac Biotech (Hong Kong) for emergency use in Hong Kong.    https://archive.fo/6vbAd
The first batch of one million doses of Sinovac COVID-19 vaccine was delivered to Hong Kong on 19th Feb    https://archive.vn/Vaogd
About 70,000 people have reserved their first and second doses of the vaccine and all slots available between February 26 and March 11 have been taken up.    https://archive.vn/wwbVm

The COVID-19 Vaccination Programme was officially launched today. A total of about 6,000 people received their first dose of the vaccine on 26th Feb.    https://archive.vn/iGhDe    The Government decided to arrange priority vaccination for the five groups below:    - Persons aged 60 years or above (a maximum of two carers who accompany elderly people aged 70 or above can also receive vaccination);  - Personnel in healthcare settings and those participating in anti-epidemic related work;  - Residents and staff of residential care homes for the elderly / persons with disabilities;  - Personnel maintaining critical public services; and  - Personnel providing cross-boundary transportation or working at control points and ports.    https://archive.vn/ZJ791
About 7,000 people received their first doses of the vaccine under the COVID-19 Vaccination Programme today, the Government announced.    https://archive.vn/haEhs

The Department of Health started distributing the first batch of the Sinovac vaccine to private doctors and clinics participating in the COVID-19 Vaccination Programme. People can choose and make an appointment to be vaccinated directly with a private doctor or clinic under the programme, without going through the Government's online booking system. They must bring their identity document and proof of belonging to a priority group to their vaccination appointment.    https://archive.vn/rIK16

A,B,C  Sinovac    Around 10,000 citizens have received the Sinovac vaccine through private doctors as at 4pm, the Department of Health announced today. The department explained that starting March 1, it has been distributing the first batch of the Sinovac vaccines to private doctors and clinics participating in the COVID-19 Vaccination Programme. The relevant private doctors and clinics began providing vaccination to the public from March 2. A, B, C and additional priority groups (sinovac, Comirnaty)    The Government today expanded the scope of priority groups to cover seven categories of people who have greater risk of exposure to COVID-19 and risk of infection. The seven categories of people include staff of premises that serve food and beverages, markets, supermarkets, convenience stores, couriers and takeaway delivery including food delivery. It also comprises staff of local public transport service operators, registered construction workers and property management such as security guards and cleaning and security personnel. The remaining categories include teachers and school staff, employees in the tourism industry and staff of scheduled premises under the Prevention & Control of Disease (Requirements & Directions) (Business & Premises) Regulation.    https://archive.ph/TEAbn#selection-563.0-579.229    Arranged by the Government, around 100 people in the vaccination priority groups received the Comirnaty vaccine at the community vaccination centre at Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park Sports Centre this morning.    https://archive.ph/CDvsP

A, B, C and additional priority groups (sinovac)    BioNTech vaccination suspended     The Government today announced that it immediately suspended COVID-19 vaccinations concerning BioNTech (Comirnaty) after deviations in the vial seal were found in one batch of the vaccine. It explained that it received written notification this morning from Fosun Industrial Co about the deviations that involve batch 210102. The Government noted that while BioNTech and Fosun Pharma have no reason to believe there is a risk to product safety, for the sake of prudence, vaccination of the batch concerned should be suspended pending an investigation.    https://archive.ph/lohJg

'The Secretary for Food & Health today [3 June 2021] approved lowering the age limit for receiving the BioNTech vaccine to 12.  The Department of Health submitted the application for lowering the age limit to the Advisory Panel on COVID-19 Vaccines earlier, along with relevant clinical trial data for consideration.  After scrutinising relevant information, the advisory panel advised the health chief to approve the application.  Having regard to the panel's advice and taking into consideration the threat to public health posed by COVID-19, the bureau chief considered that the benefits of lowering the age limit for receiving the BioNTech vaccine outweigh the risks.  This can also protect adolescents from COVID-19 and enable them to resume normal school and daily life as soon as possible, the Government said.  It will announce the arrangements for providing the BioNTech vaccine to adolescents aged 12 to 15 early next week.'    https://archive.vn/yjV9d

'The Government will make it convenient for students to get vaccinated, Secretary for the Civil Service Patrick Nip said today [5 June 2021].  Mr Nip made the statement this morning. It comes after the age limit for receiving the BioNTech vaccine was lowered to 12.  He said: “We'll focus on two aspects. First is to disseminate information and the relevant data, messages to schools, including teachers, students and parents.  “I am glad that the medical community has already been doing this. It's important for us to tell the schools about the importance of getting vaccination, and also the safety, the efficacy of getting the jabs.  “The second aspect is that we would arrange very convenient and multiple channels to enable students, parents and teachers to get vaccinated.”  He called on people to get their first jab by the end of August.'    https://archive.ph/GXXi7

'The Government announced today (July 5) that, given public health considerations, the COVID-19 Vaccination Programme has, since the end of May, covered Mainland residents who are holders of the Exit-entry Permit for Travelling to and from Hong Kong and Macao and will stay in Hong Kong for a period of time. The Government is also preparing to arrange for non-refoulement claimants and refugees recognised by the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees who are in Hong Kong to be vaccinated starting from around mid-July. The coverage of the Vaccination Programme is now further extended to other visitors who are allowed to stay in Hong Kong for a period of time as permitted under the law (hereinafter referred to as "other visitors").                 A Government spokesman said that at present, there are over 2 000 other visitors who are holding valid travel documents and have to continue to stay in Hong Kong owing to the COVID-19 epidemic. On public health considerations, providing vaccination for these other visitors will help prevent the spread of the virus in the community and thus enhance Hong Kong's overall anti-epidemic capability.           Other visitors who will be covered by the Vaccination Programme must be holders of valid travel documents who are allowed to stay in Hong Kong as permitted by the law, and can complete two doses of vaccination within their limit of stay without extension. From July 6, they can bring their travel documents and the landing slips or extension of stay labels (applicable to other visitors with extension of stay) issued by the Immigration Department to any post office (except mobile post offices) during office hours and the staff will assist them in making appointments for completing two doses of vaccination in the 29 Community Vaccination Centres within their limit of stay.              In general, all visitors to Hong Kong must depart Hong Kong on or before the expiry date of their limit of stay. If there is a special or urgent need to stay longer, visitors may make an extension of stay application within seven days before their limit of stay expires. Applications will be considered on individual merits, but those made solely for the purpose of getting vaccination will not be considered.'    https://archive.vn/Abu0z

A measure relevant to HK's vaccination policy:    'The Government today [8 July 2021] announced that it will arrange one-off health check services for taxi and public light bus drivers from July 15 to help them understand their health conditions and decide whether they are suitable for COVID-19 vaccination.  The health check is voluntary and free of charge.  Designated health check centres will provide physical examination, diabetes, anemia and gout screening, blood lipid profile and a health check report for participating drivers.  From July 12, taxi and public light bus drivers may register via WhatsApp or WeChat at 9465 1172, and provide their names, Hong Kong Identity Card numbers, driver identity plate numbers and phone numbers.  Successful registrants will receive a registration number. They can call or send WhatsApp messages to the desired health check centre for booking two working days after receiving the registration numbers.  A limited quota is available for the free health check services on a first-come, first-served basis.  The services will run until August 14.'    https://archive.vn/5fUGj

HK government press releases:  'Regarding media reports about a man receiving two extra doses of COVID-19 vaccines in Hong Kong after his completion of two doses of vaccines overseas, a Government spokesman today (July 19) appealed to the public for receiving COVID-19 vaccines following the Government's arrangement.               With regard to the two COVID-19 vaccines approved for emergency use in Hong Kong and provided under the Government vaccination programme, the current Government's arrangement is: for people who had never received any COVID-19 vaccines, they need to receive two doses; for people who were infected with COVID-19, they only need to receive one dose; for people arriving in Hong Kong who had received the first dose in places outside Hong Kong, they need to honestly convey to the healthcare service provider responsible for administering the vaccine the details regarding the first dose in order to be considered for the second dose; as regards people arriving in Hong Kong who had completed the entire vaccination course in places outside Hong Kong, there is no need for them to receive extra doses of COVID-19 vaccines.'    https://archive.vn/FGfeh

From Monday, March 1, 2021, all Croatian citizens and residents in Croatia can apply for vaccinations. After receiving the application, citizens will receive a notification about the place and time of vaccination to their email address, text message or phone, depending on the choice at check-in.  People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of younger age.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210412234934/https://www.koronavirus.hr/najnovije/pokrenut-sustav-prijavljivanja-za-cijepljenje-cijepise-zdravlje-hr-i-0800-0011/898

From Monday, March 1, 2021, all Croatian citizens and residents in Croatia can apply for vaccinations. After receiving the application, citizens will receive a notification about the place and time of vaccination to their email address, text message or phone, depending on the choice at check-in.  People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of younger age.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210419122444/https://www.koronavirus.hr/najnovije/pokrenut-sustav-prijavljivanja-za-cijepljenje-cijepise-zdravlje-hr-i-0800-0011/898

Vaccines available in Croatia are Pfizer–BioNTech, Moderna, and AstraZeneca. The primary target of the vaccination are the following: 1) employees and residents of homes for the elderly; 2) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases and 3) the rest of the population.    From March 1, 2021, all Croatian citizens and persons residing in Croatia can apply for vaccination via the cijepise.zdravlje.hr website or by phone at  0800 0011, where applications will be received and recorded in the central registration system. After receiving the application, citizens will receive a notification about the place and date of vaccination to their e-mail address, SMS or phone, depending on the choice at registration. People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of a younger age. Vaccination is carried out in family medicine surgeries, especially for chronic patients, in the  County Institutes of Public Health and at mass vaccination points.    Foreigners who are in Croatia as tourists cannot register for the vaccine.     https://archive.vn/Cts1T   https://archive.vn/CfGOY

•	As of 27 Jan 2021, inoculation of healthcare workers nearly complete.  •	Vaccinations for nursing homes and residential social institutions were carried out.  •	Nearly 90% of those over the age of 65 registered have already been vaccinated.  •	On February 11, vaccination of chronic patients under the age of 60 began.    •	The police, law enforcement officers and soldiers involved in the defense were also vaccinated.  •	As of 14 April 2021: patients in the highest risk groups have received their shots; fully 178,000 teachers were given preferential shots in two rounds (80% of the profession); most general practitioners are under way vaccinating active age adults. Vaccination is voluntary and free of charge. The order in which people are vaccinated is not determined by the order in which they register, but by their vulnerability to disease caused by the coronavirus. Already 16-18-year-olds can take the vaccine, and about 90,000 students studying in technical or vocational schools can take advantage of this opportunity. In the first round, young people who have previously registered and made an appointment will receive the Pfizer vaccine.   Vaccines available in Hungary are the following:  Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, Astra Zeneca, Sinopharm, Sputnik V. The Hungarian government has announced that a COVID-19 vaccine will be provided to everyone who is legally present in Hungary and is old enough to receive an approved vaccine.  The vaccine will be provided free of charge.  Residents who are not participants in the Hungarian State Health Insurance program (“TAJ”) will be prioritized after those who are program participants.    Starting on May 4, foreign citizens living in Hungary without TAJ cards can now register for COVID vaccinations here: https://vakcinainfo.gov.hu/.  The registration website is in both English and Hungarian.    https://archive.vn/8e0IL   https://archive.vn/aTqdv   https://archive.vn/0zwq6
