A;B;C  Covishield (a version of the Oxford–AstraZeneca vaccine manufactured by the Serum Institute of India)   Covaxin (developed by Bharat Biotech)  Sputnik V (procured by Dr. Reddy's Labs from Russia)    Notes on Sputnik:   1. The pricing and procurement routes of Sputnik V in India is interesting. It is the first COVID19 vaccine that seems to be procured and may potentially be sold outside of Govt channels in India -- at least with its pilot program that started the rollout of this particular vaccine.   2. Next, given that the vaccine's deployment is still in very early stages it is unclear to what extent it would be available to private hospitals and organizations (i.e. outside of govt. channels).  3. It is also not clear the extent to which Sputnik shots would be covered/funded by Central/State/Local governments.   4. Given its early days, for now, I am going to continue marking H7 as "govt. funded" ... as its deployment increases, and levels of Govt funding for Sputnik V becomes clearer, H7 may need to be coded as 4I.    https://archive.vn/62Q0H: Date 14 May 2021 Sputnik V was rolled out in India in a limited pilot program by Dr. Reddy's Lab in Hyderabad on May 14 2021:: "India on Friday began using Sputnik V in its battle against COVID-19 with the first dose of the vaccine from Russia administered in Hyderabad. The vaccine is being sold at a maximum retail price of ?995 per dose.  The use of the vaccine follows clearance for the imported doses from the Central Drugs Laboratory in Kasauli on Thursday. Sputnik V that last month was accorded emergency use authorisation by the Drugs Controller General of India... .  Members of the senior leadership of Dr. Reddy’s said the vaccine will be supplied at the same price —?948 plus 5% GST — to both government and private sector. For the consumers, there would also be administering charges levied by hospitals. Given that the vaccine must be stored at minus 18 degrees C and the lack of availability of such cold chain infrastructure, the company said, “We will begin with Metros and Tier 1 cities and scale up to the rest of India.”   In the run up to the launch, the company’s leadership had said the cost of imported Sputnik V, which is a two dose vaccine, in India would hover around the $10 a dose at which it was priced in other global markets by Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF).  Co-Chairman and Managing Director G.V. Prasad said, “We are prioritising our efforts to launch Sputnik V vaccine across India.” Dr. Reddy’s was also in discussion with a couple of State governments for vaccine offtake."    ---------------    "On 19 April, it was announced that the next phase of the vaccine program would begin on 1 May, extending eligibility to all residents over the age of 18. Registration for the next phase began on 28 April; a single-day record of nearly 13.3 million people registered. Phase-II  was initiated from 1st March 2021 and 1st April 2021 and focussed on	  protecting the	most vulnerable i.e.	population more than 45 years of age. Widespread vaccination by Sept. 2021    Mostafa Ghane'ei, an official with the Vice Presidency for Science and Technology, said that the domestically produced COVID-19 vaccine will probably be injected into the whole population in the [next Iranian calendar year] month of Mehr (starting September 23, 2021).    Emphasizing that no Iranian vaccine has been yet allowed to enter the human phase so far, he said that “progress is made when the Food and Drug Administration issues a vaccine clinical work permit.”    All vaccines are in the pre-clinical stage and it is hoped that at least 4 vaccines to start phase 3 of the human trial in September 2021, he highlighted.    Now that coronavirus vaccines have been developed in the world and the third phase of clinical trials has passed, the possible side effects are almost certain, and Iran will be aware of the side effects which speeds up the process, he noted, adding, “vaccines produced in Iran are the same as those produced in China, India, the United States, etc.”    Iraj Harirchi, the deputy minister of health, has said that in Iran, 12 groups are making efforts to develop coronavirus vaccine, three of which have passed the animal testing.    Last week, Namaki expressed hope that the country will introduce the home-grown COVID-19 vaccine by the end of the current Iranian calendar year (March 19, 2021).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201215165940/https://www.tehrantimes.com/news/454829/High-hopes-for-COVID-19-vaccine-in-Iran

Around 4 million doses are being also negotiated with China"  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125140855/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Mass vaccination against COVID-19   started in Iran on February 9, with the priority given to medical staff, the elderly, and people with underlying diseases, President Hassan Rouhani announced.  Iran imported the Sputnik V vaccine from Russia.   Importing vaccine from COVAX, a global initiative to ensure rapid and equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines, is also on the agenda. And already the first shipment of the COVAX vaccine was delivered.  Iranian scientists have been working on developing domestic vaccines against the coronavirus, two of which are in the human trial phase.    Coviran Barekat, the first coronavirus vaccine made by Iranian researchers of the Headquarters for Executing the Order of the Imam, was unveiled and injected into three volunteers during a ceremony on December 29, 2020.    The second COVID-19 vaccine is a product of the Razi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute. Razi COV-Pars — an mRNA recombinant vaccine — is administered via injection and inhalation.    https://archive.vn/nltAB  https://archive.vn/rdoy1  https://archive.vn/GwPbY  https://archive.vn/zmFUK  https://archive.vn/LzSYI

Iranian scientists have been working on developing domestic vaccines against the coronavirus, two of which are in the human trial phase.    Coviran Barekat, the first coronavirus vaccine made by Iranian researchers of the Headquarters for Executing the Order of the Imam, was unveiled and injected into three volunteers during a ceremony on December 29, 2020.    The second COVID-19 vaccine is a product of the Razi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute. Razi COV-Pars — an mRNA recombinant vaccine — is administered via injection and inhalation.    https://archive.vn/nltAB  https://archive.vn/rdoy1  https://archive.vn/GwPbY  https://archive.vn/zmFUK  https://archive.vn/LzSYI

Iraq is expected to receive its first doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine by February, according to Iraq’s Health Minister on Monday.     Last month, the ministry announced it had signed a preliminary deal with the vaccine makers to import 1.5 million doses by early 2021. Health Ministry spokesperson Saif al-Badr confirmed this week with state-owned newspaper al-Sabah that Iraq’s share of the vaccine is now 8 million doses, enough to cover 20% of the country’s population. Troops, health care workers and the elderly are prioritized for vaccines, Badr had said in December.     “The distribution will be made to all governorates through hospitals to be determined through the media and according to priority,” he told al-Sabah on Monday. “The vaccine will not be compulsory at all.”        Read more: https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2021/01/iraq-baghdad-coronavirus-vaccine-covax.html#ixzz6jwM9BWXS

Particular importance will be placed on vaccinating persons who are in the frontline in the battle against the pandemic. This applies to healthcare workers and others working in emergency departments and intensive care units in hospitals, on COVID-19 wards and wards for patients who have been infected with COVID-19, healthcare workers who perform screening tests in cases of suspected COVID-19 and the staff of nursing and retirement homes. The vaccination of persons living in nursing and retirement homes and old-age wards in hospitals will also have high priority.    There are ten priority groups. The groups with the greatest priority consist of a relatively few number of people; the first five groups are estimated to number around 20,000 persons.    Group 6: Persons aged 60 and older    Group 7: Persons with underlying long-term illnesses    Group 8: Employees of nursery, primary and secondary schools and select groups of social and welfare service workers    Group 9: Persons who are in sensitive circumstances due to their social and economic situation    And finally, Group 10: All others who request vaccination, as determined by the Chief Epidemiologist.    The regulation makes no provision for the COVID-19 vaccination of children born 2006 or later unless such children have an underlying long-term illness and are members of a special risk group.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210103140447/https://www.covid.is/categories/information-on-covid-19-vaccine

A, C:    Iceland received the first doses of COVID-19 vaccine on December 28 and vaccination began on December 29. At the moment, Iceland is expecting to receive vaccine for at least 30,000 people before the end of March.  COVID-19 vaccination is optional and free of charge in Iceland. Vaccines are being administered according to priority groups defined by health authorities, though the Chief Epidemiologist may grant exceptions to that order. The first to be vaccinated were frontline healthcare workers and nursing home residents. According to the current vaccination schedule, the next priority groups are people over the age of 70, paramedics who transport COVID-19 patients, and some additional healthcare workers        https://web.archive.org/web/20210106190138/https://www.icelandreview.com/ask-ir/whats-the-status-of-covid-19-vaccination-in-iceland/      http://web.archive.org/web/20210103140447/https://www.covid.is/categories/information-on-covid-19-vaccine

A, C:    There are ten priority groups:   "Group 1  Healthcare professionals and other staff working in emergency wards and intensive care units of Landspítali University Hospital and the intensive care unit in the hospital in Akureyri.  Group 2  Healthcare workers working in COVID-19 out-patient wards and wards for patients who have been infected with COVID-19.  Group 3  Persons living in nursing and retirement homes and old-age wards in hospitals.  Group 4  Ambulance staff, paramedics, the employees of the Icelandic Coast Guard, fire brigade employees, prison guards, call-out police officers.  Group 5  Healthcare professionals involved in the primary care of patients and who must necessarily be vaccinated.  Group 6  Persons aged 60 and older.  Groups 7  Persons with underlying long-term illnesses who are at particular risk.  Groups 8  Employees of nursery, primary and secondary schools and select groups of social and welfare service workers.  Groups 9  Persons who are in sensitive circumstances due to their social and economic situation.  Groups 10  All others who request vaccination."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210203164947/https://www.covid.is/covid-19-vaccine     As of 02 Feb 2021, the government is vaccinating up to group 6:   "Vaccinations are taking place between between 9:00 and 15:00 at Suðurlandsbraut 34 today. These will be for people in priority group six; a group of 2,600 people, 70% of which have already started vaccinating in nursing homes."   Both Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are being administered.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210202140059/https://grapevine.is/news/2021/02/02/more-covid-19-vaccines-arrive-in-iceland/    The next group, Group 7, will include B, our "clinically vulnerable groups".

"Members of the public aged 18-35 are encouraged to contact the HMOs to schedule an appointment for vaccination (starting tomorrow).  "Despite the opening of the vaccination operation to the general public, Minister of Health Yuli Edelstein and the Ministry's Director General have ordered the HMOs to focus their efforts on those aged 50 and older and those confined to their homes."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212120510/https://www.gov.il/en/departments/news/03022021-01  ***Updated to add source

HMOs are offering the vaccine to all members over 16. The army is vaccinating forces. The percentage of the population vaccinated is now over 47% indicating both availability and delivery. Vaccination is voluntary.    "The majority of the Israeli population will be vaccinated. In the first stage, certain groups, such as children (under 16 years of age) and recovered patients, will not be vaccinated due to a lack of information about vaccination among these populations."    Percentage of vaccinated in the total population: 21/2  	• 47.06% first dose vaccinated  	• 32.29% second dose vaccinated    Who will get the vaccine first?  	• The vaccine is given to individuals who are 16 years of age or older.  	• Pregnant women or women who plan to be pregnant can get the vaccine.   	• People with an acute illness, especially if their body temperature is 38 degrees Celsius or higher, should recover before getting the vaccine.    Who will not get the vaccine at this stage?  	• People who are younger than 16 years of age.  	• People with a history of severe allergic reactions. They are required to tell staff before they are vaccinated and ask if they can have the vaccine.  	• Certified recovered COVID-19 patients.    Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20210224150712if_/https://datadashboard.health.gov.il/COVID-19/general    https://web.archive.org/web/20210223153943/https://govextra.gov.il/ministry-of-health/covid19-vaccine/en-covid19-vaccination-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226115508/https://govextra.gov.il/ministry-of-health/covid19-vaccine/en-covid19-vaccine-faqs/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226113624/https://www.timesofisrael.com/poll-some-25-of-israelis-who-havent-vaccinated-have-no-intention-of-doing-so/

"As the Delta variant spreads, Israel has become the first country in the world to begin distributing third dose booster shots to adults with impaired immune systems, based on “accumulating evidence” indicating they aren’t well enough protected after their initial doses.    "The Health Ministry issued a statement to healthcare providers on Monday, saying they are free to start giving the boosters — clearing up confusion created on Sunday when minister Nitzan Horowitz said they were available, but doctors weren’t told.    “There is accumulating evidence that patients with immunosuppression do not develop a satisfactory antibody response after two doses of the coronavirus vaccine, and some of them may develop antibodies after a third dose,” wrote Dr. Emilia Anis, head of the ministry’s epidemiological unit. Jordan on Wednesday began its vaccination campaign against the coronavirus pandemic, with healthcare workers and the elderly prioritized for the first shots.    Dr. Daoud Hanania, the country’s former director of medical services, became the first person to receive the injection in an event aired by state TV.    Health Minister Nazir Obeidat earlier said that the vaccination program will prioritize the most vulnerable groups including the elderly, those who suffer from chronic diseases, and medical personnel.    According to the Health Ministry, 29 centers across the kingdom will receive the vaccines.    The jabs arrived in Jordan on Saturday and Monday, starting with 3,800 tons of the Chinese Sinopharm virus vaccine and the Pfizer-BioNTech respectively, according to official media sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118223154/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/latest-on-coronavirus-outbreak/jordan-begins-covid-19-vaccine-rollout/2108497

Jordan has become one of the world’s first countries to start COVID-19 vaccinations for refugees, UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency, reports today:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201214421/https://www.unhcr.org/uk/news/press/2021/1/5ffffe614/refugees-receive-covid-19-vaccinations-jordan.html
No change in policy.

Not noted who is eligible  Has the government of Jordan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use????Yes  Individuals in Jordan may register to receive a vaccine at?https://vaccine.jo/cvms/?(English and Arabic). Both Jordanian citizens and non-Jordanian nationals are eligible to register for a vaccine in Jordan.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210122011932/https://corona.moh.gov.jo/en

"The vaccination campaign in Jordan is led by the Ministry of Health and National Centre for Security and Crises Management, under the umbrella of the Government of Jordan.    Any individual on Jordanian soil is eligible to receive the vaccine, and it is free-of-charge. Therefore, you do not have to pay any fees."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308155417/https://help.unhcr.org/jordan/en/frequently-asked-questions-unhcr/covid-19-vaccine/

The first phase of vaccinations started on January 13, with the goal to vaccinate about 1.75 million people. Priority is being given to healthcare workers, and health-vulnerable populations (including refugees). 3rd Dec 2020, Japan's parliament enacted a law to cover the costs for residents to be vaccinated against the novel coronavirus, (Law says the government will cover all vaccine costs for Japan's 126 million residents, although the revised law does not clarify whether the scheme will include foreign residents of Japan, but health ministry officials have said they expect them to be covered based on other vaccinations offered for free)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115184013/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/12/4cca32cd0580-japan-enacts-law-to-make-coronavirus-vaccines-free-to-residents.html

A - Medical workers  Pfizer  No policy changes.  https://archive.ph/T33pO    Japan is in the midst of inoculating about 4.8 million health care workers and plans to expand the vaccine rollout to the rest of the population, starting off with people aged 65 or older, a group of about 36 million, from April 12.  https://archive.ph/jrsRt    As a side note, there is increased activity to develop vaccines in Japan. Shionogi became the second company to trial a Japan-originated COVID-19 vaccine late last year, and KM Biologics disclosed the initiation of its study on the same day as Daiichi. Japan is set to receive 100 million doses of the Pfizer vaccine between May and June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517231133/https://www.timeout.com/tokyo/news/heres-the-tentative-timeline-of-japans-covid-19-vaccination-programme-012021    C. As of June 21, the government begins inoculating occupational sites for universities and companies that have submitted applications for workplace vaccination. Over 13.73 million employees of 3,400 workplaces are scheduled for vaccination at 260 venues. 17 universities begin vaccinations for all students, faculty, staff, and associated frontline employees across 11 prefectures: Hokkaido Medical University; Tokushima University; Tokyo International University; Tokyo University, Keio University, Nihon University, Japan Physical Education University; Shonan Institute of Technology; Matsumoto Dental University; Osaka University, Osaka University of Economics and Law, Kansai University, Kinki University, Yamato University; Kobe City College of Nursing; Hiroshima University; Tokushima University; Nagasaki International University.  This is in addition to high risk medical workers and those age 65+ that can already access vaccination. As of July 11, 76% of the eligible elderly population have received their first dose, 46% have received their second dose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210711231359/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711231750/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/flow/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711235125/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210621/k10013095001000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711233304/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/workplace.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711230618/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210711/k10013133021000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711232949/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210621/k10013095451000.html

Beginning July 8, as an extension of the occupational and universities group for vaccination, the Tokyo Chamber of Commerce and Industry in cooperation with the Medical Association of Tokyo begin innoculating employees of small to mid-sized companies. Mass inoculation at this site will be given daily until the end of September.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210711233546/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210708/k10013126881000.html

Vaccinations continue at occupational sites for universities and companies that have submitted applications for workplace vaccination. 2000 universities/companies will have begun incoluations by the end of the week, with another 400 scheduled shortly begin. The remaining ~2600 workplaces are scheduled for vaccinations to begin in August.  This is in addition to high risk medical workers and those age 65+ that can already access vaccination. To incentivize quicker vaccinations, medical professional and institutions will be provided 100,000 yen per day if 50 inoculations or more are conducted per day; 100 inoculations or more in a week for 4 weeks receive 2000 yen per; 150 incoulations receive an additional 3000 yen. The country continues to roll out covid-19 vaccine and more information is released to the media outlet as we move forward in time. Kazakhstan citizens receive free vaccination and vaccination is voluntary in the country. The vaccine currently used in Kazakhstan is the Sputnik V vaccine, which is contraindicated for children under 18. The following groups of key workers will be vaccinated at the first stage: healthcare workers of, infectious diseases hospitals, ambulance, intensive care units, emergency hospitals, hospital admissions and sanitary and epidemiological service.     https://archive.is/h64OJ

Sputnik V consists of 2 stages. Currently, about 28,388 people received the vaccine stage 1, and about 14933 people received the vaccine stage 2. Now, only key workers are receiving vaccines. It is planned to vaccinate vulnerable people from April 1.  Link: https://archive.vn/VpOYW

As of March 31, more than 173 thousand people in Kazakhstan received at least one dose of the Russian Sputnik V vaccine. First of all, doctors, key workers - police officers, teachers, who are in contact with a large number of people, have been vaccinated. From April, the government is planning to start vaccinating elderly people.     Kazakhstan launched local production of the Russia-developed vaccine (Sputnik V) in December 2020 and started voluntary vaccination of the local population on February 1. The authorities plan to vaccinate six million people (about one third of the population) free of charge by end-2021. The first stage vaccination is expected to cover groups with high risk exposure, including doctors, teachers, and law enforcement workers. In addition, a locally developed vaccine (QazCovid-in) and the vaccine developed by Pfizer/BioNTech are expected to be available later in the year. Mass vaccination is expected to start after priority groups complete vaccination, likely in May. The authorities are also conducting an awareness campaign about vaccination, including recent statements by the President to counter misinformation about the vaccines.  Links: https://archive.vn/W1l7I https://archive.vn/Eau3N https://archive.vn/IG3zg

Kenya rolled out vaccines in early March after received the first vaccines from the COVID-19 Vaccines Global Access facility – COVAX.  'The current vaccination plan only covers 30% of the population as this is what the government has been able to secure. Once more doses and funds become available, they will expand the target.  Healthcare workers in 47 counties are among those who will get the jab first. Frontline workers, including security personnel and teachers, are also on the priority list. [Healthcare worker and frontline workers are both counted as 'Key workers] ...  Vaccine rollout will be done in three phases. The first involves 1.25 million people and runs between now and June 2021.'    https://archive.vn/Zm4XU

'Kenya has offered free COVID-19 vaccines to all diplomats based there, including thousands of United Nations staff, even though it has not completed inoculating its own health workers, other frontline staff or elderly, drawing criticism from local medics.  ...  The government note said vaccinations would begin on March 23 and only accredited diplomats and their families were eligible.'    https://archive.vn/O6H7H
'NAIROBI (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Kenya will let private hospitals charge for COVID-19 vaccinations and will not set a price limit on their cost...'    https://archive.vn/QRxBD

AstraZeneca Vaccine A:  The country is vaccinating after receiving its first batch of vaccines in march 2021. The country is prioritizing health workers and essential personnel including security agents. A,C - Key workers, Elderly Groups  Astra Zeneca    ***Discussion to acquire the Pfizer and Johnson&Johnson vaccines are underway***    The vaccine is first being rolled out to key workers, with the addition of the diplomatic community receiving doses as well.  There is evidence that there were changes to the initial plan within the first few weeks of the campaign rollout to also include the elderly in the first phase.    As the coding only requires to fo focus on the 3 groups, only "2 groups" were chosen based on the available options.  _________________      Quote (1):  "Kenya’s Ministry of Health has already launched its campaign and kicked off its deployment plan for the vaccines which are prioritized for frontline health workers and essential staff including security personnel."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20210425160440/https://www.afro.who.int/news/kenya-receives-covid-19-vaccines-and-launches-landmark-national-campaign  __________________    Quote (2):  "The plan outlined by the Ministry of Health involved three phases, the last two of which were to run concurrently. In phase one, between February and June 2021, 1.25 million health workers, security and immigration officials would be vaccinated. In phases two and three, from July 2021 to June 2022, nearly 10 million over-50s and over-18s with underlying health conditions and five million of those considered vulnerable, such as those in informal settlements, would be immunised."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20210425161648/https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2021/4/3/what-is-going-wrong-with-kenyas-covid-19-vaccine-drive  __________________    Quote (3):  "NAIROBI (Reuters) - Kenya has offered free COVID-19 vaccines to all diplomats based there, including thousands of United Nations staff, even though it has not completed inoculating its own health workers, other frontline staff or elderly, drawing criticism from local medics."    Link (3): http://archive.today/2021.04.25-161314/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-kenya-idUSKBN2BC0LH  _________________    Quote (4):  "Kenya’s first phase is meant to run until the end of June 2021. The initial plan was to vaccinate high priority groups, such as frontline healthcare workers. A few weeks into the rollout, the target group was expanded to include all Kenyans older than 58 years. This expanded the original target from 1.25 million people to about 3.2 million in the same time period."    Link (4): http://web.archive.org/web/20210425162601/https://theconversation.com/kenyas-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-has-got-off-to-a-slow-start-the-gaps-and-how-to-fix-them-158477  _________________    Quote (5):  "Kenya’s ministry of health on Monday announced that it will starting immediately prioritize persons aged above 58 years in the ongoing COVID-19 mass vaccination drive."    Link (5): http://archive.today/2021.04.25-162808/https://africa.cgtn.com/2021/03/25/kenya-to-prioritize-persons-aged-over-58-years-in-vaccination-drive/  _________________    Quote (6):  "Health Cabinet Secretary Mutahi Kagwe has said  the government was pursuing acquisition of one million doses of  vaccines each from  Pfizer as well as Johnson and Johnson respectively to supplement the Astrazeneca vaccines."    Link (6): http://web.archive.org/web/20210425161512/https://www.health.go.ke/kenya-to-acquire-pfizer-johnson-and-johnson-vaccines-says-cs-kagwe/

To date, there has been no news seen of vaccination campaigns actually taking place, although announcements have been made that doses have been receided through GAVI and are planned for a March 2021 campaign; with morse doses from Russia and China in the pipeline.    ____________________________________  Quote from linked article 1:  "COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Has the government of the Kyrgyz Republic approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  No"    Web archived link 1:  http://archive.today/2021.03.07-133200/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  _____________________________________    Quote from linked article 2:  "BISHKEK, Feb. 10 (Xinhua) -- A COVID-19 vaccination campaign will begin in Kyrgyzstan on March 1, the country's Health Minister Alymkadyr Beishenaliev said on Wednesday.    Speaking on state radio, the minister said that 504,000 doses of AstraZeneca vaccine will arrive in Kyrgyzstan in late February under COVAX, a global initiative to ensure quick and equal access to vaccines against COVID-19.    Beishenaliev said that in order for life to return to normal, it is necessary to vaccinate at least 70-80 percent of the population.    "We have developed a national vaccination program. According to the program, first of all, doctors, teachers, border guards will be vaccinated, that is, those persons who are in direct contact with large masses of people," Beishenaliev noted.    The minister also said that negotiations are underway to secure Russian and Chinese vaccines.    "To date, we have ordered 500,000 doses of the Russian vaccine. The Foreign Ministry is also working with China on the supply of vaccines,"    Web archived link 1:  http://archive.today/2021.03.07-142344/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2021-02/10/c_139735603.htm

A,C (AstraZeneca): Vaccination campaign for elderly people over 60 years old began March 23. Ministry of Health will look for strategic ways to administer the remaining 110,000 doses of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccines to the elderly. The vaccines are to be provided to senior citizens in each of Phnom Penh’s 14 districts, an act also aimed to prevent them from contracting the virus while going to the usually crowded designated hospitals.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419015209/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50829110/drive-to-protect-elderly-15-day-vaccination-campaign-begins-in-earnest/

A,B,C (Sinovax, Sinopharm, AstraZeneca): The first day of Sinovax vaccination campaign begins April 1 after receiving 1.5 million doses from China. People considered as vulnerable and front liners are still prioritised in the vaccination campaign. Among the priority groups are health workers, journalists, police and military personnel, government officials and factory workers. Priority campaign for the elderly began March 23.  Currently, Cambodia has three kinds of vaccines in Sinopharm, AstraZeneca/SII (COVISHIELD), and Sinovax.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419014153/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50833455/nearly-20000-inoculated-on-the-first-day-of-sinovac-vaccination-campaign/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419014646/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50834563/some-140000-people-get-sinovac-vaccines/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419015209/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50829110/drive-to-protect-elderly-15-day-vaccination-campaign-begins-in-earnest/

A,B,C (Sinovax, AstraZeneca, Sinopharm): As of April 17, more than 1.24 million people have been vaccinated against COVID-19 since the first shots were given on February 10.  Priority groups continue to be the elderly, the vulnerable, and frontliners including health workers, journalists, police and military personnel, government officials and factory workers.  The vaccines delivered are Sinopharm – 1.3 million doses, Sinovac 1.5 million doses and Astra Zenecca through the Covax initiative, 324,000 doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419021414/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50840072/vaccinations-for-covid-19-suspended-for-three-days-from-today-to-monday-resumes-on-tuesday/

Cambodia will be administering the second dose of Sinovac vaccinations from April 24 to April 30 for people living in Tuol Kork district. They will be able to receive their second dose without having to cross district boundaries. Priority groups continue to be the elderly, the vulnerable, and frontliners including health workers, journalists, police and military personnel, government officials and factory workers.  The National Committee for COVID-19 Vaccination has also asked local authorities to list the names of anyone living in a Red Zone waiting for their second dose to prepare a vaccination programme for them.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210427055613/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50844214/new-location-for-vaccines-in-toul-kork-district/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419021414/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50840072/vaccinations-for-covid-19-suspended-for-three-days-from-today-to-monday-resumes-on-tuesday/

(Sinovax, AstraZeneca, Sinopharm): Beginning May 1, the government of Cambodia has begun a targeted mass vaccination campaign for all adults within designated "Red Zones" within Phnom Penh. This vaccination effort is to prevent serious community transmission of COVID-19. Vaccinations will continue to include all residents of Phnom Penh and Kandal province during May and June.  In addition, other priority groups continue to be the elderly, the vulnerable, and frontliners including health workers, journalists, police and military personnel, government officials and factory workers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504020749/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50848400/large-scale-covid-19-vaccination-campaign-for-red-zone-will-start-may-1st/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504021301/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50848724/revealed-vaccination-centres-in-the-four-red-zones-of-phnom-penh/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504021318/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50849863/pm-says-phnom-penh-and-kandal-vaccinations-will-be-done-by-june/

(AstraZeneca, Sinopharm, Sinovac): On May 5, Prime Minister of Cambodia orders the army to assist in the complete vaccination of all individuals within designated Red Zones with priority for the elderly, those living with disabilities, and monks. Second doses are scheduled to be administered without delays.  In addition, other priority groups outside of Red Zones continue to be the elderly, the vulnerable, and frontliners including health workers, journalists, police and military personnel, government officials and factory workers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510235023/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50851598/prime-minister-hun-sen-orders-complete-vaccination-of-all-people-eligible-in-red-zones-beyond-the-original-520000-estimates/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510235405/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50852110/vaccine-priority-for-elderly-disabled-and-monks-in-red-zones/

(Sinopharm, Sinovac, and AstraZeneca.)  On 11 April 2021, the Royal Government of Cambodia (RGC) issued a Sub-decree on mandatory COVID-19 vaccination for:  o civil servants and all kinds of armed forces personnel  o citizens who hold public office and public officials at legislative bodies including other officials in the judiciary  o individuals based on their professions and infection risks as determined by MOH.  From May 2021, vaccination is accelerated in Phnom Penh, especially focusing on all residents living in high risk areas categorized as ‘Red Zone’.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210518001500/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/countries/cambodia/covid-19/covid-19-joint-who-moh-sitrep-44.pdf

(Sinopharm, Sinovac, and AstraZeneca): As of 31 May 2021, a total of 2,625,338 and 1,988,224 target individuals received the first dose and second dose of the COVID-19 vaccine, respectively. The coverage among the total target population for the first dose is 26%, and for the second dose is 15.6%. The proportion of vaccine coverage in females for the first dose is 47% and for the second dose is 46%. From 1 May 2021 to 31 May 2021, a total of 927,339 individuals (female: 494,244,53%) received the first dose and 671,686 (female: 352,486, 52%) received the second dose through the mass vaccination campaign in Red Zone in Phnom Penh.  The vaccination programme in Cambodia has been carried out using a “blooming flower” strategy by administering vaccines from the core outbreak areas, where all adults in hotspots are heavily prioritized for vaccinations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607203854/https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50864716/vaccination-masterplan-will-be-strictly-abided-to-says-pm-hun-sen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607201546/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/countries/cambodia/covid-19/covid-19-joint-who-moh-sitrep-48.pdf?sfvrsn=825e1c54_5&download=true

Arrival of first shipment of 12,000 Astrazeneca vaccines on 25th May 2021    On Tuesday, 25 May, Kiribati received 12,000 doses of the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine from the global COVAX facility. Another 12,000 batches of doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine is expected to arrive in the country within a month.    • These initial batches of vaccinations are catered only for 20% of the population covering essential and frontline workers as well as the most vulnerable, like elders and those with medical conditions. Groups: A,B,C  Vaccine: AstraZeneca    Arrival of first shipment of 12,000 Astrazeneca vaccines on 25th May 2021    On Tuesday, 25 May, Kiribati received 12,000 doses of the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine from the global COVAX facility. Another 12,000 batches of doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine is expected to arrive in the country within a month.    • These initial batches of vaccinations are catered only for 20% of the population covering essential and frontline workers as well as the most vulnerable, like elders and those with medical conditions.    However, the rollout of the recently arrived vaccinations started Wednesday, 26 May with Dr. Tabutoa Eria, championing the vaccination program by being the first person in the country to get vaccinated.    • An official government launch of the COVID-19 vaccine will be held at the end of this week (Friday, 28 May) at the Parliament premises in Ambo.    • In an interview with Radio New Zealand earlier this month, Health Minister Dr. Itinteang said the Kiribati government has also secured 10,000 doses of Sinopharm, due to arrive in the country at the next available flight. On December 8th, the Korean government secures up to 44 million vaccines for COVID-19. The government announced that it will pre-purchase overseas vaccines for up to 44 million people through COVAX Facility (for about 10 million people) and global vaccine companies (for about 34 million people). The pre-purchased vaccine is expected to be introduced in stages from the first quarter of 2021 (February and March); however, the later distribution may vary depending on ongoing clinical trial results and close monitoring.     The elderly, vulnerable groups, and essential service personnel such as health care professionals  will be the first in line to receive the vaccine as they account for about 36 million people.    https://archive.vn/KOalT

"The government concluded the contract for the Pfizer and Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, securing an additional 2 million doses of 86 million doses.  ...  Pre-purchased vaccines are expected to be introduced in stages from the first quarter of '21 (February to March), and vaccinations will be promoted in stages without delay compared to other countries. The Janssen vaccine will be introduced in the second quarter of next year, and the Pfizer vaccine will be introduced in the third quarter of next year."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201226043530/http://ncov.mohw.go.kr/tcmBoardView.do?brdId=3&brdGubun=31&dataGubun=&ncvContSeq=4493&contSeq=4493&board_id=312&gubun=BDJ

The Kuwaiti Ministry of Health webpage (https://www.moh.gov.kw) allows residents of Kuwait, including U.S. citizen residents, to pre-register for the COVID-19 vaccine by clicking on “COVID-19 Vaccination Pre-Registration.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301195154/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    The disparity in Kuwait’s campaign has triggered an online debate between those nationals defending the policy and outraged expatriates and Kuwaitis who feel the pro-citizen push is flavored by racism.    There were signs of a shift on Wednesday, with expat residents of Kuwait saying that more elderly foreigners were seen at inoculation centers.  An initially slow vaccination program gained momentum with the opening of more inoculation centers and the arrival of doses made by Oxford University/AstraZeneca. Kuwait says it’s prioritizing all frontline workers and those in high-risk groups.  https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=e6ddafd0-7acb-11eb-aab9-4d3d4aa651bf&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0wMi0xOC9rdXdhaXQtcHV0cy1jaXRpemVucy1iZWZvcmUtZXhwYXRzLWFzLXZhY2NpbmUtcHVzaC1zdGlycy1hbmdlcg==    Distributed vaccine  As the fifth shipment of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine arrived in Kuwait this week, the total number of doses received reached 550,000, with 150,000 in the first shipment and 100,000 in every other shipment following, a source told Al Jarida.    The Pfizer vaccine is being prioritized for those above the age of 65 and between the ages of 16-17, as only those above the age of 18 can receive the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine. https://web.archive.org/web/20210301202818/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/kuwait/covid-19-no-deaths-from-taking-vaccine-says-kuwait-ministry-of-health-1.77489540    Ministry of Health yesterday started providing COVID-19 vaccination for residents at the Kuwait Vaccination Center in Mishref particularly for the elderly and those suffering from chronic and immunological diseases, as these groups are most at risk of the COVID-19 infection and the occurrence of complications.

Has the government of Kuwait approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes.  The Kuwaiti Ministry of Health webpage (https://www.moh.gov.kw) allows residents of Kuwait, including U.S. citizen residents, to pre-register for the COVID-19 vaccine by clicking on “COVID-19 Vaccination Pre-Registration.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314213621/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    By mid-February 2021, around 119,000 Kuwaitis but only 18,000 migrant workers had been vaccinated, a Bloomberg report revealed. "We feel like we have the right to be vaccinated too, because we are here to serve them [the Kuwaitis]. We mostly work in the front line, in restaurants, to deliver food, drive taxis, so being vaccinated is something like protection," Krishna told me.    Kuwait’s citizen-first approach to public policy, of which the discriminatory vaccination campaign is the latest symbol, underlines a barely concealed de facto caste system that is the cornerstone of modern Gulf economies. https://web.archive.org/web/20210315194914/https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/.premium-vaccine-nationalism-in-the-gulf-kuwait-s-cruel-covid-caste-system-1.9617911

No change in policy.    Pfizer, Moderna and Oxford-AstraZeneca    Around 500,000 people have received vaccination since an inoculation campaign started in the country in December. Nearly 1 million citizens and expatriates in Kuwait have registered to get vaccinated against COVID-19, and earlier this month, Minister of Health Dr Basel Al Sabah said that 2 million people are expected to be vaccinated by September.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210325181251/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/kuwait/kuwait-1m-register-to-get-covid-19-vaccine-1.1616506428765

KUWAIT CITY, May 9 (Xinhua) -- Kuwait launched on Sunday the second phase of the COVID-19 field vaccination campaign that provides vaccines for workers of shopping malls in the country.    In the first phase of the field vaccination campaign, more than 34,758 employees who have direct contact with the public have received vaccine through this service, he explained, noting they are from several bodies such as cooperative societies, mosques, banking sector, food factories, cinemas and others. When Kuwait’s vaccination registration site went live in December, authorities declared that health-care workers, older adults and those with underlying conditions would be first in line.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515165452/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2021-05/09/c_139934430.htm    https://web.archive.org/web/20210525023812/https://www.newindianexpress.com/world/2021/apr/04/expats-struggle-to-get-coronavirusvaccines-in-kuwait-citizens-come-first-2285668.html

The vaccination campaign started on December 27. On May 30, Kuwait inaugurated the first drive-through vaccination center with a capacity of 5,000 cars per day. As of early June, about 65 percent population has received at least one dose of the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210713091800/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Lao PDR today received its first shipment of COVID-19 vaccine doses through the COVAX facility, a partnership between the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI), Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, UNICEF and the World Health Organisation  The shipment consists of 132,000 doses of the AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine, manufactured by the Serum Institute of India (SII), and was shipped by air to the Wattay International Airport in Vientiane from Pune, India. This batch of AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccines is the first of the total of 480,000 doses being planned for delivery to Lao PDR via the COVAX initiative this year to cover about 20 percent of the total population.  According the country’s National Deployment and Vaccination Plan (NVDP), this initial batch of AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccines will be used by the Government of Lao PDR to first immunise priority groups in the country who are at greater risk of exposure to COVID-19 and those who are most likely to develop severe symptoms from infection.    This includes frontline healthcare workers, older adults above the age of 60 and people with underlying health conditions. Some essential workers will also be prioritised based on the nature of the job and high-risk of exposure to COVID-19 such as workers at points of entry and in quarantine centres.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210405183726/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-vaccines-shipped-by-covax-facility-arrive-in-lao-pdr/

The government has begun vaccinating the most vulnerable and at-risk groups in a step towards ending the acute phase of the Covid-19 pandemic.  The national rollout of COVAX-supported vaccines began at Mittaphab Hospital in Vientiane on Friday (April 2).  The vaccines were received on March 20 and were provided by the COVAX Facility, a partnership between the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations, Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, UNICEF, and the World Health Organisation (WHO).  The shipment consisted of 132,000 doses of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine manufactured by the Serum Institute of India.  This shipment is the first of Laos’ initial allocation of 480,000 doses. COVAX aspires to provide enough vaccine to supply at least 20 percent of the population this year, according to a press release from UNICEF.   the priority groups comprise healthcare workers, adults above the age of 60, and people with underlying health conditions.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210412183244/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/04/05/laos-mass-rollout-of-covid-19-vaccine-gets-underway
Vaccine open for foreigner as well.    US Web Archived for Embassy: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412182114/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A,B,C (AstraZeneca, Sinopharm): Health authorities in Laos have launched an online registration programme for Covid-19 vaccinations aimed at priority groups. According to an announcement by the Centre of Information and Education for Health, residents of Vientiane and foreign citizens will be able to register online for Covid-19 vaccinations. The AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine and Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine will be given to priority groups such as medical personnel and individuals in at-risk groups, as well as people who are 60 years old or above. After medical personnel, individuals with chronic illnesses, such as respiratory or cardiovascular disease, asthma, obesity, immunodeficiency, and others, are expected to receive the vaccine first.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426202227/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/04/24/authorities-open-online-registration-for-covid-19-vaccinations-in-laos

Health authorities in Laos have launched an online registration programme for Covid-19 vaccinations aimed at priority groups.    Healthcare workers Those at high risk of acquiring and transmitting infection including medical staff from the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Defense, Ministry of Public Security, laboratory staff, pharmacists, village health volunteers, health workers at private health facilities and medical students.  Older adults (=60 years old) People aged 60 years or above. The risk for severe illness and death from COVID-19 substantially increases with age, with older adults at highest risk.  People with underlying health conditions Those with underlying health conditions including lung or heart disease, diabetes, obesity, conditions that affect the immune system, and others.  Essential workers This group includes workers considered essential for maintaining the economy and providing services such as border control officers, security forces, teachers, civil servants, judges, transport, logistics, energy, mining, utilities, finance, communications, customs, and others.  Essential travelers Those currently in Lao PDR at risk of acquiring infection outside the home country and reintroducing infection upon return to home country. This group includes migrant workers, international students, business people, diplomats, international organizations, aid workers, and others.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517173341/https://vaccinatelaos.la/index-en.html

https://archive.vn/YVFlR    Hasan: The Vaccination Campaign is Being Implemented Systematically     A year after the pandemic, we succeeded in developing the public health sector in an unprecedented      manner, said Dr. Hamad Hassan, minister of public health in the caretaker government, said that "the vaccination campaign proved a week after its launch that it is being implemented in a good and systematic form, despite some breaches that are being dealt with quickly in some centres."  "The success rate on the national registration platform is rapidly rising and adjusted according to the need, such as rounding up the appointments of people who are immediately following their appointments to those who may miss the vaccination, which will ensure that no vaccine dose is  lost."  "The bumps we experienced in the face of the pandemic were very difficult, especially the epidemic, which resulted from the easing of the holidays and the repercussions of the port explosion," Hassan told Al-Mayadeen tv, marking the one-year anniversary of the Corona virus  outbreak. "The vaccine has provided an additional factor that works in response to the epidemic in addition to preventive behaviour," he said.  "In the coming period, there will be multiple vaccines, which will be free for the Lebanese," he said, stressing the adoption of the principles of justice and transparency.  "Lebanon will receive 250,000 Pfizer vaccines by the end of March, with shipments to continue until 2.1 million vaccines are reached," he said.  "Lebanon has started quick talks with the company to secure more of this vaccine, which has been proven effective by research," he  said.  He continued: "The Ministry of Health had booked two million and 555,000 doses with the Kovacs platform, and the receipt of 1.5 million vaccines from AstraZeneca was finally signed.  As for the Russian vaccine, contrary to what is rumored, we went to the embassy early last September with a book to get the vaccine and secure a donation and negotiations are continuing until now, and the ministry has also begun to study the Chinese vaccine file after completing the documents."  "The import of the Russian vaccine through the Ministry of Public Health ensures that sensitive shipping conditions are secured at temperatures below 18 degrees, or through a tripartite agreement that will provide community initiatives with more vaccines," he  said.  The minister of health was surprised by the "continued media confusion over the performance of the Ministry of Public Health, such as the rumor that the Pfizer vaccine will not be handed over to Lebanon for certain political reasons, or that the Ministry of Health was competent in distributing equipment and equipment to hospitals and much more misinformation."        "The ministry responds to repeated allegations of compliance with the plans and the serious performance on the ground that reflects the positives of all Lebanese, and the reality is that pfizer's vaccine has arrived on its stated dates in Lebanon, and the equipment has been distributed to all hospitals in all regions without discrimination, and international institutions are dealing with confidence and effectiveness with the ministry despite attempts by some to harm this relationship," he  said.  "One year after the pandemic, the public health sector's horizon looks different," Hassan  said. This sector has been supported in an orderly, systematic and unprecedented manner in terms of equipping government hospitals with intensive care rooms and state-of-the-art equipment and equipment. "These hospitals have won the confidence of the Lebanese in their various segments and classes."

The minister of health was surprised by the "continued media confusion over the performance of the Ministry of Public Health, such as the rumor that the Pfizer vaccine will not be handed over to Lebanon for certain political reasons, or that the Ministry of Health was competent in distributing equipment and equipment to hospitals and much more misinformation."        "The ministry responds to repeated allegations of compliance with the plans and the serious performance on the ground that reflects the positives of all Lebanese, and the reality is that pfizer's vaccine has arrived on its stated dates in Lebanon, and the equipment has been distributed to all hospitals in all regions without discrimination, and international institutions are dealing with confidence and effectiveness with the ministry despite attempts by some to harm this relationship," he  said.  "One year after the pandemic, the public health sector's horizon looks different," Hassan  said. This sector has been supported in an orderly, systematic and unprecedented manner in terms of equipping government hospitals with intensive care rooms and state-of-the-art equipment and equipment. "These hospitals have won the confidence of the Lebanese in their various segments and classes."

After receipt of 96,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine, through the COVAX facility, Liberia, on April 1, 2021, joined many countries to officially launch the vaccination campaign against COVID-19. Vaccines are available to the frontline workers and the most vulnerable (A and B groups).  The vaccines are now deployed at eight sites in Montserrado and Margibi counties including; the Number 14 Military hospital, JFK memorial hospital, Catholic hospital, Redemption and SOS Hospitals among others. The vaccines will subsequently be rolled out to the others counties in the coming days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210409171516/https://www.afro.who.int/news/liberia-launches-vaccination-against-covid-19

Astrazeneca  A,B  After receipt of 96,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine, through the COVAX facility, Liberia, on 1st April 2021, joined many countries to officially launch the vaccination campaign against COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.afro.who.int/news/liberia-launches-vaccination-against-covid-19   Vaccines are available to the frontline workers and the most vulnerable (A and B groups). The vaccines are now deployed at eight sites in Montserrado and Margibi counties including; the Number 14 Military hospital, JFK memorial hospital, Catholic hospital, Redemption and SOS Hospitals among others. The vaccines will subsequently be rolled out to the others counties in the coming days.  Liberia has identified its 20 per cent priority population to be targeted. The priority group includes health care workers, elderly people (60+), people with co-morbidities, refugees and other essential workers who cannot social distance due to the work they performed.   https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.unicef.org/liberia/press-releases/ministry-health-starts-vaccination-campaign-against-covid19-0

Liberia has received 96,000 AstraZeneca vaccines via the COVAX initiative. A national COVID-19 vaccination campaign has commenced with three priority phases.    Phase 1: legislators; executive staff; judges; diplomatic missions; UN staff; traditional leaders; religious leaders; marketeers; healthcare workers.    Phase 2: people aged over 60 or with co-morbidities.    Phase 3: others, including teachers, military, immigration, police, hospitality sector, journalists. Foreign residents are eligible for vaccination.    The Ministry of Health has identified eight healthcare facilities in Monrovia where the vaccine will be administered: John F Kennedy Medical Center; Redemption Hospital; JDJ Memorial Hospital; 14 Military Hospital; St. Joseph’s Catholic Hospital; ELWA Hospital; SOS Clinic; and the UN Clinic. Mobile vaccine clinics are also available on request for groups of over 50 individuals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607202725/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liberia/coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.unicef.org/liberia/press-releases/ministry-health-starts-vaccination-campaign-against-covid19-0    http://web.archive.org/web/20210517214344/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liberia/coronavirus
no updates  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607202725/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liberia/coronavirus

TRIPOLI, April 17 (Xinhua) -- The Director of the National Center for Disease Control of Libya, Dadr Addin Annajar, on Saturday announced the start of the vaccination against COVID-19 in the capital Tripoli. Annajar revealed that Libya so far has received vaccines from China, Russia and other nations and will distribute them to different parts of the country via 450 vaccination centers. He also explained that vaccination priority will be for medical staff treating COVID-19 patients inside isolation units, followed by the elderly, those with chronic diseases, and then the health workers who do not deal with the infectious virus. Within a few weeks, a large number of people are expected to be vaccinated, Annajar added, confirming that around 500,000 people have already registered online to get the jabs.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210419130621/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/africa/2021-04/18/c_139887759.htm    Since, shots have not been administered yet, recording it as 0.

A,B,C:   Libya kicked off its coronavirus vaccine drive in the capital Tripoli on Saturday.    At some health centres, there were queues of people waiting for their shots.    Some 430 centres have been approved across the country.    Priority for the vaccines has been given to the elderly (C) and those with health conditions (B) and health care workers (A).    Libya is using a mix of vaccines, such as Russia's Sputnik jab, the Oxford-AstraZeneca and the Chinese Sinopharm vaccine.    Those over 70 would get the AstraZeneca jab while the Russian Sputnik V vaccine would be administered to medical personnel and those aged 50-60, the National Centre for Disease Control said.    A total of 400,000 doses have arrived in Libya so far.    Some of those vaccines have come through the global Covax programme.    The vaccines are currently stored in medical supply stores, with plans to distribute them across the country imminently.    The government has urged people to register for the jab.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510101746/https://www.africanews.com/2021/04/18/libya-kickstarts-coronavirus-vaccine-drive/

From 29th January, the Ministry of Health began vaccination program rolled out using the 500,000 COVISHEILD doses from India as a 'gift'. Since the start of vaccine campaign in Sri Lanka, made possible by the gifting of vaccines by India, 500,000 citizens have been vaccinated with the 'Made in India' COVISHIELD vaccine. The vaccine was given to key workers. Since the arrival of the next 500,000 doses (also COVISHEILD) on 25th February, the vaccine has now been rolled out into public where citizens above the age of 30 are receiving the jab. This has been focused in the Western Province primarily given that this is a current 'hotspot' for the country. (no availability of updated information regarding which specific groups are now currently getting the vaccine)     Source: https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/asiapacific/2021-03/02/c_139778159.htm

COVID-19 vaccines are available in Sri Lanka to citizens and resident visa holders. Six vaccination centers have been set up in Colombo for the public to get vaccinated. Colombo residents need to contact their area Ministry of Health officer or Public Health Inspector’s office and register for the vaccine, or they can go to the nearest centre and wait to be vaccinated.    Astra Zeneca and Sinopharm are widely in use (Sri Lanka received 600,000 doses of Sinopharm from China as a donation on 31st of March)     Pfizer has now been approved for emergency use - 5 million doses will be imported in the near future     Sputnik was first administered on the 6th of May - Sri Lanka received 15,000 doses to begin with, and 13 million are to be expected in the near future     See here:   https://archive.ph/OEXv9  https://archive.ph/g7xTe  https://archive.ph/MgUqp

no change in policy, see here for vaccine updates: https://archive.ph/GZfpD    The government appears to be approaching the vaccine roll out by district:    The vaccination program implemented by the Ministry of Health to control Covid-19 and currently being carried out in Colombo, Gampaha and Kalutara districts of the Western Province will be conducted in Kandy, Kurunegala and Ratnapura districts after the Western Province, said Minister Pavithra Wanniarachchi.    Speaking to media, Minister of Health Pavithra Wanniarachchi said mostly infected Regional Health Medical Officer of Health areas in Kandy, Kurunegala and Ratnapura districts will be selected to provide the Covid-19 vaccination.    Speaking further Minister of Health said, “We are currently vaccinating only in the Western Province. We have fully vaccinated 100,000 people in the Western Province. About 13 million people are expected to be vaccinated nationwide to prevent the spread of the disease.”    see here: https://archive.ph/r3uIt     Additionally, The Government and the World Bank (WB) signed a $80.5 million additional financing agreement to help Sri Lanka access and distribute Covid-19 vaccines and to strengthen the country’s vaccination system and pandemic response. Lesotho received the first batch of AstraZeneca vaccines on 3 March 2021. The 36 000 doses enabled the government to roll out its mass vaccination programme a week later. King Letsie III and Prime Minister Moeketsi Majoro were among the first to vaccinated against the deadly virus which had infected 10 720 people and killed 316 by yesterday in Lesotho.  The vaccination campaign was then spread to essential workers such as health workers and media practitioners. The ministry also vaccinated the elderly and those with life-threatening conditions like HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis.  The latest donation will enable these groups to receive their second and final dose of the vaccine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614074521/https://allafrica.com/stories/202106100503.html

"A,B,C: AstraZeneca.  The second phase of the government's vaccination program started on June 16, 2021. ""Lesotho received the first batch of AstraZeneca vaccines on 3 March 2021. The 36 000 doses enabled the government to roll out its mass vaccination programme a week later.  After the government leaders were jabbed, the vaccination campaign was then spread to essential workers such as health workers and media practitioners. The ministry also vaccinated the elderly and those with life-threatening conditions like HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis.    These groups will receive their second and final doses of the vaccines during the second phase of the vaccination programme.""    ""Those who have not received the first jabs will have to wait until after we have received a different vaccine for the purpose,"" she added.  This was in reference to the government's plans to switch to the Johnson & Johnson vaccines. Health Minister Sekatle recently said they would procure Johnson & Johnson vaccines because ""they present less logistical challenges as people only have to be vaccinated once"".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210711230329/https://allafrica.com/stories/202106160775.html"

All Lithuanian residents may be vaccinated, provided that they:  "- are entitled to personal health care services paid from the Compulsory Health Insurance Fund or from the State budget;  - citizens of the Member States of the European Union and the European Free Trade Association and their family members, who have come to live in Lithuania for the period exceeding 3 months in 6 months, and who have been granted the right to reside in Lithuania;  - foreign citizens and persons without citizenship, to whom the Lithuanian residence permit has been issued;  - persons, to whom the national visa has been issued;  - persons accredited and residing in Lithuania;  - other persons who have to be vaccinated by the Government’s resolution." On November 30th, Luxembourg issued regulations for the distribution of the covid 19 vaccines. The first groups that will benefit from this vaccine are the elderly, identified as people that are 65 years or more, and the healthcare workers.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201213172111/https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Overview-of-EU_EEA-UK-vaccination-deployment-plans.pdf

The first people to be vaccinated are health professionals and staff in hospitals, as well as ambulance drivers, staff in residential care facilities for the elderly and in care and support networks, and people living in these facilities. On Thursday 28 and 29 December, around 800 people from the hospital sector will be vaccinated, and 200 people per hospital establishment for acute treatments respectively. On Wednesday 30 December, staff from senior citizens' homes will be vaccinated - with an additional 400 vaccinations planned. In addition, paramedics transporting COVID-19 patients were offered vaccination during these three days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103233531/https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/12-decembre/28-vaccin-covid.html

Anyone who is 18 and above (12 and above for messenger RNA vaccines) have the opportunity, under certain conditions, to register online on one of the waiting lists and express their interest in being voluntarily vaccinated against COVID-19. Anyone aged 18 or older can register to be vaccinated with Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca), Janssen (J&J), or an mRNA vaccine (Pfizer or Moderna). A:    The first vaccination rooms in Latvia started operating on December 28, 2020. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) and the European Commission (EC) have approved the quality, safety and efficacy of the first two Covid-19 vaccines. These are the vaccine Comirnaty manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and the vaccine manufactured by Moderna.      The vaccine will first be given to medical staff working with Covid-19 patients and to the staff of the Emergency Medical Service (EMS). After that, other vaccines will be gradually delivered to Latvia. The first vaccines will be given to healthcare workers working with Covid-19 patients in hospitals and to the Emergency Medical Service.     It is planned that all other residents of Latvia will be able to be vaccinated starting from the second quarter of 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233236/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/vaccine  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233533/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/kad-vakcinas-bus-pieejamas-latvija

Macau officials announced on Monday (25 January) edition of the regular press conference of the Novel Coronavirus Response and Coordination Centre: "vaccination would be free-of-charge to Macao ID holders, non-resident workers, and non-locals studying in Macao’s tertiary education institutions, according to a preliminary plan for such effort. Vaccination would be on a voluntary basis."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210201041736/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N21AYwk9XC;jsessionid=7E507A4D36F69599F372237A7381E53A.app02?0&topic=Novel_Coronavirus
The vaccination was not rolled out until 9 Feb.  https://archive.vn/q4RAP

First stage of vaccination in Macao began on 9 Feb is available to three prioritized groups, including frontline government workers and those who inevitably have to travel to high-risk areas.    More detail:  'Macau began rollout of Sinopharm vaccines on 9 Feburary.  The first batch of 100,000 mainland-made two-dose Sinopharm vaccines - chosen for the first phase of Macau's program that arrived on Saturday [i.e. 6 Feb] - can cover 50,000 people.  Vaccinations started for high-risk groups yesterday, including health-care workers and disciplinary officers.  "There will also be another brand of vaccines arriving in Macau at the end of this month citizens can choose the brand they want later."  Macau rolled out vaccinations from 9am yesterday [i.e. 9 Feb], with medical workers, police, firemen and customs officers among those receiving the shot.  Vaccinations are available to three prioritized groups, including frontline government workers and those who inevitably have to travel to high-risk areas.  The next stage of vaccination, to start on February 22, will be open to other Macau residents.  The jab will be free for all residents, non-local employees with work permits, students and prisoners. It will cost 250 patacas (HK$242) for non-residents.  People working in high-risk sectors, such as frozen and fresh food handlers, care home staff, transport workers, teachers, croupiers and government security officers, are also covered.'  https://archive.vn/q4RAP    The government encourages the residents to take the vaccine when available.  https://archive.vn/pJtvM

Morocco has announced a nationwide Covid-19 vaccination campaign. The campaign aims at covering 80 percent of Moroccan population over 18 years old (about 25 million people). The vaccination is expected to take place over a 3-month period, but it is not yet clear when it would start. Morocco has pre-ordered about 30 million Covid-19 vaccine doses for the vaccination campaign, and is developing partnerships to manufacture Covid-19 vaccines in Moroccan laboratories.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#M

Morocco's government seeks to vaccinate 80% of its adults, or 25 million people, as soon as the vaccines are approved by domestic regulators. Priority will go to medical staff and other front-line workers, as well as the elderly. Morocco has one of the most advanced vaccination plans in the region. The country has also reported the second-highest number of virus infections and deaths in Africa, after South Africa.    The Moroccan health minister said the government’s target is vaccinating 25 million of the country’s 36 million people, all free of charge, according to orders from King Mohammed VI.  Jabs in the arms have not yet started.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162307/https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/morocco-kick-mass-vaccination-plan-chinese-drug    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162312/https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/morocco-acquires-65-million-covid-19-vaccine-doses-from-china-uk

Morocco’s health ministry on Wednesday approved the COVID-19 vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and Oxford University for emergency use, Health Minister Khalid Ait Taleb said.    Morocco had announced it plans to launch a free vaccination campaign targeting 25 million people, or 80% of its population.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210117123703/https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-health-coronavirus-morocco/morocco-approves-astrazeneca-oxford-covid-19-vaccine-minister-idUSKBN29C0QA

No change in policy.    Morocco started a nationwide Covid-19 vaccination campaign on January 28, 2021. The campaign aims at covering 80 percent of Moroccan population over 18 years old (about 25 million people). The campaign is relying on Morocco's network of primary health care institutions and mobile clinics. Priority is given to citizens in the frontline such as health workers, authority agents, security forces, teachers, elders and people with underlying health conditions. "Initially, vaccinations will be available to senior residents aged 75 or over, living either in care homes or in the community, who have received a letter from the Government inviting them to contact the COVID-19 Call Centre"    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115170152/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/First-COVID-19-vaccination-in-Principality    In general:    Vaccines will become available gradually, and so the Prince’s Government has had to establish priorities to ensure that at-risk groups are at the front of the queue. These groups are:    -Elderly people living in care settings    -People aged over 75    -People aged 65–74    -People with underlying health conditions (obesity (BMI>30), particularly among younger people, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory disease, complex high blood pressure disorders, heart disease, type 1 or type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, recent history of cancer (within the last three years), solid organ transplant or haematopoietic stem cell transplant, Down’s syndrome, etc.)    -Healthcare workers, etcA    The vaccination campaign will therefore be rolled out in several phases to target each category of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165719/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/vaccination-procedure/

Preparations in anticipation of receiving vaccines continue, with the creation of the National Committee for the Coordination of Immunization Activities and a simulation exercise. It is expected that the first vaccines received will be in mid-February and include 24,570 doses of Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine and 264,000 doses of Oxford / AstraZeneca. As of 13 February, there is no evidence doses have been received.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210213211930/https://gov.md/sites/default/files/proiect_hotarire_cnesp_nr._44_din_09.02.2021_1.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213212305/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/02/12/21001071

A:  AstraZeneca    On 02 March, the first person was vaccinated with the AstraZeneca vaccine, donated by Romania to Moldova. According to the Ministry of Health, Labor and Social Protection, the first will be vaccinated doctors from intensive care and COVID departments. Subsequently, all employees in the medical system will benefit from the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308021525/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/02/21001591

The Pfizer vaccine is expected to arrive in mid-March to Moldova via COVAX.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308022834/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovan-government-holds-meeting-6 https://web.archive.org/web/20210308022524/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/03/21001643

A  Vaccines in use: AstraZeneca.   Pfizer-BioNTech will be used from 23 March.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322212503/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/19/21002088  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322194100/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/22/21002162

The vaccination will be extended (phase 2) for the following target groups: adults above 60 years,  people with comorbidities (high risk groups) and the people with comorbidities, aged between 18 and 60 years, for whom the COVID-19 poses a high risk of the serious forms and death.  Coding 1 group was kept, however, due to lack of vaccines.    https://archive.vn/UFBxH
A  vaccines in use: Astra Zeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech    http://web.archive.org/web/20210405162442/http://news.gov.md/news/2021/04/05/21002556

The third stage of vaccination begins with the immunisation of people in the following areas: processing, distribution and marketing of basic foods; water plants, water treatment, transportation and distribution; power plants, production and transmission of electricity; gas production, transmission and distribution units; units for the production, transport and distribution of medicines and medical devices; transport of people and goods. Also the third stage includes employees of the special telecommunications, radio and national television service; hotel and restaurant workers; hairdressers and employees of body maintenance centers; theater workers; bank employees, postal staff, representatives of religious denominations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210531142128/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/05/11/21003378

All people can get vaccinated. However, so far, 253,310 doses of vaccine have been administered, which means a vaccination rate of 6.3% - therefore not coded 5.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210531193920/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/05/19/21003569

As of May 18, vaccination appointments were made available to the general public. However, as of Jun 1 the vaccination rate among the general public was slightly below 10%. Moldova has only received 886,390 doses of vaccine and only 416,814  people have been vaccinated (therefore coding as a 3, since vaccination rate is not at least 20% of the target population).
