COVIDSHIELD vaccines have arrived in Madagascar.  The vaccination campaign is currently open to everyone over 18 years of age.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621150432/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

AstraZeneca/Covidshield vaccines are available to any individuals 18 and older while supplies are available.    From the U.S. Embassy in Madagascar on June 24:  However, Madagascar is awaiting additional doses and thus vaccination clinics are not running at this time.  When supply exists, the vaccination campaign is currently open to everyone over 18 years of age. The GOM expects a second shipment of vaccines to arrive in July to complete vaccination of those who received their first dose by June 18.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210702222513/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

"A,B,C: AstraZeneca, Covishield  While vaccination is open to everyone 18 and up, vaccination is currently on hold as Madagascar awaits additional doses. Vaccine hesitancy is also greatly affecting vaccination rates in the country.  ""COVISHIELD vaccines arrived in Madagascar and were distributed.  However, Madagascar is awaiting additional doses and thus vaccination clinics are not running at this time.  When supply exists, the vaccination campaign is currently open to everyone over 18 years of age. The GOM expects more shipments of vaccines, including COVISHIELD and Johnson & Johnson, to arrive in August. Information on how those vaccines will be distributed has not yet been made available.""  ""MAP’s next goal is to facilitate vaccination, says Manahira. But first, he is organizing surveys to see who in the Andavadoaka region, if anyone, is willing to get the vaccine. If enough people want a jab, the team will raise funds to hire a helicopter to bring in doses. But there hasn’t yet been enough interest. This seems to be a pattern around the country. Madagascar received 250,000 doses of AstraZeneca’s Covishield vaccine in May through the COVAX programme — an alliance of international organizations that aims to distribute vaccines to low- and middle-income countries — but health officials administered only 190,000 of the doses before they expired on 17 June, because not enough people turned up to receive them. Michel Saint-Lot, a representative of the development and humanitarian aid organization UNICEF Madagascar, anticipates another vaccine shipment from COVAX in August, which will be necessary for vaccinated individuals to get their second dose. “We’re confident these things can be overcome, and we’ll step up the campaign,” he says. “We hope the full government will join us to get the country immunized.”""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210725212859/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210726050147/https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-01933-9"

Mali received its first batch of vaccines against COVID-19 on 5th March, the first Sahel-Saharan country to receive shots through the COVAX initiative.  A plane carrying 396,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine landed in Bamako where President Bah N'Daw and Prime Minister Moctar Ouane were among those waiting:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322142507/https://reliefweb.int/report/mali/covid-19-vaccines-arrive-covax-facility-becomes-reality-mali

Mali's government says it has chosen to use the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in its plan to initially immunise 4.2 million people. The Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine is available through the COVAX Facility and according to the Malian Minister of Health, vaccines are initially being given to health personnel, people over 60 years of age, and people living with chronic diseases. https://web.archive.org/web/20210417161105/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

With no policy change currently, the Minister of Health and Social Development of government of Mali has announced that as of  April 6,2021 that they will be rolling out vaccination campaign against COVID 19 for Health care workers, elderly above 60 years of age and people with co-morbidities with in the district of Bamako. The web archive link shows the official website of the Minister of health and social development posted on date April 3,2021 containing the announcement made as of March 31st 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502084403/http://www.sante.gov.ml/index.php/actualites/item/6063-vaccin-contre-la-covid-19-la-vaccination-dans-tous-les-csref-et-cscom-a-partir-du-6-avril-2021

A:    The Pfizer-BioNtech vaccine arrived in Malta on 26th December 2020, with vaccinations of healthcare workers and frontliners starting on 27th December. People over the age of 85 will start receiving their inoculation letters from 7 January. They will be given the date and time for their first and second shots. Hence for now, only one group has vaccine access.    Source: /web/20201228065246/https://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2020-12-26/local-news/First-batch-of-Covid-19-vaccines-arrive-in-Malta-6736229721

A, C:    After starting vaccinating Healthcare workers, on 1st January 2021, Malta started vaccinating also people in old people's homes.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210101183322/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/woman-94-becomes-first-elderly-person-to-be-vaccinated-against-covid.842265
A,C  Pfizer, Moderna
Pfizer, Moderna

From Wednesday 27th January 2020, Malta started vaccinating Clinically vulnerable groups, together with Key workers and elderly groups. Vaccines being used are Pfizer and Moderna jabs.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201071312/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/cancer-patients-to-start-receiving-covid-19-vaccine-from-wednesday.847161

As from 10th April 2021, The Maltese government announced that the vaccine programme is now extended. Apart from the three groups of people who are already being administered the vaccine (Key workers, clinically vulnerable groups, elderly groups), the vaccine is now broadly available to anyone who wishes to be vaccinated. For now this is limited to those aged over 50. This will be then extended to younger individuals.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411070025/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/chris-fearne-covid-19-vaccines-vaccination-strategy-malta-health.863757

From Monday 17th May, any individuals who are over 16 and willing to take the vaccine may register and receive the vaccine.    Vaccines being administered: Pfizer, Moderna, Astrazeneca, Johnson and Johnson    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517070939/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/109580/people_aged_16_and_over_can_register_for_covid19_vaccine_from_monday

A- Key workers, B- Clinically vulnerable groups  Myanmar has received its free first batch of Covishield, AstraZeneca’s vaccine manufactured by the Serum Institute of India. More than 110000 Healthcare workers and volunteers will be vaccinated as part of the initial phase.   This will be followed by the government official and the elderly over the age of 65.   About 20 percent of the 54.4 million population in Myanmar will be given vaccines under the global Covax affordable medicines program and the Global Alliance for Vaccine and Immunisation.The first batch of COVID-19 vaccine under the World Health Organization’s Covax program will arrive in late February, according to the health ministry.    **Despite the military coup, Myanmar’s Ministry of Health and Sports says it is continuing with its COVID-19 vaccination program.  The ministry’s permanent secretary, Dr. Thet Khaing Win, has been named minister after the National League for Democracy’s (NLD) appointee, Dr. Myint Htwe, resigned after Monday’s coup.**  http://web.archive.org/web/20210308203126/https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/burma/myanmar-health-ministry-continue-vaccinations-despite-coup.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210308203526/https://www.reuters.com/article/myanmar-politics-india-idUSKBN2A41VE

Vaccine: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19)    According to the US Embassy,    "COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Have Burmese authorities approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Are vaccines available in Burma for U.S. citizens to receive? – YES        Burmese authorities previously received approximately 3 million Covidshield/AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine doses in early 2021. These vaccines are being distributed without any public announcement of a vaccination plan. Burmese authorities have not communicated to the U.S. Embassy how or if they will provide this vaccine to foreign nationals residing in Burma."    However, based on previous information, dated 5th February, health workers and volunteers, as well as select elderly people over the age of 65 has started receiving the vaccine. There has been no further updates on Myanmar Times (the newspaper of record in Myanmar) as it has suspended reporting for three months starting 21 February due to the coup d'état.    See Myanmar Times' reporting on 5th Feb, archived at http://web.archive.org/web/20210412181318/https://www.mmtimes.com/news/more-380000-myanmar-receive-covid-19-vaccine.html  See the US Embassy's website, archived at https://archive.vn/o0WBl

'Mongolia will launch a nationwide COVID-19 vaccination campaign on Tuesday [23 Feb 2021], with frontline workers in health and security sectors receiving the first jabs, said Deputy Prime Minister Sainbuyan Amarsaikhan.  Amarsaikhan, also head of State Emergency Commission, made the announcement early Monday while attending the handover ceremony of 150,000 doses of the Covishield, a vaccine co-developed by the University of Oxford and pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca and produced by the Serum Institute of India.  Meanwhile, 300,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccine produced by Chinese pharma company Sinovac are set to arrive on Monday night, said Health Minister Sereejav Enkhbold.  Enkhbold said that Mongolia is expected to acquire four types of COVID-19 vaccines.'    https://archive.vn/8WI6C

A. The frontline health care workers at high risk.  Mongolia launched COVID-19 Vaccination Programme on 23 FEB, 'beginning with the frontline health care workers at high risk. Government of Mongolia has received an initial 150000 doses of AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine, produced by the Serum Institute of India, that has received Emergency Use Listing by the World Health Organization (WHO) and approval by Mongolia’s national regulatory authority. Following the arrival of further doses, other priority groups, including older people and those with health issues, which put them at higher risk for severe illness, will be vaccinated against the coronavirus.'    https://archive.vn/5Y993
No change in policy.

'Director of the Vaccination Department of the National Center for Communicable Diseases reported that since February 23, when the vaccination campaign kicked off in Mongolia, a total of around 13,200 people have received the first dose of AztraZeneca vaccine against coronavirus until today, March 4, Montsame reports.  Among them, 9500 people are healthcare personnel, including members of the teams administering COVID-19 vaccine, and 2,600 people are the first responders against CVOID-19, such as police, emergency management and professional inspection officials.  ...  According to the Ministry of Health, people over 50s, people with disabilities, individuals with underlying medical conditions, such as those with cardiovascular diseases, diabetes and cancer, groups of individuals of ready reserve mobilization for COVID-19 vaccination and response measures, employees of strategically-important sectors, such as border employees and coal-hauling truck drivers and employees of all-levels of educational organizations are next in line to receive coronavirus vaccines.'    https://archive.ph/R3eIP

As of 22 March, '[a] total of 223,444 people received first dose of vaccine so far nationwide, including 218,400 people in Ulaanbaatar and 5,044 people in Umnugobi aimag, since the vaccination campaign launched on February 23, Montsame reports.  According to the WHO recommendations, 98 percent of healthcare workers and 99 percent of personnel of other organizations that are working in the frontline to fight the COVID-19 have been inoculated. In Ulaanbaatar, about 185,000 people aged 50-64 are currently eligible for the first dose, of whom 19.5 percent have been inoculated. In addition, people over the age of 65 and those who had the transplants started receiving the first dose on March 22.'    https://archive.vn/De3Yz
No change in policy.

'Mongolia on Friday [i.e. 9 April 2021] received the first batch of COVID-19 vaccines it has purchased from China as part of the efforts to curb the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.  ...  Mongolia launched a COVID-19 vaccination campaign across the country on Feb. 23, and more than 323,600 people have been vaccinated so far, according to the country’s health ministry.  The country plans to vaccinate at least 60 percent of its 3.3 million people using four types of COVID-19 vaccines, and 20 percent will be vaccinated under COVAX, a global initiative for equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines, said the ministry.'    https://archive.vn/z4jJd     Unclear which Chinese vaccine is received.

Malawi received 360,000 doses of the AstraZeneca COVID vaccine on March 5 through the COVAX programme. "The Government of the Republic of Malawi has identified priority groups who will be among the first to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. These include health care workers, including those working in the private sector, who are at higher risk of COVID 19 infection than the general population due to the nature of their work, and more likely to be affected by COVID-19. Also included in phase one are police, immigration, Malawi Defence Force, teachers, prison warders, prisoners, those 60 years and above, and people with underlying conditions."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322031324/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20-%201-15%20March%202021.pdf

A,B,C:  AstraZeneca  The COVID 19 vaccine was launched in Malawi on 11 March 2021 in Zomba and Mzuzu districts concurrently, presided over by the State President and Vice President respectively. As of 15 March, 890 health workers and other frontline workers have been vaccinated. Malawi aims to vaccinate 20% of its population in the initial vaccination phase through the COVAX initiative.  "On COVID-19 vaccination, let me inform the public that we are continuously working on  training more vaccination teams in the districts to ensure that more vaccination sites become  operational to increase access to the COVID-19 vaccine to the priority groups in the first  phase. As communicated on Thursday that, apart from continuing vaccinating the Health  Care Workers and other Social Workers, we rolled out vaccinating those with underlying  conditions (such as diabetes, asthma, hypertension) and those aged 60 years and above. It is important to note that the delivery platform remains the government and CHAM health facilities. The public is requested to contact their local/district health authorities for specific vaccination schedules for their area or district as more sites are being opened from tomorrow.  Let me request those coming for vaccination to bring their National Identity Cards while  those with underlying medical conditions to also remember to bring their health passport book (health profile). The public should be reminded that the COVID-19 vaccine is free of  charge and that it is voluntary. In the spirit of Covax, the vaccine is being distributed to all  corners of the country to allow for equitable access. Let us all wait for our turn."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322035053/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3702864499769038    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322035650/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3702163413172480%3F__tn__%3DK-R    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322031324/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20-%201-15%20March%202021.pdf

"A,B,C:  AstraZeneca  COVID 19 vaccination was launched in Malawi on 11 March 2021.   Ministry of Health update on march 26: ""I would like to commend the public for the overwhelming response to the call to get  vaccinated especially for those targeted in this first phase. The response gives hope to the  COVID-19 fight in our country. On the overall, the rolling out has been smooth although in  some vaccination sites, we observed long queues due to high numbers of people coming to get vaccinated against the available staff. There were also some information gaps in some communities especially in the rural areas. In view of this, the Government through the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 has allocated additional resources to assist in vaccination roll out. These resources will help to address the bottlenecks currently being observed. As we are working on these challenges, I would like to appeal for patience as we will ensure that everyone targeted in the first receives the vaccine.    Once again I would like to thank those that have made the excellent decision to get vaccinated. This is very commendable since fighting the COVID-19 pandemic is a collective effort. Let me also request those that are not eligible to receive the vaccine in the first phase, to patiently wait for their turn which will be communicated in due course. My request for those not eligible is to desist from going to the vaccination sites now to give opportunity to the elderly and those with co-morbidities to be vaccinated since COVID-19 tends to be more severe in these categories of people. The public should be reminded that the COVID-19 vaccine is free of charge and that it is voluntary.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328193331/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3716961151692706%3F__tn__%3DK-R    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328192921/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3720073904714764%3F__tn__%3DK-R

"A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  Vaccination continues throughout the country targeting key workers, the elderly and clinically vulnerable groups. The government announced on March 29 that pregnant women are eligible for the vaccine. As of April 4, the government reports 157,581 distributed doses of the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine. Local news reported that the ""government has ordered medical personnel to expedite the process of the Covid 19 vaccine in vaccination centres. It follows observations that the vaccination exercise is not starting at the set time of 8am in most centres due to delayed delivery of the vaccines. This has led to crowding and long queues, thereby raising security concerns and frustrating some people to get the vaccine. Currently, the vaccination exercise targets the elderly, people with underlying conditions, journalists and other social workers.""     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404221016/https://www.nyasatimes.com/over-90-000-get-astrazeneca-jab-in-malawi/    April 4, MOH post: https://web.archive.org/web/20210404220051/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3746395888749232    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404215205/https://www.nyasatimes.com/govt-says-pregnant-women-can-now-get-vaccine/"

A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  Vaccination continues throughout the country targeting key workers, the elderly and clinically vulnerable groups. ""Currently, we are using the AstraZeneca vaccine and to get fully protected one is required to receive two doses at an interval of 8-12 weeks apart. Those that have received the first dose are encouraged to check on the vaccination card to see when their next dose is due.For those eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine in the first phase i.e. the health workers, other social workers, those aged 60 years and above and those with underlying conditions, please take note that the vaccination exercise is still in progress in all Government and CHAM facilities. Please take this opportunity to get vaccinated.""    April 5, MOH post: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412001337/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3748838631838291

A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  On April 6, the government announced that the vaccine is now available to everyone 18 years old and above. "I would like to inform the general public that we are now entering the second phase of COVID-19 vaccination whereby apart from those targeted in the first phase i.e. the health workers and other social workers, those aged 60 years and above and those with underlying conditions, the vaccination has been extended to everyone aged 18 years and above. My special appeal goes to those who by nature of their occupation interact with a lot of people on daily basis such as those working in banks, shops, vendors and those in the transport sector to come and get the vaccine. I would like to request everyone aged 18 years and above to utilize this opportunity to get vaccinated so that they are protected from COVID-19 severe disease, risk of hospitalization or death due to COVID-19. The vaccination exercise continues in all the Government and CHAM health facilities." According to Malawi government authorities, as of April 6, 2021, the vaccination has been extended to everyone 18 years old and above.  However, only 400,000 out of Malawi's 18 million citizens--approximately 2% of the population--have been vaccinated (coding as a 2, as vaccination rate is significantly lower than 20% of the target population and it does not seem that all key workers, vulnerable groups, or elderly groups have been vaccinated). Vaccines: AstraZeneca    The low vaccination rate is due to vaccine shortages and vaccine hesitancy. Malawi received a total of 512,000 doses, 93% of which have been used. Thousands of expired doses have had to be destroyed. The country is expecting a donation of 900,000 doses from the COVAX facility by the end of July.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621120834/https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/malawi-facing-covid-vaccine-shortage-after-burning-expired-doses    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621112953/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621121225/https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=~MWI

Vaccination has currently halted due to vaccine shortage. However prior to this, vaccines were available for people aged 18-59.    Vaccines available: Astra-Zeneca    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703055624/https://malawi.un.org/sites/default/files/2021-07/Malawi%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Update%20-%202.07.2021.pdf

AstraZeneca is the only vaccine currently in use in Malawi. However, misinformation, vaccine shortages, and vaccine burnings have impeded on Malawi's vaccination campaign, resulting in low uptake and vaccination numbers. Attempts to combat this are outlined in the below UN publication.   https://archive.ph/wsjzU  https://web.archive.org/web/20210726221550/https://mw.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Government of Malaysia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use, Malaysia began its national vaccination program in February, Phase 1 (February – April 2021): Front line workers including those working in healthcare, defense, security, and essential services, Phase 2 (April – August 2021): Senior citizens over age 60, individuals with disabilities, and individuals with health conditions that place them at higher risk, Phase 3 (May 2021 – February 2022): Adults age 18 and above. Priority will be given to those in red zones, followed by yellow, then green zones; source: /web/20210615072605/https://my.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

'Malaysia began its national vaccination program in February and foreign nationals residing in Malaysia are eligible for COVID-19 vaccination through this program. Malaysia’s vaccine program will have the following three phases:  Phase 1 (February – April 2021): Front line workers including those working in healthcare, defense, security, and essential services  Phase 2 (April – August 2021): Senior citizens over age 60, individuals with disabilities, and individuals with health conditions that place them at higher risk  Phase 3 (May 2021 – February 2022): Adults age 18 and above. Priority will be given to those in red zones, followed by yellow, then green zones.  Individuals in Malaysia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine in one of the following ways:  Through the MySejahtera app  Via Malaysia’s National Immunization Website  Via the National COVID-19 Vaccination Registration Line: 1800-888-828'  https://archive.vn/4t578    'The government aims to boost the country's vaccination rate to 400,000 a day in August in order to achieve 80 per cent herd immunity by September.  Covid-19 National Immunisation Programme (NIP) coordinating minister Khairy Jamaluddin said the government is targeting a maximum vaccination capacity of 300,000 per day in July.'  https://archive.vn/pP4ab    'While Malaysia had approved three vaccines for use in its National Immunisation Programme (mRNA-based vaccine Pfizer-BioNTech, the Oxford AstraZeneca and Sinovac’s CoronaVac), conditional approval has just been given to China’s CanSino Biologics and US Johnson & Johnson on Tuesday (Jun 15).'  https://archive.vn/d33Yc

First piece:  'Malaysia's health ministry said on Friday (Jul 16) it has granted conditional approval for emergency use to the COVID-19 vaccine manufactured by China's Sinopharm.  ...  Authorities have also granted conditional approval to the Janssen COVID-19 vaccine made by US drugmaker Johnson & Johnson and manufactured in Belgium, Dr Noor Hisham said.  Malaysia had earlier approved another batch of Janssen vaccines that had been given the greenlight for emergency use by the World Health Organization.  The approvals come a day after Malaysia's health ministry said that it would stop administering the COVID-19 vaccine produced by China's Sinovac once its supplies end, as it has a sufficient number of other vaccines for its programme.  Malaysia started its national COVID-19 immunisation programme on Feb 24. It has administered a total of 12,647,558 doses of COVID-19 vaccines as of Thursday, with more than 4 million people - or 12.3 per cent of the population - fully vaccinated so far.'  https://archive.vn/mYP34    Second piece:  'Malaysia will soon allow the commercial sale of COVID-19 vaccines manufactured by Chinese firms Sinopharm (1099.HK) and Sinovac (SVA.O), the science minister said on Friday, as authorities try to ramp up inoculation rates amid surging cases.  Malaysia has one of the region's highest number of coronavirus infections per-capita but also one of its fastest vaccination rates. About 39% of its adult population has received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine.  The Sinopharm vaccine, which Malaysia approved on Friday for emergency use, would soon be open for private purchase, science minister Khairy Jamaluddin told a virtual news conference.  Meanwhile, Sinovac vaccines would be available commercially from Aug. 1, after it has completed the delivery of some 15 million doses procured by the government, he said.  ...  Malaysia had previously said it would stop administering Sinovac vaccines after supplies run out, and would instead rely largely on the Pfizer-BioNTech (PFE.N), (22UAy.DE) mRNA vaccine for its national rollout. read more  On Friday, Khairy clarified that surplus Sinovac shots would remain available for those who may have allergy concerns with other vaccines.  "There is no issue over Sinovac's efficacy," he said.  Malaysia would also consider purchasing more doses from Sinovac in the event of a shortfall of AstraZeneca vaccines from neighbouring Thailand, Khairy said.'  https://archive.vn/teN8e

Namibia has made progress in preparation to acquire suitable COVID-19 vaccines. The government has already paid an amount of N$29 272 320 (US$1 626 240) to acquire vaccine doses enough to vaccine 20% (508 200 persons) of the population through the COVAX Facility. The government has also signed a Financial Commitment Agreement on the 5th November 2020 for the remaining US$9 096 780. The Facility has informed us on the 6 January 2021 that it may be in a position to initiate a small scale “first wave” of deliveries using the Pfizer vaccine as early as end of January or February.  Apart from the COVAX Facility, there have been engagements with Pfizer on a bilateral basis, China, Russia, and other countries that are making great progress in the manufacturing of COVID-19 vaccines for possible bilateral deals and or donations. We will prioritize frontline Health Care Workers and population groups vulnerable to severe COVID-19 disease once the vaccine become available.  Public education and community engagement on correct and authentic information about the vaccines is ongoing. The vaccine will save lives once it become available.    See "AMENDMENTS OF PUBLIC HEALTH COVID 19 GENERAL REGULATIONS: PUBLIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH ACT, 2015: DR KALUMBI SHANGULA, MP, MINISTER OF HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICES. 23RD COVID-19 PUBLIC BRIEFING" (https://web.archive.org/web/20210116183005/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Proposed+Ammendments+to+Current+Regulation+13.01.2021.pdf/5a9f41f2-cd24-4ffb-891b-9b053740e7af), with announced measures set to take effect at 23:59 on January 13th, 2021.
No change.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210124222442/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Daily+Update+22.01.2021.pdf/155c4bef-cd5d-4de3-b700-ff50b424b87e

COVID-19 Vaccine Information:   •	Has the government of Namibia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  No   •	According to Namibian Minister of Health and Social Services Kalumbi Shangula, Namibia has made progress in its preparation to acquire suitable COVID-19 vaccines.  The government has paid to acquire enough vaccine doses to vaccine 20% of the population through the COVAX Facility.  Namibia may receive a small–scale “first wave” of vaccine deliveries as early as the end of January or February.  Additional resources need to be secured for acquisition of additional doses to vaccinate at least up to 60% of the population in order to achieve a desirable level of herd immunity.  Namibia will prioritize frontline health care workers and population groups vulnerable to severe COVID-19 once the vaccine becomes available.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210129163942/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

There have been government announcements about preparations for the Pfizer vaccine and through the COVAX facility, but the specific details concerning vaccine delivery and administration are not clear. For reference, see also the announcement of previous government regulations from 13 January (https://web.archive.org/web/20210116183005/https://mhss.gov.na/documents/119527/828815/COVID-19+Proposed+Ammendments+to+Current+Regulation+13.01.2021.pdf/5a9f41f2-cd24-4ffb-891b-9b053740e7af).

According to the U.S. Embassy in Namibia, as of June 16, 2021, the vaccine is available to anyone who falls within Namibia's eligibility guidelines, which includes healthcare workers and clinically vulnerable populations. (A, B) Namibia has placed age restrictions on vaccines and includes the elderly as part of the eligible group (C). The available vaccines are Covishield and Sinovax.    According to Namibian Minister of Health and Social Services Kalumbi Shangula, Namibia has made progress in its preparation to acquire suitable COVID-19 vaccines.  The government has paid to acquire enough vaccine doses to vaccine 20% of the population through the COVAX Facility.  Namibia has begun vaccinating targeted populations with donated vaccines from China, and plans to roll out additional donated vaccines from India soon.  Namibia is prioritizing frontline health care workers and population groups vulnerable to severe COVID-19.  Minister Shangula also announced that non-Namibian citizens can receive a vaccine in Namibia if they fall into one of the designated priority groups eligible for the vaccine.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210616140741/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Health workers, vulnerable people over 60, members of the defence and security forces, refugees and migrants, are among groups being prioritised.  https://archive.vn/ArxUC    General information on the vaccines:   The Government of Niger has announced that COVID-19 vaccines are available in all eight of Niger’s regions.  Two vaccines are currently available in Niger: the Sinopharm vaccine and the AstraZeneca vaccine. As of 26 May 2021, a total of 159,525 vaccine doses have been administered. Those fully vaccinated make up 0.03% of the population and those that have received at least one dose make up 0.63%. First doses received via GAVI on 14 April 2021 (Doses received: 355,000 SII-AstraZeneca (COVISHIELD) vaccine*, doses allocated: 1,596,000). The second phase of the COVID-19 Astrazeneca vaccination began in Niger State May 19 with the Governor Abubakar Sani Bello receiving his second jab of the vaccine. In his remarks, the Commissioner for Health and Hospital Services in Niger, Dr Muhammad Makusidi, said the state has received a total of 89,600 doses as of May 20. He explained that 44,860 doses were used in the first phase, stressing that enough doses were available for the second phase of the vaccination exercise.  https://archive.vn/uXhfT  https://archive.vn/ZNUII  https://archive.vn/O4zxq  https://archive.vn/4yfq6  https://archive.vn/jseFa  https://archive.vn/xjySx

Nigeria is currently registering people electronically for vaccination to ensure efficient and orderly scheduling of the date and time to receive the vaccine, Mr. Shuaib tells Africa Renewal. This is the first time Nigeria will pre-register people for vaccination.    All persons 18 years and above can register for the vaccination through an e-registration portal. The country relies on the media to promote this e-registration under an electronic immunization data management scheme.     The vaccination is then carried out in phases, according to predetermined classifications, Mr. Shuaib says. Frontline health workers are prioritized for the jab so they can safely care for others.    The primary health care agency uses its electronic database to track those who have received the first dose in order to know when they are due for their second dose.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426191848/https://www.un.org/africarenewal/magazine/april-2021/nigeria-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-kicks-africas-most-populous-country

Despite these assurances, however, doubts persist which may further threaten the vaccination exercise, and possibly thwart the Nigeria’s authority target to vaccinate millions of eligible citizens within the next two years.    Aniette Patrick, journalist, says she thinks the issue of trust is a major challenge for most Nigerians because leadership has been a major challenge and people tend not to trust the system in place despite the campaigns and enlightenment.    “In Nigeria, I guess nonchalant attitude is one thing and lack of trust is another, people feel what the government is giving as vaccines may not be the same thing others are receiving, that is the common man understanding and I think that is the major factor,” she added.    Experts say vaccine hesitancy will not only threaten COVID-19 response but prevent Nigeria from achieving herd immunity.    The Public Relation officer, National Hospital, Abuja Tayo Haastrup reiterated that the Covid 19 response was first launched in National Hospital by the Federal government and on record, the first Doctor in Nigeria to take the vaccination in the center, is from the Hospital with two of their nurses.    Well within the first two weeks, we had a large turnout of people coming to take the vaccination and we created two venues for the vaccination. At the trauma center, we created some rooms there and we also we created another    “I am sure it was because of the awareness and media support within the period that encouraged people to come out for the vaccination but at today, the turnout is decreasing not as populated as it used to be when we started,” he said.    Chief consultant National Hospital, Abuja, Dr Rais Ibrahim, says as a healthcare provider, he has taken the vaccine so he can render his services to Nigerians adding that there is no pain and recommend everyone should get it.    ‘People are always resistant to change and something new but with time people will see the benefit of taking the vaccine so that you protect yourself and by extension protect your family,” he said.    A recent release by the National Primary Health Care Development Agency, NPHCDA, showed that only1, 043, 737 eligible Nigerians have so far been vaccinated with the first dose.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210510185706/https://www.africanews.com/2021/04/24/covid-19-nigerians-hesitant-to-get-vaccinated//

The FCT Primary Health Care Board (FPHCB) announced the end of the first round of Covid-19 vaccinations on the 14th of May, signalling that Nigeria had ended the first phase of the covid vaccinations which has so far helped reduced Nigeria’s infection rate to less than 50 cases per day, compared to over 500 during the peak of the second wave.    Last week, the federal government gave the green light for the commencement of the administration of the second dose of the Oxford-AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines on eligible Nigerians who had received their first shots.    On a visit to a Federal Hospital in Abuja where vaccinations are given, a nurse speaking anonymously disclosed to Nairametrics that the administration of the second dose of vaccinations is expected to commence sometime between the last week of May and the first week of June 2021.    Vaccination rate at the end of the first phase  At the end of the first phase on the 15th of May, 2021, Nigeria had used 89.2% of its first phase proportion, vaccinating 1,794,552 residents, according to the National Primary Health Care Development Agency.    Lagos State recorded the most vaccinations at 279,372, vaccinating 101% of its proportion, with the FCT vaccinating 96% of its proportion at 118,895.    Expectedly, Kogi State, which was one of the last states to resume vaccinations, has only vaccinated 14,401 residents, which is 66% of its first phase proportion.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210524171311/https://nairametrics.com/2021/05/17/covid-19-vaccines-where-nigeria-stands-today/

COVID-19 vaccines if you live in Nigeria  Wherever possible British nationals living in Nigeria should aim to be vaccinated in Nigeria. You should seek advice from your healthcare provider on the availability of vaccines locally. You can also obtain further information from National Primary Health Care Development Agency (NPHCDA) or contact individual State Health authorities who will be responsible for the vaccine roll out in each State.    A national vaccination programme was launched on 5 March. Health workers (and other front line staff) will be prioritised in the first phase. This will be followed by phase 2 (people aged 50 and above) and phase 3 (people with co-morbidities).    The vaccine registration e-portal is now open on the NPHCDA website. Nigerians and residents of Nigeria will be eligible according to priority. You should upload your National Identity Number (NIN), passport or other forms of ID as advised on the portal in order to register. You can get further information on registration from the NPHCDA on 00 234 (0) 803 123 0415/0416.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210621163406/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nigeria/coronavirus

"Order of vaccination  Health Council has advised on who to vaccinate first  Not everybody can be vaccinated at once. To protect the most vulnerable in society and relieve the pressure on healthcare services, a start was made in January 2021 on vaccinating the following groups:    Acute care hospital staff (staff working in intensive care units, A&E departments and on COVID-19 wards) and ambulance crews, who are directly involved in the care and treatment of COVID-19 patients.  Care professionals working in nursing homes, small-scale residential homes and disability care homes, district nurses and social support workers.  Nursing home residents and residents of homes for people with intellectual disabilities.  Plans for vaccinating subsequent groups will depend on factors like approval, effectiveness and delivery of vaccines. "    A- Key workers    C-Elderly groups (In care homes)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130131720/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/dutch-vaccination-programme/getting-vaccinated-against-covid-19

"In the Netherlands, the two-dose AstraZeneca vaccination is being given to people aged 60 to 65 as well as younger adults with morbid obesity and the over 18s with Down’s syndrome. Healthcare workers who have not yet been vaccinated will also come on board. From Monday, family doctors in Zeeland will start vaccinating their patients with the vaccine, and the programme will then be rolled out to Limburg, Brabant and then the rest of the country."   As this is not yet a national shift, left at 2G for now, but should be updated in the coming days/weeks. A start was made in January 2021 on vaccinating the following groups: 1) Acute care hospital staff (staff working in intensive care units, A&E departments and on COVID-19 wards) and ambulance crews, who are directly involved in the care and treatment of COVID-19 patients; 2) Care professionals working in nursing homes, small-scale residential homes and disability care homes, district nurses and social support workers; 3) Nursing home residents and residents of homes for people with intellectual disabilities.  Vaccination is free and isn’t compulsory. Vaccines used are as following: BioNTech/Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Moderna, Janssen. Vaccinations efforts are focused on those aged 60 to 64. In mountainous districts, everyone above 18 years of age will be vaccinated given the availability of vaccines. Vaccines: AstraZeneca, Sinovac    As many as 691,494 people across the country have so far received both shots of the vaccine against the coronavirus disease as of 12 June. A total of 2,422,376 people have been administered the first jab of the vaccine as of 14 June. However, the government is struggling to procure enough vaccine doses. About 1.4 million elderly Nepalese received an initial dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine in March but now are unsure when they can get a second dose as the government struggles to acquire the vaccine. Additionally, COVAX, the UN-backed project to supply vaccines to poor regions of the world, pledged Nepal 2 million doses by March but has only provided 248,000 because it also is facing a serious shortage.    Links: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621181237/https://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/nepal-receives-800-000-doses-of-coronavirus-vaccine-from-china-121060200071_1.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621181458/https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/nepal-covid19-cases-vaccines-1.6069389    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621180011/https://reliefweb.int/report/nepal/nepal-covid-19-response-situation-report-no-04-15-june-2021    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621181620/https://reliefweb.int/report/nepal/nepal-cover-covid-19-emergency-response-project-phase-ii-situation-report-6-16-june

26/01/2021: In a joint press release from the New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Arden and  Minister for the COVID-19 Response Chris Hipkins stated that “We expect the first vaccines will arrive in New Zealand by the end of the first quarter but we are making sure everything is in place in case of an earlier arrival…We acknowledge that there is international pressures for Pfizer and BioNTech to prioritise countries that have serious community transmission of COVID-19. As we have seen, timelines are changing often.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129073244/https://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/covid-19-vaccine-slated-possible-approval-next-week

"The Government has guaranteed that everyone in New Zealand will have access to the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. It has secured an additional 8.5 million doses, enough to vaccinate 4.25 million people."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318115418/https://covid19.govt.nz/health-and-wellbeing/covid-19-vaccines/covid-19-vaccines-in-new-zealand/vaccines-being-used-in-new-zealand/      A- Key workers: "The first people to be vaccinated are people working at the border or in MIQ, and the people they live with (household contacts).    People in Group 1 can get early access to a vaccine because border and MIQ workers are most at risk of contracting COVID-19. Vaccinating this group first will also potentially reduce the risk of transmission in the community."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318115740/https://covid19.govt.nz/health-and-wellbeing/covid-19-vaccines/getting-a-covid-19-vaccine/how-our-vaccine-rollout-will-work/vaccine-rollout-groups/

According to the vaccine timeline, A are being vaccinated but people living in high-risk areas are also being vaccinated. Since the latter includes people living and working in care homes, they belong to B and C. However, all people from B and C are not being vaccinated just yet.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329220854/https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccines/covid-19-getting-vaccine/covid-19-when-you-can-get-vaccine    The vaccine type seems to be Pfizer/BioNTech as the other vaccines are still in agreement-in-principle stage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329221058/https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccines/covid-19-types-vaccines

There is the only vaccine used in New Zealand - Pfizer/BioNTech. The Pfizer vaccine is free and available to everyone in New Zealand aged 16 and over it doesn’t matter what your visa or citizenship status is. There are several group sections to be vaccinated:  Group 1 — currently being vaccinated - border and managed isolation and quarantine (MIQ) workers; Group 2 -  currently being vaccinated - high-risk frontline workers and people living in high-risk places;  Group 3 — getting underway -  People who are at risk of getting very sick from COVID-19;  Group 4 — being vaccinated from the end of July - everyone aged 16 or over.     https://archive.fo/h8jdi   https://archive.fo/fKf7y   https://archive.fo/IKLG9

Oman has reserved 1 million doses of the vaccine from the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization (GAVI) which represents 20 per cent of the Sultanate's need. Sultanate has directly contracted with Pfizer and booked 370,000 vaccine doses 20,000 of which is expected to be delivered in December and the remainder will arrive at the beginning of next year. Oman plans to cover 40% of population in the 1st stage. No availability at the moment, please keep watching this index.  https://archive.vn/OY2G6

A:    27 December  Dubai: Oman has launched a national COVID-19 vaccination campaign, with the sultanate’s health minister receiving the first dose of the Pfizer vaccine, local media reported.  State-run media reported that the first batch of 15,600 doses was flown in industrial freezers to Muscat International Airport last week to vaccinate a priority group of older adults, health care workers and those with underlying health conditions starting on Sunday (27 December).    The Health Ministry said the initial phase of the vaccination campaign would cover 20 percent of the population due to temporarily limited supply.    During the early stages of vaccine distribution, priority to develop immunity from COVID-19 will be given to those working on the frontline,” - therefore despite intentions to vaccinate more groups, have coded just one until further evidence emerges    https://web.archive.org/web/20210108103954/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/oman/oman-launches-national-covid-19-vaccine-campaign-1.76136737     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118143949/https://www.hoteliermiddleeast.com/news/121645-oman-to-offer-covid-19-vaccine-from-december-27

Oman currently is on an inoculation drive with Pfizer as well as Astra Zeneca vaccines, with over 32 per cent of the population having received the shots as of February 24.    The first phase started with the coverage of frontline medical staff and among general population, those with immuno-compromised health above 65 years of age. As per the announcement by Dr. Saeedi, this week will see the start of vaccination for those who are 60 and above.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210323092955/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/oman/oman-covid-19-vaccine-for-ages-60-and-over-this-week-1.77492480

91,000 people in the country (57 per cent of the target groups) have already received the vaccinations. Around 30,000 people have received both doses, and 60,000 have been given a single dose so far. The country aims to receive 5.4 million doses of the vaccine by the end of this year. 30 per cent of Oman’s population will be given the coronavirus vaccine by the end of June, and 70 per cent by the end of 2021.   To date, the country has signed contracts to obtain 3.02 million doses of vaccines from multiple manufacturers: Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Johnson & Johnson’s. Negotiations with other companies will be made once they have reached the minimum requirements acceptable by international bodies. The vaccine is distributed to three main groups: A) A large number of healthcare workers; B) clinically vulnerable people; C) Elderly above 60 years of age.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210322090049/https://timesofoman.com/article/30-of-omans-population-to-get-vaccinated-before-june

"I congratulate [all those present here] for working at great speed to import a vaccine. We also thank China for gifting us 500,000 vaccines," he said.    The premier also sought to assure the nation that the vaccine distribution across the various provinces is being done in a "just" manner. "No one should think we distributed more vaccines in a given province than in others." The national government has determined the first 25 million Filipinos to be given a COVID-19 vaccine. Presidential Spokesman Harry Roque presented a tally of these priority vaccine recipients during a press conference on Monday, December 7.  Unclear when this comes into effect so coded as a 0    Here's what he presented:    1st priority - Frontline health workers: 1,762,994    Breakdown: 612,975 public and private health facilities, 602,982 public health workers and local government contact tracers, 414,640 barangay health workers and barangay emergency health response teams, 132,397 from DSWD, DepEd, DILG, BJMP, Bureau of Corrections    2nd priority - Indigent senior citizens: 3,789,874    3rd priority - Remaining senior citizens: 5,678,544    4th priority - Remaining indigent population: 12,911,193    5th priority - Uniformed personnel like from the military, police, Coast Guard, Bureau of Fire Protection, CAFGU: 525,523    TOTAL: 24,668,128    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207220724/https://www.rappler.com/nation/covid-19-updates-philippines-december-2020

"No coronavirus vaccine has been approved for general use in the Philippines, nor is one expected to arrive, officially, until at least February. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210119022651if_/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/vaccine-coronavirus-chinese-workers-philippines/2021/01/16/e5126c88-4f09-11eb-a1f5-fdaf28cfca90_story.html

Following approval of the Pfizer-BioNTech and AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccines, Phillippines is expected to begin receiving vaccines from the COVAX Facility beginning mid-February.  In total, Phillippines is expecting 117,000 doses of Pfizer-BioNTech's vaccine, and 5,500,800 to 9,290,400 indicative doses of AstraZeneca's vaccine subject to UNICEF and Pan American Health Organization established supply agreements with manufacturers.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1129105

On February 7, priority list for vaccinations are announced. "The national government would only need less than a month to vaccinate all health front-liners in the country, Malacañang on Sunday said as the country expects the first doses of the Covid-19 vaccine to arrive this month."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208034013/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1129912

A (health workers, uniformed personnel), C (senior citizens), and B (indigent residents): Pfizer-BioNtech vaccine    "At least 537,820 Dabawenyos will receive the first shots when the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) vaccines are rolled out here, the City Health Office (CHO) said Thursday. The priority groups include 16,677 health workers, 77,189 senior citizens, 5,258 uniformed personnel, and 432,549 indigent residents."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221211457/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1131032    "The Philippine Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has granted authorization for emergency use of Pfizer BioNTech’s and AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccines in the Philippines."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221205117/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On 25 February, Health Secretary Francisco Duque said that Sinovac Biotech’s COVID-19 vaccine is safe and effective, citing assurances from the medical community.    The country expects to receive the first delivery of 600,000 doses of Sinovac COVID-19 vaccines donated by the Chinese government.    It is also awaiting the delivery of 3.5 million doses of vaccines manufactured by AstraZeneca and Pfizer, through the COVAX Facility, a global alliance that seeks to help poor countries vaccinate their populations.    Galvez, who is also the chief implementer of the National Task Force Against COVID-19, reported that for the first quarter, the Philippines will receive a total of 5.1 million vaccine doses.    In the second quarter, a total of 24.1 million doses is expected to be delivered to the Philippines, which will come from COVAX and government procurements.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210302061146/https://pia.gov.ph/press-releases/releases/1067871

On 28 February, the 600,000 doses of Sinovac-made vaccines finally arrived in Manila on Sunday as part of China's commitment to supporting the Philippines' vaccination rollout.    The Chinese military plane carrying the donated vials called CoronaVac landed at the Villamor Airbase in Pasay City past 4 p.m. and was welcomed by several Cabinet members.    President Rodrigo Duterte also witnessed the historic event and inspected the crates containing the vials, the first-ever to arrive in the Philippines, during its ceremonial turnover to the Philippine government.    In his speech, Duterte thanked the Chinese government for the vaccine donation, confident that more batches of vaccines will be available at the earliest possible opportunity.    “I convey my sincere gratitude to the Chinese people and the government of China for this gesture of friendship and solidarity – the hallmark of Philippines-China partnership,” he said.    Duterte also reiterated his statement that Covid-19 vaccines should be treated as a global public good and made available to all, rich and poor alike    “No nation – no people - should be left to suffer the ravages of this pandemic for whatever reason," he said.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210302061604/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1132107

A (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Dr. Edwin Miraflor, officer-in-charge of the City Health Office (CHO) in Manila, said the first batch of vaccinees who took the second dose were among those who initially received the vaccines on March 5 and 7. Data from the CHO showed that some 5,452 medical front-liners here have been inoculated against Covid-19 as of March 31. Of the number, 3,095 received Sinovac while 2,357 were given Astra Zeneca.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406002735/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135808

A, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Announced March 28, Philippine will begin vaccinating the elderly alongside healthcare workers. The country has so far received 525,600 doses of AstraZeneca vaccines through the World Health Organization-led COVAX Facility. Apart from AstraZeneca vaccines, the country has also so far got 1 million doses Sinovac’s CoronaVac vaccine donated by Chinese government.  The national government’s vaccine priority list are as follows: A1 refers to frontline medical workers, A2 refers to senior citizens aged 60 and above, and A3 refers to persons with comorbidities.    In addition, President Duterte has announced Philippine will allow private companies to import COVID-19 vaccines "at will" in order to vaccinate their workers, in addition to those secured by the government provided the orders follow guidelines and are approved by the National Task Force.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406003259/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135144  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329072412/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135197    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406003846/https://pcoo.gov.ph/news_releases/govt-allows-private-firms-to-import-covid-19-vaccines/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210330095530/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135371

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): In press briefing with the Presidential Spokesperson of Philippine, "as of April 3, 2021, 795,320 people have been vaccinated with the first dose of COVID-19 vaccines at 2,669 vaccination sites in the country. Of this number, 765,871 are frontline health care workers. Vaccination has also begun for senior citizens and individuals with comorbidities. A total of 16,121 grandparents were vaccinated in NCR and Region IV-A, while 13,328 were vaccinated against individuals with comorbidity."    The Philippines aims to secure 148 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines from several companies to inoculate an initial 50 to 70 million Filipinos this year. The bulk of vaccine doses are expected to arrive by the second and third quarters of the year.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406004822/https://pcoo.gov.ph/press-briefing/press-briefing-with-presidential-spokesperson-harry-roque-12/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210406004846/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1135813

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): The Department of Health (DOH) on April 8 adopted the recommendation of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to temporarily suspend the use of AstraZeneca vaccines for individuals aged below 60 years old, following reports of rare cases of blood clots with low platelets detected in some individuals inoculated with the vaccine.  To date, the National Adverse Events Following Immunization Committee has not received any local reports of such side effects.  The NTF and the DOH reiterated that vaccination is safe and free. Senior citizens and persons with comorbidities are urged to receive the available vaccines from their local government units.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412034914/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1136165

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Directed by the government of Philippines, local government units are further enjoined to prioritize the generation of the demand for vaccination to those with highest risk for severe disease and death, particularly Priority Groups A2 (senior citizens aged 60 and above) and A3 (persons with comorbidities).  Use of AstraZeneca on persons under 60 continues to be suspended.    500,000 more doses of Sinovac vaccines arrived on Sunday afternoon from Beijing.  Jabs from Russia's Gamaleya Research Institute and US firm Moderna will arrive this month while deals with Pfizer-Biotech are ongoing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412031525/https://pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/20210410-IATF-RESOLUTION-109-A.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412035821/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1136401

A, B, C (Sinovax & AstraZeneca): Priority Groups A1 (frontline medical workers), A2 (senior citizens aged 60 and above) and A3 (persons with comorbidities) continue to be prioritized for vaccinations.  When there is sufficient supply of vaccines, Priority Group A4 (essential workers) will be able to get vaccinated simultaneously with the previous 3 groups. A4 Essential workers include: members of the media, basic education personnel, government workers, and economic frontliners.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419233202/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1136850  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419233523/http://www.radyopilipinas.ph/rp-one/articles/national/a4-catergory-sa-pagbabakuna-posible-nang-simulan-sa-oras-na-madagdagan-ang-mga-bakuna-sa-bansa

See the press release related to the World Immunization Week, dated 4/24/21: "Currently, the COVID-19 vaccine is also currently being rolled out among priority groups, beginning with health workers, and vulnerable individuals such as the elderly and persons with comorbidities."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426191247/https://doh.gov.ph/2019-nCoV
Around 5,000 Covid-19 vaccine were rolled out to minimum wage workers and OFWs included in the A4 vaccination group on May 1 for the observance of Labor Day.    https://archive.vn/scMRe
The Department of Health announced on 7 May to reallow the use of the Oxford AstraZeneca vaccine for all age groups.    https://archive.vn/wARy4

Only A and B are currently being prioritised for vaccines. Please check previous coding.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517221900/https://doh.gov.ph/Vaccines/when-will-the-COVID-19-available-to-me
No change in policy    A,C; Vaccines - Sinovac and AstraZeneca    https://web.archive.org/web/20210525212716/https://doh.gov.ph/Vaccines/when-will-the-COVID-19-available-to-me

(AstraZeneca, Sinovac): As of May 26, a total of 4,495,375 Filipinos have received at least one dose of the Covid-19 vaccine, 1,029,061 of them now fully vaccination. Among those who have been fully vaccinated, about 581,797 are health services front-liners, 195,952 are senior citizens, 250,777 are individuals with comorbidity, and 535 are essential sector front-liners.  Priority Group A4 refers to informal essential workers who cannot work from home will begin vaccinations in June.  Sputnik V vaccines have also arrived but no mention that they have been distributed to the population yet.    “Most of those we’ve vaccinated, those in priority group A1, we’re already at 85 percent, first dose who are master-listed, second are the senior citizens at 12 percent only so we need to promote the A2 and A3 (groups). The vaccination of A4 may start on the first week of June), symbolic was May 1st for our OFWs and labor force who belong to the A4. But we’ll just do this in what we call NCR Plus 8, so that’s NCR, Bulacan, Cavite, Pampanga, Laguna, Batangas, Rizal, [Metro] Cebu and [Metro] Davao only, while the other regions continue with A1 to A3."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210601053739/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1141516  https://web.archive.org/web/20210601053950/https://pcoo.gov.ph/news_releases/be-part-of-the-solution-get-vaccinated-palace/

The Government presented yesterday, December 3, the Vaccination Plan against Covid-19. According to the document, the vaccine, which should arrive in Portugal as early as January, will be universal, free and optional, and will be made available to the population according to the characteristics approved by the European Medicines Agency. Three phases are planned for the implementation of the vaccination plan against Covid-19 in 2021, which will accompany the pace of availability of vaccines.    1st phase - It is intended for people over 50 with associated pathologies; residents and professionals in nursing homes and long-term care units; Health professionals; armed forces, security forces and critical services professionals. At this stage, approximately 950 thousand people should be vaccinated.    2nd phase - In this phase 1.8 million people over 65 years of age and around 900 thousand with associated pathologies and over 50 years will be vaccinated.    3rd phase - The rest of the population. The groups in this phase will be reviewed according to the pace of delivery of the vaccines    Vaccine administration  The first phase of vaccination will be administered at the approximately 1,200 vaccination points that are usual in health centers, in homes and long-term care units.  The health centers will be destined to 400 thousand people over 50 years old and associated comorbidities, while users and home professionals will be vaccinated there by the resident nursing teams.  The vaccine will also be administered to health professionals and essential services in the field of occupational medicine.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213003729/https://www.sns.gov.pt/noticias/2020/12/04/plano-de-vacinacao-contra-a-covid-19/

A,C:      Portugal begins vaccinating frontline health workers on 27 December. If all goes according to plan (meaning the Pfizer vaccination gets European Medicine Agency approval later this month), Phase One will start in January immunising:    People over the age of 50 with at least one of the following pathologies: cardiac insufficiency, heart disease, renal insufficiency or chronic respiratory disease requiring ventilation.  Residents of old people’s homes and those interned in professional continuous care facilities  Healthcare professionals directly involved in caring for the sick, Armed Forces personnel, security forces and all ‘essential service personnel’ (criteria still to be defined).    Code remains the same as this extra clause for clinically vulnerable has not yet been bought into effect    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111141448/https://www.portugalresident.com/portugals-vaccination-programme-opens-with-950000-getting-shots-between-january-and-february/

From February 2021 : People aged =50 years, with at least one of the following pathologies: Cardiac insufficiency Coronary heart disease, Renal insufficiency (Glomerular Filtration Rate <60ml / min)  (COPD) or chronic respiratory disease under ventilatory support and / or long-term oxygen therapy.  People aged 80 and over.    The Prime Minister said "this week we started the second part of the first phase, now addressing everyone over 50 years old who have a set of associated diseases and to the entire population over 80 years old, and also to all those who provide essential services to the country, namely those who work in the security forces and services "    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206180604/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/vacinacao-covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206180731/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/noticia?i=comeca-vacinacao-das-forcas-de-seguranca-armadas-e-de-trabalhadores-de-servicos-essenciais

Portugal has announced that it is suspending the inoculation of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine as a “precaution,” joining other European countries – including France, Germany, Italy and Spain – in halting its use following reports of blood clots post inoculation.    “Portuguese health authorities today decided to suspend the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine against Covid-19 for reasons of precaution and public health,” Portugal’s national health authority said Monday in a statement.     According to the national health authority, the decision was taken “due to reports of the appearance of blood clots in vaccinated people.”    The decision comes despite assertions from the United Kingdom’s Joint Committee on Vaccinations and Immunizations (JCVI) that the vaccine has been “rigorously tested for safety.”     The European Medicines Agency (EMA) also said Monday that the benefits of the AstraZeneca vaccine outweigh the risks, adding that the number of people developing blood clots after vaccination does not seem to be higher than in the general population.    The agency said it would hold an emergency meeting on Thursday to advise on “any further actions that may need to be taken.”    Note: Despite this suspension, the three priority groups continue to be vaccinated.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210316142901/https://edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-pandemic-vaccine-updates-03-16-21/h_4342ae241ec9a83567b7eabedfc3b111

The president of Infarmed, Rui Ivo, started by revealing that the experts made an analysis of the vaccine that shows that "the benefits are greater than the risks" (...)". The list of priorities for the second phase of the vaccination plan against covid-19 will be changed, if the proposal of the specialist committee of the Directorate-General for Health (DGS) is approved. The plan is to start vaccinating by age, using the criterion of decreasing age groups, but simultaneously including people with diseases associated with increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19, and without age limit. A new “two-legged strategy that will run in parallel”, the DGS said this Thursday.  (...) In the second phase, which begins after the completion of the vaccination of the priority groups of the first phase, on April 11, as announced by the task force coordinator, this new strategy must be “adjusted in order to vaccinate the largest number of people in the smallest period of time ”and taking into account“ an expected increase in the doses of vaccines available.".  Source: https://archive.vn/QtcHO

Starting this Friday, April 23, individuals aged 65 or above (including those without any pre-existing conditions) will be able to chose the date and place of vaccination in the Health Directorate General portal. They will be able to accept the date suggested by the portal, chose another one or stay on the waiting list. Those who register in this portal will have to wait for an SMS that will confirm the date, time and place.     According to the government, 2,015,225 people have already taken the first dose, while 689,329 (representing approximately 7% of the population) already have complete vaccination against the virus SARS-CoV-2. By age group, 91% of the elderly over 80 years old (617,566 people) are already vaccinated with the first dose and 58% (394,186) have already received both doses of the vaccine. In the age group between 65 and 79 years old, 42% (669,263) also received the first dose of the vaccine a percentage that drops to just 4% (59,658) if we consider those who have taken the two doses.    Note: Upgraded to 4 since, according to the codebook "Broad groups may include a large group of adults, for example those aged 50-65". In this case, includes those aged 65-79.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210514231120/https://www.jn.pt/nacional/pessoas-com-mais-65-anos-podem-agendar-vacinacao-a-partir-de-hoje-13603627.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210514232113/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/23/sociedade/noticia/65-anos-saiba-agendar-vacinacao-covid19-1959726

The Health Secreatary of State, António Lacerda Sales, announced that the Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, of the Johnson & Johnson group, will be recommended to people over 50 years old and will start start being administred now.     He added that the ongoing studies and the data that are still being analyzed by the European Medicines Agency can justify the revision of this recommendation at any time. Those who are under 50 can choose to receive the Janssen vaccine, as long as they are informed about the benefits and risks, and expressly give their consent.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210501173819/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/portugal-recomenda-vacina-da-johnson-para-pessoas-com-mais-de-50-anos--13629866.html

""“In view of the good pace at which vaccination against Covid-19 has been taking place, it is reported that the possibility of self-scheduling is now available for ages 55 and over," says the 'task force' in a statement sent to newsrooms.  The measure to extend the age comes just four days after having opened on Sunday the appointment for over 60 years, a development that reflects the period of intensification of vaccination."  According to the 'task force' schedule, vaccinations for this new age group should only start from next 24 May.  In a table presented on 27 April, at the last Infarmed meeting, the coordinator of the national vaccination plan against Covid-19, Gouveia e Melo, said that the goal for people between 60 and 69 years of age is that everyone has a dose of the vaccine by 23 May. Already for the group between 50 and 59 years, which includes part of the population now covered with the new extension of self-scheduling, the appointed date is 13 June." "The task force for vaccination against covid-19 in Portugal will implement a system that involves the initiation of simultaneous vaccination for various age groups with a one week interval between them, between the end of May and the beginning of June.  The over-50s will start to be vaccinated first; a week later jabs will start to be given to the over-40s, and one week later the over-30s.    The objective, according to reports, is to take advantage of Johnson & Johnson's vaccines for the over-50s, and use Pfizer and Moderna for other age groups."    Source: https://archive.vn/Sy7Cn

"The self-scheduling of the vaccine against Covid-19 will be available from the next few hours this Monday for people aged 40 or over (...) A.    Palestine started its vaccination campaign on 04.02.2021 after the arrival of a first shipment of 2,000 doses of American firm Moderna’s vaccine.  After health workers, people over the age of 60 and those with chronic diseases will be vaccinated.  The Palestinian government has also placed orders for the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine and will receive it “during the coming period.”  Some 37,000 vaccine doses are also due to arrive in Palestine under the COVAX initiative, according to the minister.    10,000 doses of Russia's Sputnik V vaccine have been delivered to the West Bank but the rollout has been dogged by problems. The Palestinian Authority (PA) accused Israel on Monday of holding up the delivery of 2000 Sputnik V vaccine doses into Gaza, where Palestinians have yet to receive any.    https://archive.vn/utPXZ  http://web.archive.org/web/20210215224314/https://www.bbc.com/news/55800921  http://web.archive.org/web/20210215224850/https://english.alarabiya.net/coronavirus/2021/02/16/Palestinians-accuse-Israel-of-preventing-coronavirus-vaccine-transfer-to-Gaza

On 2 February, the Palestinian MoH launched its vaccination campaign in the West Bank, following the donation of 12,000 doses of the Modena and Sputnik V vaccines, giving priority to frontline health workers in ICUs. On 15 February, the MoH announced that it had to delay a broader rollout of the vaccination campaign, due to delays in anticipated deliveries.    In Gaza, the first batch of vaccines, 2,000 doses of Sputnik V, arrived on 17 February; an additional 20,000 does of Sputnik V were delivered on 21 February, as a donation from the United Arab Emirates. The vaccination campaign in Gaza began on 22 February, targeting frontline health workers.    The first vaccines delivered through the Gavi COVAX AMC Facility, in partnership with WHO and UNICEF, are now expected to arrive in March, including 37,400 doses of Pfizer/BioNTech, subject to agreement with the manufacturers. A further allocation of 240,000 doses of the Oxford-AstraZenica vaccine are also expected, probably in June.    Through COVAX, the Palestinian Authority PA is eligible to receive donor funded COVID-19 vaccines for up to 20 percent of its population and has applied for additional doses to cover an additional 40 per cent of the population on a self-financing basis. According to the World Bank(link is external), about US$55 million will be needed to vaccinate 60 per cent of Palestinians, of which there is an existing gap of $30 million.    Israel is continuing its vaccination programme, which is also available to Palestinians in East Jerusalem, and currently ranks first globally for per capita vaccinations(link is external), with over three and a half million people already vaccinated with the first dose. On 23 February, Israel opened a vaccination centre at Qalandiya checkpoint for Palestinians with Israeli residency (from East Jerusalem) who live beyond the Barrier, and who face problems in accessing the remainder of Jerusalem city.    On 28 February, the Israeli government approved a plan to vaccinate over 120,000 Palestinians without Israeli residency, who are employed in Israel or in Israeli settlements, to be implemented at border crossings and in industrial zones across the West Bank. A number of Israeli, Palestinian and international health and human rights organizations, as well as Israeli health officials, have called on(link is external) the Israeli authorities to ensure that vaccines are equally and fairly provided to Palestinians living under occupation in the West Bank and Gaza.    https://archive.vn/HQxN3

C,B,A:  Per the Ministry of Public Health, vaccinations are prioritized for Older People (defined as over 60), people with sever chronic conditions (inc. diabetes, asthma, heart disease, compromised immune systems), and healthcare workers at higher risk of exposure. Details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210118165327/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Covid19-Vaccine/Pages/Priority-groups.aspx

Everyone is at risk of getting COVID-19 and developing serious complications from the virus, but certain population groups are at higher risk and it is therefore more important for these groups to receive the vaccine as soon as it is available.     Initially, vaccines will be prioritized for three key population groups: older people, people with certain chronic conditions and key healthcare workers.    Older people   Evidence from both here in Qatar and around the world clearly shows that the risk of developing severe complications due to COVID-19 increases with age. People over 60 years of age have a higher risk of severe illness and death.     People with severe chronic conditions   People with certain long-term chronic medical conditions, including diabetes, asthma, and heart disease, or compromised immune systems, have an increased risk of developing severe complications as a result of COVID-19, regardless of their age.     Healthcare workers at high risk of exposure to COVID-19?    Healthcare workers, especially doctors, nurses and paramedics working directly with COVID-19 patients, have an increased risk of being exposed to COVID-19 and catching the virus and becoming sick. Additionally, healthcare workers who catch the virus can spread it to their patients, many of whom may be at increased risk of severe complications due to chronic conditions or compromised immune systems. ??  /web/20210209193238/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Covid19-Vaccine/Pages/Priority-groups.aspx

Hoti added that besides 535,000 Pfizer-BioNtech vaccines, some 600,000 doses would come from Austria and an additional 720,000 based on the World Health Organization COVAX programme. While Kosovo is expected to receive its first vaccines from the World Health Organization's COVAX program for poorer countries, they are not yet delivered.
